user_comment: I bought Divinity: Original Sin for PS4. PoE actually interests me more, so I wish I had known that this was coming out when I did. Then again, D:IS has online co-op, so that is a big sell for me. Can't go wrong with either one, right?

shiiiiit i'm very tempted
This game is so addicting and is def a 9/10.

Was really stoked to pick this up on PS4 until I heard about the long loading times... I mean... it's a 15GB game! What reason is there in 2017 for a game with these graphics to have a minute loading screen!?

They made the PS4 controls easier and better than keyboard and mouse ever was for this game.
Played the PC version extensively before getting the PS4 version yesterday. A few hours in on my current playthrough on PS4 and I can tell you they did a phenomenal job with the controls, the GUI, gameplay, graphics, man everything. I absolutely love how they made it so easy and intuitive to interact with your environment (looting, starting conversations, opening doors/chests) and how smooth and straightforward the other game mechanics are.
I cringed the whole time, but if you like it that's cool too.
This looks awesome. Diablo 3 was damn good on consoles.

Yea but except for the top down view, it's really not like Diablo. It's more like the old Baldur's Gate games of the 90's. Lots of reading, walking around and long periods between combat.
img {-moz-force-broken-image-icon: 1;}
I imagine playing this on consoles would be a form of torture.  Great game but I'll stick with my mouse and keyboard.
@Fennarth It seems like they figured out the most elegant possible solution for this problem.

@Fennarth  M/KB is so overrated.  Nothing like sitting at a desk like your working- very uncomfortable.  Controllers were specifically designed for gaming, M/KB- negative.  The only reason I can see M/KB is competitive PC FPS games.  I can see this game being M/KB though- its whats the term- CRPG? makes sense.
@Fennarth  So FPS and CRPG- correction.
@JEF848484 @Fennarth  Also RTS's, TBS's, visual novels, MOBA's, regular RPG's, ARPG's (Diablo, Path of Exile, etc), and anything else which require's precision or lots of different commands.

@Obrusnine @JEF848484 @Fennarth True- But I can care less about most of those genres.  What do you mean by "regular RPG's"?   I just cant fathom sitting up tight at a desk for hours and hours after doing it at work all day.  Pressing the wrong dam keys, etc...To each their own though.

@JEF848484 @Obrusnine @Fennarth  What does it matter if you don't care? That doesn't mean they don't exist. These genres are why the M+KB remains a very relevant control scheme, because some games are meant for a controller and some are meant for a keyboard. It would be lunacy to ever limit myself to using just one.

As for "regular" RPGs, I mean stuff that wouldn't be considered an Action-RPG (The Witcher 3). Stuff like Dragon Age, Mass Effect, or anything else with a deep ability pool. On console those games need to be constantly paused in order to select your abilities (especially the earlier games) while on PC you get a much more convenient hotbar.
@Obrusnine @JEF848484 @Fennarth What you call convenient, I call uncomfortable and awkward- agree to disagree. game on.

@JEF848484 @Obrusnine @Fennarth  So, you find it more comfortable to have to constantly pause your experience in order to issue commands, than to have your commands instantly recognized? Controllers alone can extend the playtime of these games up to 10 hours or more. I'm not just saying it's more convenient, it is objectively more convenient and is also much of the time the way the game was meant to be played. 

Micromanagement on a controller is a pain in the ass. It doesn't mean it isn't possible, but to pretend like you're not getting an inferior experience is just moronic.

@Obrusnine @JEF848484 @Fennarth I disagree as I have played Witcher 3, Dragon Age and Mass Effect on console and I was seldom inconvenienced by the controls.  I was only talking about Pillars of Eternity as a mouse cursor is clearly more convenient.

I mostly game on consoles, owning both a PS4 and XB1, but a game of these mechanics was obviously intended to be played with a mouse and keyboard.  It just seems annoying trying to direct combat with a controller when precision is demanded.  I don't care much for RTS games either.

@Fennarth O yea I agree, as these games were purely made for PC gaming.  FPS games makes sense too cause of the aiming.  Long RPGS with a lot of questing for hours and hours - controller all the way.  Its not that I oppose M/KB (though I can see how would think that, lol)- its the positioning, up tight at a computer desk- the identical position after sitting at work for hours- is so not relaxing.
Would love to play a demo of it on PS4 but there isn't one. Potential customer lost.

I have to say that I am very glad I don't listen to most reviews when it comes to my purchases! I haven't had this much fun with Mario since Sunshine. However, Mario isn't the star of this show. The Rabbids are the greatest thing to hit a Mario game since Yoshi! I know that sounds hard to believe but let me explain. I laughed almost at every turn and video games hardly ever make me laugh! It is well written and keeps each world fresh with new ideas! Not that my opinion counts but this is the best game of the year! Why? I had the most fun playing it! Beat the last boss today and now going back to complete all challenges! 9.1

After a little over 15 hrs I feel like my score would be a little higher than IGN's (maybe an 8.5?). I love the game. It's much deeper, and harder than I expected it to be, too. And bonus for me: my 3 old daughter likes to watch me play it. She asks too many questions, but at least I get to play a fun video game instead of watching another show about dinosaurs (she's obsessed with dinosaurs).

So the nice goat mom turned into a broken heart, which made these people gush with emotions.  Is this IGN for kids?  What are these people talking about?!  How was this slideshow selected GOTY 2015?  I can see how something like this can be nominated for some weird category like “2D games from last century”, but 2015 game of the year?!  Am I missing something here? 

These reviewers have the minds of 5-year olds, and they sound like they just discovered the RPG genre.  These guys focus on some strange emotional aspect of the game, while ignoring what their eyes see (or they haven't played a game in the last three decades).  I had a hard time matching their emotional outbursts to the visuals they showed us.  Maybe I’m losing my mind.

IGN reviews need more balance and consistency.  There should be some baseline on which every game is judged, which should apply to all reviewers.  If a game is rated as a “masterpiece” because the reviewers completely ignored the visual aspect, they are being unfair to other more esthetically pleasing, and modern looking games that got lower scores because of something else.  This game looks worse than most modern games, so just based on that it cannot be a 10!  By the way, a game can be made to look and feel old-school, and still look great, but THIS is not it.  This is just cheap looking, with little or no effort put in the design, considering today’s standards and possibilities.  The reviewers ignore this aspect entirely.  This is BS.
@unknown123_536957  I agree 100%
Ridiculous score for a game that looks as it was produced in the 80's.  IGN haven't got a clue.

It looks like it belongs on the Atari 2600 -- and I'm only slightly exaggerating.  You're giving this game ... a 10.  Out of ... 10.  What's the catch?  Is this a "masterpiece" for 1983?  Yes, it probably was.  Maybe that's what your reviewer meant.

I recommend that you fire whoever it was who chose this game to have this score, and then fire the editor who allowed this review to be published.  Anyone can arbitrarily choose some crazy niche game to ace the scoring system.  It's an entirely other matter to keep a standard that is followed by ALL the games that get reviewed!

This is good but it's not a 10. An how the fuck do they give this game such a high score for its narrative but only give "to the moon" a 7.5, when that game probably had a better one. It's a top down 2d game as well and it's the only game besides ff7 to ever make me cry. They Need more consistency

Finally! Beat this game tonight. Took me like 3 weeks. I enjoyed it... very much so. I do think that not all heroes are equal. For instance... i had Hollywood with me about 90 percent of the time... later on down the game i had to master some of the others, and some were just never as powerful or good. Hardtack is my prime example... besides his shotgun getting more range... i never felt any type of improvements with him (getting to level 19) with him. The Npcs and world could've been better... i loved the cartoony/saints row look... but not much effort went into the world (same with saints row 4) 

Besides that... i have no major complaints. Heroes are completely optional (for the most part) there are some missions where you need one that can break a shield (there's at least 4 of them that can do that) so you could play the entire game and never have to use the entire roster. The gameplay is fantastic... reminds me a lot of Saints Row 4's 

So besides a dull world... some under-powered characters... there's nothing that really bothered me too much . The frame-rate was also steady up until the last mission... there's an increase of enemies on screen... there's just a lot more going on. Besides that, the game runs smooth. 

my final score would be an 8

GAME Looks FUN ???

IGN try reviewing a game without scoring it.
Then do a pole on what we think the score is.
Then release your score a week after release and see if we guess right.

Listening to the review I would have guess 8.6-8.8

@StephenSays i think it's a very good game. That's just me though... there are no major flaws... so i don't see why someone wouldn't give it an 8.5-8.8 

i think people forgot about fun factor. the game is fun... not everything needs to be a "masterpiece"

i have no major complaints about this game. how any site could rate this game anything but GOOD is beyond me

Buy it if you haven't . Especially if you liked Saints Row 4

Overall, as someone who loves open world games as well as 3rd person shooters, I would personally give this game an 8.5 to 9.0.  I'm praying that there will be some awesome dlc down the road.

I wish they would make a sequel and include some of my favorite levels that didn't make it to this game:
- Sonic 1: Spring Yard, Scrap Brain
- Sonic 2: remake any of the scrapped levels from the popular Sonic 2 prototype (Hidden Palace would be good), Casino Night 
- Sonic 3: Ice Cap  Zone/Marble Garden/Carnival Night
- Sonic & Knuckles: Mushroom Hill/Sandopolis

I also wish they would remove the special levels that you chase a UFO - they are weird and boring. The special levels from Sonic 3/Knuckles are much more fun.
Oh to have something like this done with Symphony of the Night.

This game is a great way of revisiting the Sonic classics from the 90s - kudos to Sega, they finally figured out what made Sonic great in the 1st place and made good use of it.

Not sure what's broken with the Sky Chase or the "keep the lights on" mechanism - I didn't think they were annoying in the 90s and I still think they are fine.

Favorite level is Flying Battery - it's both a throwback to that zone and to Sonic 2's Wing Fortress... And the theme is awesome!

If you're a Sonic fan this game is highly recommended.

I wish that they would've set up the bonus options more like Sonic 3 Complete (especially regarding music themes). I've scrolled up and down the commentary seeing Nintendo fans taking time to cape for Mario and I'll say again what I said a few months ago. Sonic 3 & Knuckles is better than Super Mario All-Stars & World and Yoshi's Island and especially the NSMB series. It's amazing considering that the style was perfected in the early 1990s. The Mario games are probably more epic "adventures" than the Genesis/SCD Sonic games on average but S3&K told the best story with a simple prologue, transition scenes and a dynamic epilogue. It had had a superior action and exposition. Sonic impressed more with three elemental shields than Mario did with all of his cute situationally beneficial power-ups. Better boss fights from start to end (especially toward the end). Better and more subtle use of multiple characters (Tails-Easy, Sonic-Normal, Knuckles-Hard mode). Much more detailed level designs. Better musical themes.... and I absolutely LOVE the majority of the Super Mario games.

@TruHoopstar13 I definitely agree with you. I was always more of a Sonic fan but when Sega dropped the ball after Sonic Adventure, I became more of a Mario fan due to better quality games made by Nintendo.

Glad this article spent so much time talking about graphics and atmosphere.

I spent an obscene amount of time in the very first area just marveling at the visuals. Truly very well executed. Ninja Theory should be proud. This game stands out from the pack visually.

Now, I'm playing on the PC version, so my experience might be a little different:

Maybe it's not present on PS4, but on PC, the photo mode gives an amazing opportunity to really appreciate the graphics even further, and I'm really disappointed it's not mentioned here. Senua is not only a beautiful woman, but a truly beautiful piece of art.

The model and textures obviously have been pored over meticulously; probably to the point of agony. 

The streaks of dirt and paint on her face are perfectly organic, and if you play with the exposure and Post FX just right, you can make find some truly staggering images. 

Hell. I spent probably fifteen minutes just looking at her leather headband. They got all of the textures and topology PERFECT. The 3D artist responsible for this masterpiece is a GOD.

@JEJoll  Photo mode is there, and it does look amazing on the PS4. Not sure if it looks any better on PC, I wouldn't be surprised if it does but at the same time it looks good enough on the ps4 that I doubt I'd be able to tell the difference.

I'm not sure I would say that Senua is a "beautiful" woman by any stretch. But that's alright because I don't think she really has to be because she's interesting. 

My biggest criticism for the game is some of the live action video mixing looks very awkward. The live action characters move.. well like a person would in real time, where Senua being animated looks slow and sluggish by comparison. It didn't bring me out of the experience very often, but there were 1 or 2 scenes where the live action looks... well cringy.  If you're only a few hours in, you likely haven't seen it yet.

The combat falls off pretty hard after awhile. It always looks great in motion, but towards the end it starts to get exhausting. Especially in some of the later boss fights and scenes leading up to them.  There are just too many enemies on screen for the camera/targeting to handle. As a result, Senua will frequently switch targets mid-dodge or swing, causing you to miss or turn your back on an enemy who is swinging at you. At that point, it feels rather sluggish and exhausting.
That never happened to me during combat. I was able to manage the enemies and the camera successfully. And, hell, anytime an enemy did end up behind me, the voices would help! Lol

@saint_sinatra3  Have you beaten the game? The last boss fight in particular when you get mobbed, or even the one before that when you're fighting the shadow bosses, the camera seems ill equipped to handle both of them running through you at the same time (which they do repeatedly throughout the fight). You'll be in a good rhythm, then have to dodge, and then your camera will randomly select which of the 2 bosses to focus on (generally the closer) while the other one destroys you from behind.
@Crash486 @JEJoll Does your PS4 have a 1080ti?
@blazeaglory @Crash486 @JEJoll  No, but my PC does. And when I play MegaMan on my PC it looks the same as when I play it on my PS4. Hardware is not the only determining factor for how a game looks.

Does anyone else feel like this game is starting rather slowly?  I know the review score is the opinion of just 1 person but I hope this game lives up to its score.  However I am about an hour in and it seems pretty boring.  Does it pick up?

@deesnutz99  Depends. The puzzles become more interesting as you go on, but they are still puzzles. If you don't like puzzle solving then that part is not going to pick up. The combat gets better, but towards the end when they've introduced you to every enemy type, and it just begins to throw waves of them at you in 5 minute fights, it becomes repetitive. I will say, the game has one of the coolest boss fights of any game I've played this generation. You really need to be playing with headphones to appreciate it, but it was awesome. 

In short, if you don't like the puzzle gameplay, ask yourself why. If it's because you don't like the pacing or solving puzzles in general, then it's never going to really get better. If it's because the puzzles seem uninteresting, then it gets better as they get more interesting.

Another fine example of what its possible when unleashing the latent potential of videogames. 

Hellblade puts you inside Senua's schizophrenic, mind but it's not just another psychological horror. It actually marries the subject of psychosis perfectly with the historical context set on the Viking age, an age of pagan gods, ruthlessness and superstition. This merciless world makes Senua's often doubt her perception, not just because of her condition, but because of the inborn superstition which gripped all of humanity during the dark ages. 

But superstition alone doesn't make it any less merciless for Senua, who needs to struggle with her past and the cold, unforgiving present. The game actually makes you feel in your skin the journey she must face. The experience is so real and haunting, it actually makes you physically fatigued - not because of the gameplay, but because of real psychological stress the game constantly puts you through.

Hellblade is definitely the engrossing experience of the year, for me personally, and for many others. It fulfill the basic obligations of any game, but it goes beyond. Anyone playing can see right away in the first 5 minutes of play-though that this is no ordinary game, it's an experience. For me, this is where I draw the line when a game stops being just a game, and becomes art.

I feel like I'm playing a revamped Advance Guardian Heroes and I love it.  Thousands of games require you to find power-ups to continue like Zelda, and just as many are open world and non-linear.  But only a few give you the great combat and Epic Boss fights of Advance Guardian Heroes.  And combat aside, from the collecting crystal like souls to power up, the sky warriors and floating eyeballs, and the creepy voice talking in your head, these two games have alot in common.  The boss fights aren't as epic as some of the ones in Advance Guardian Heros, all 4 are pretty much the same fight in Sundered, but no FPS loss.

On Insane difficulty it is just a farming game though.  I'm 45% done and I cannot even contest a boss.  I'm missing the grappling hook and perks, but mostly I just farm an arena over and over...boring.  And yesterday's update made that even harder.  In fact I don't recall one thing in the update that didn't make this already difficult game even more difficult.  Oh yeah, the shrines, they are nice, and the damage cap, but I barely notice as I'm being slaughtered in temple areas.

@Ralecus Advance Guardian Heroes... I stopped here.

I loved that game although it *could* have been better.

Gotta get this game now.

... Wish it was on the Switch.

@Irenicus785 @Ralecus I hope you enjoy it.  I'm not sure which game is better, but I'm still enjoying Sundered.  And I played AGH so much, making sure I beat it on every difficulty so I could get the alternate start screen :)  I'm doing well on Insane now, just over 15 hours and I have defeated 2 bosses and grabbed every upgrade.  You must remember you're supposed to die, rinse, and repeat.  Basically I start off a run with an objective to reach a switch, or a perk before dying.  The boss fights seem overwhelming but you don't need to focus on them until endgame.  I explored all 3 areas before going back to the first area to fight it's boss.

BTW Irenicus is one of my favorite villians.  He's up there with Darth Vader for me, epic voice, epic power...he made BG2.  He was the kind of sorcerer my friends and I aspired to make but never could.

I really am loving this game, but I really do have to say what is up with the loading times!? I kind of hope they maybe stream line it with an update because come on. Aside from that definitely worthy of ones time.

@slayerfoy I'm currently programming a video game and I'm at the part where I need to code the procedural generation of grass. I coded some basic rules for the program to follow in order to have realistically spread grass and that alone added 3 minutes of load time. The load times are long because the algorithm generating content and design for the game is complex. This complexity is essential otherwise the game would have non-sensical levels and content. Hope that explains it.

@if_statement @slayerfoy you still have to bow down to consumer demands and competition.

Nobody is going to accept a 3 minute load time due to grass and sales will plummet.

@psfourthewin @if_statement @slayerfoy this is why procedural generation is not topping the charts for popularity.  No Man's Sky  deals with it by vigorous use of pop-in rendering, making for an ugly game while flying. 
I think if game designers want to use procedural generation, they should apply it in studio, hand pick the best dungeons, tweak and refine them, and then have 500 pre-generated dungeons in the can ready to load.  Bloodborne's balanced this well with its chalice dungeons, where only a few dungeons had randomization, and the randomization was not extensive.  We still paid for it in the form of the lack of variation in the art design, a stark contract to the main game.

@psfourthewin @if_statement @slayerfoy I totally agree. I just wanted to explain the reason why the load times in Sundered are high because slayerfoy asked. Btw the load times in my game are now much much faster after tweaking the algorithm. Plus I've now added procedurally generated rocks and hills. I plan to add shallow and deep water, and sand next, build worlds from there. If they were to reduce the load times in Sundered they would have to compromise on the quality of the procedurally generated content. This would also be perceived as negative by consumers and place the game behind competitively. There is a balance to be aimed for and the devs have chosen that the current load time and content quality is what they consider the best for their game. As CPUs and hard drives (although this one has been lagging badly) become more powerful the load times would be reduced. In the meantime we have no choice but to trust the devs.

@CthulhuChile666 @psfourthewin @if_statement @slayerfoy You have a point about mixing procedural generation and custom content and design. This is how most games are made today. In the case of a small studio or just one indie guy, like me with a full-time job and who programs on the side, relying more on procedural generation can be a good thing depending on how it is done. I cannot imagine all the time it would take to custom design all levels in my game. It is important to design an algorithm that will avoid repetition in content and level design as much as possible, and also affect gameplay in a positive way (thinking of environment layout and interaction with characters and enemies). When done right you get games like Spelunky, Crypt of the Necrodancer and Don't Starve. Pop ups don't have to be present in a game if all the content is loaded into memory before the player gains control of the character in a level. This is easier done in a 2d game but it mostly comes down to how the levels are fragmented in the game. For example, my game has a huge world divided in regions. Before entering a region all the content is loaded into memory. Which means no pop ups. In No Man's Sky they wanted to make a huge open world with no loading screens. That was a design decision and the trade off for loading screens was popups.

@if_statement @CthulhuChile666 @psfourthewin @slayerfoy Do you have develop diaries or anything similar for you game? A place where we can see what you're talking about? Genuinely interested in what you're game looks like.

@WonGJonG @if_statement @CthulhuChile666 @psfourthewin @slayerfoy Unfortunatly, I don't have any of those. Partly because I don't have the time (because I also have a full-time job and most days come back home with my brain about to collapse, I sleep 3 hours per night on week days to get things done) and because things posted on the internet depending on what website you post them on can be own by the company owning the website. When you sign up they have you accept contracts to create the account and some contracts mentions that they then own the content you post. So they could sue me when I release my game saying that I signed up to the contract. Also I am programming my game little by little. I never studied programming (I studied Science and later on Management, and I work in Finance :) ). Everything I know in programming I've learned on my own because I love it. I have been programming since I was 12. I am now 32. Right now the game is functional but the graphics are crap because I am not focusing on graphics but the functionality of mechanics in the game. It's a 2d procedurally generated open world rpg. I want the game to be more about exploration and story rather than fight, fight. I want combat to be smart, strategic, meaningful and rare (although I'm planning to allow players to choose how rare). Anyway, menus are done (pc centric with mouse + keyboard but I will also program menus for controller). Combat system is bare bones but at least I started programming it :). I am now programming the procedural level generation. After that I will be programming procedural quests. They will not be generic and repetitive. I have come up with a procedural quest design concept that I have never seen in any game I know of so far. I think I will license this before releasing the game. After that I will be polishing all the features I have programmed and adding new ones over time, even after the game is released.

There are a number of great features of the game - not least of all the music and visual style - but the game-play is seriously flawed in a number of respects. First, the lack of companion AI and the fact that you can only control one character at a time makes the emphasis on teamwork mostly a sham. As a number of others have noted, the most surefire tactic is simply to choose a fast character and run it into the other team's pyre. Second, the game's difficulty spikes enormously about half way through the game. One of the ways it does so is through extremely inorganic or arbitrary mechanisms, such as making it so that the other team starts with more hp/pyre points. Finally, the game lags on the ps4 in the later stages - there are serious moments of delay that can cause you to lose the ball/orb. I would say the game is mediocre or perhaps good, because as compelling as the narrative is, the matches are at best serviceable.  While I appreciate SuperGiant's commitment to maintaining a small team, they should really consider investing in additional or better AI programmers. This game, in short, suffers from style over substance.

I'm inclined say that the gripes this review has are relatively unfounded, but for only one particular reason. This is only an HD North American localization of a version of FF12 that was released in 2007 (Final Fantasy XII International Zodiac Job System) with hardly any additions (if any at all).
 Saying game mechanics that would've been nice to have added are Cons seems to me that your expectations were that it would be a new and different version than the 2007 re-release that NA never got. It's simply unfair to see these things as a downfall when they were never intended, promised and should not have ever been expected. 

Perhaps a lack of knowing/research caused the reviewer to not realise this, I won't make that sort of assumption. But it's kinda like expecting a little known Jackie Chan movie only released in China to have a better story now that it's getting an North American release for the first time in HD in about 10 years.

It's poor management of expectations I feel like we all see in too many reviews across too many products, not just video games.

Otherwise, I would like to say, good review! I'm glad there are still a number of people that can appreciate this game for what it was and still is!

"Definitive" console experience on the go.

From what I've seen of this it looks like a quickly slapped together game that takes advantage of the fact that Trekkies want a VR Star Trek experience. 
If it was a €10-€15 game it wouldn't be so bad, but it looks like the price tag is there because it's Star Trek. If, as suggested here, you're stuck on the bridge it's a ripoff alright, shameful. 
For €50 there should be multiple ships, shuttles, space walks and you should be able to explore the whole ship. Seems like something you'd only play once or twice.. a demo game basically.
Of course I haven't played it so it might be great, but even if it is, it could be so much better.

If you're thinking about buying this game and concerned about some of the negative reviews, go read the user reviews on Steam. As someone who's been enjoying the game a great deal since launch, I can say they better reflect my experience with the game than any of the mainstream gaming reviews, many which don't give you any idea just how powerful the immersion of VR can be for an experience like this.

I think they are far too focused on gameplay mechanics on this one.  The appeal of this game is based soley on the interactions with other people.  This game is insanely fun.  I think if they made it much more complicated it would be difficult for a lot of people to get into.  Considering you are having to work with 4 people it isn't overly easy.  Expansions or DLC can add a lot of variety once everyone has gotten used to the game.  Hopefully one day you can beam your away team down to a planet.  Captain is the brawler, Tactical has the phaser, Engineering has the tricorder.

@Impyrium @generalnotsew1976

Bet you feel silly now we have voice commands, an example of post release development.
@Kyelleh @Impyrium @generalnotsew1976 Actually I am thrilled.  I was pissed and thought the game was broken when the AI would not respond to my commands.  I only hope it works well.
Well I'm over 20 hours in and it hasn't "died" for me. If you check out the steam reviews you'll find many more who are 20+ hours in and still having a blast.

I'm not a huge Trek fan. I've watched some of the shows namely OST, TNG, and Voyager as well as the movies but by no means am I a die hard fan. That being said, I've had so much fun playing this game. I honestly cannot remember the last time I've enjoyed a game this much.

AND... I do not disagree with a majority that the reviewer said. Yes, after awhile you've seen it all in this game. The ongoing voyages randomize but it is definitely familiar if you've put time into the game. I love his idea of having mini games at the various stations... I really hope they implement something like this. I'd love to see more alien races. I'd like the captain to be able to add more to engagements such as coordinating NPC help. These are all things they could implement or add and I'm curious to see what they do.

What is missed in this review is the interaction when you are playing with others in multiplayer. Yes, the content can be similar, but when you have vastly different people filling the various roles on the ship, your experience is different every time. Sometimes blandly so, but more often than not, extremely entertaining. Like a lot of VR multiplayer titles, when you visually see someone sitting across from you and are interacting with them like they are in the same room, it adds...something hard to define unless you've played VR and experienced it. Maybe that feeling is  unique to myself (though I doubt it). There is nothing like surviving a harrowing encounter in this game... afterwards you really do feel like you accomplished something as part of a crew. It's great. Solid 8 for me with this game.

@Saediss  Yeah they definitely dropped the ball on talking about what makes this game so great.  I feel like this reviewer was just going through the motions.  I wonder if they spent hardly anytime in multiplayer.

This game is awesome. Did a write up here with videos

https://redd.it/6g2gcn

6.8? Really IGN? I own this, and this one of the most definitive VR experiences I have played so far. It is extremely immersive and engaging, and there is plenty to do. This score is borderline misleading, and some of your comments lead me to question the thoroughness of your time with the game.

This game is fun and I do hope that more DLC are coming. This is out of  topic but it is such a bummer that a game like Ace Combat isn't fully VR compatible like RE7. It would have been the perfect game for VR.

Overall what ever platform you play on it is a well built game, all though I see few short falls.  Missed on missions that involve teleport, we did get to teleport off but not on why can't we beam security over to attempt to subdue or sabotage. Now with in that Why not have a 1st person VR Shooter member on standby to do security missions.  Of course the Crew Vs Crew missions would be so wonderful, of course.  A science station would have been nice so we could counter intrusions and maybe boost our own intrusion attacks, not to mention another station that was integral for the Star Trek universe.

I've been playing this game since release and sure I already know how many mission types there are. I agree that this game needs to expand its content to keep the community coming for more. 
But I've been playing Star Trek Bridge Crew for far more hours then many other VR games I own. So value wise this game has provided more gameplay time and fun than most VR games I've played.

Keep in mind the premise of this game. 
This is true to the Star Trek bridge experience. Gameplay and immersion wise they delivered on the promise and that alone is worth buying the game.
IF you love Star Trek, if you want to feel like a member of a starship crew, this game is for you. 
There are many things they can do going forward, but you get right now will give you at least 10-20+ hours of gameplay. That is a lot more than so many games we play.
To give you some evidence regarding the value of the game.
I'm reading Steam reviews and check this out:
Here is a player that is giving a not recommended review of Bridge Crew yet he has clocked 33 hours of game time .Come on? I don't invest 30 hours on games I don't enjoy : 
http://steamcommunity.com/id/electriceasel/recommended/527100/

As a fan of Tekken since the first game came out, I really don''t know what to think of this one.
Sure it's a lot nicer looking and while the Rage Arts/Drive add a twist to the general fighting, it doesn't feel much different at all to Tekken 6. What is noticeable is the missing features, from big problems like no more Team battles to little things like not being able to bump up max health to 150% (Is it just me or do fights feel a lot shorter now ?).
Not gonna cry any more over the lack of Lei, Mokujin and Armour King  (but why Roger??!!!). Still the new additions aren't anything special - Kazumi and Akuma are nice but the rest? So so.
Me and the bros normally just do VS battles so the lack of single player stuff hasn't been to much of a downer, but the campaign in this is awful. NetherRealm are way ahead of the pack when it comes to story in fighters.

Overall 8/10. Great Mechanics as always but the overall package feels a little thin.

I just finished Rime this evening. I totally disagree with the score here. This is the only game I've ever played in many years of video gaming that ever made me cry, so I will remember it for a long time. The graphics and music are spectacular. I found the worlds and puzzles to be clever and original. It wasn't terribly difficult, but that's okay because it kept me wanting to explore. My only gripe was that the character control could have been tighter as I fell off many ledges. I would give it an 8.7 out of 10. If you are looking for something different, unique, and beautiful, give it a try.
Same here. Not ashamed to admit I almost cried. The music was beautiful too.

I just got this game, it is great, OK it has some laws. But it is a complete experience of a real FPS. I have a question about the quality of the video. The video looks just like playing any other game outside of PS VR. Is this what the player is actually seeing with the headset on? I ask because my PS VR is incredibly grainy. In some games I can barely make out what's in the distance. I certainly do not see my games as the video above. Am I supposed to see lower quality visuals through the headset? I contacted PlayStation support and asked them about this - no help at all. So frustrating. I have calibrated the hell out of this thing as well. It still looks grainy/screen door effect.

@Cybertronian the PSVR is 1080P for both eyes. Now imagine you have a way to zoom in against your 1080p screen further, you would see the pixels sometimes because you re too close to the screen and flaws of the 1080p is shown at this time. Now when i played this game, it was totally fine because the devs used rendering to not cause any feeling of blurriness. RE7 did use the rendering as well but not to the extent of Far Point since it was in a house and in a less open area than far point. So what you might see on TV seems to be great quality but up close with a magnifying glass you would notice the blurriness and that s up to the devs to make it more or less blurry  depending on the framerate is been proccessed. You re not suppose to have this normally but devs are brand new to this tech so expect to not see any perfect games until the next gen of VR.  This game for me got it right but could have more improvement but so far it has been the best game on psvr
I'm up to the point you meet the girl. I wonder if he's going to hit that. Would be weird if so.

As a psvr owner I have to say this is the game that you want to sit your family and friends down with to get the experience the psvr Aim is the best light gun I have ever used. the story is predictable but who cares about story when the gameplay is this good the only thing I haven't tried yet is the 2 player.

Ok, I bought the game yesterday, immediately after seeing WW. I jumped straight into the "To End All Wars" Multiverse event in order to obtain her film gear. As far as I know the event ends tomorrow, so I leveled her up all the way to level 20 while playing versus with my gf (fastest way to level up) before jumping into Multiverse.

However, even on max level, I stuck at one fight in one of the events (Supergirl fight). Since I am very short on time today, I decided to put WW in AI mode in order to complete the event.

My question is: Do I still get all the film gear by completing the whole thing in AI mode? I noticed that she wins every time against any opponent that way. Isn't this a bit of a... cheating, however? What is the catch?

I really want to obtain all the film gear, but I fear I might have messed something up by putting her into AI mode and basically go... the easy way. At the same time I am running short on time and can't attempt certain fights numerous times, hence why going AI mode.

@venom0706 No you still get all of the gear from completion bonuses. By using the AI it lessens your chance of getting the extra motherboxes from each event, but it's not too much of a loss. I use the AI for fights that I am not good enough to do, and I think that is what it is there for, so players who aren't as good or don't have the time can still enjoy most of the same benefits

you get limited upgrade slots, you can use depending on your play style, .. like go full health or stamina (or core consumption for combos/ finisher, thar needs to be charged),.. or a balance of those., or go health regeneration.. or full damage out put, that uses the "charger" , either in "raw power" or in "faster/earlier finisher" moves (in which case you might want invest in core consumption.., which you can handle upgrade in different ways too) etc. etc..

this game is all about the atmosphere,  and as such it's brilliant.full of jump scares and a constantly engaging story that keeps revealing interesting characters at a constant clip.  but as a shooter or an rog or even an adventure game it lacks the pace and the upgrade system that would make it special.  8.0 is a pretty accurate score considering that it's a lot of fun fun despite is many shortcomings,  not least of which are the horrendously long and immersion breaking load times between areas.  This becomes particularly annoying towards the end when you have to rapidly move between areas and you end up spending 10 seconds moving your character from one for to the next only to wait a good 2 minutes or so for the next area to load. The gunplay is more annoying than fun and the upgrade system starts of as interesting but becomes less so with every additional level un locked. Still, is a memorable experience and definitely worth going through.

After only discovering this game a week ago I read the reviews and was disappointed that a potentially great sniper game failed due mostly to technical issues at launch. I like Sniper Elite so I searched to see if a patch was put out. I discovered that a massive 10 gig patch had been put out to fix most if not all of the things people were complaining about. I took a chance and got it. Now I cannot put it down. It's awesome. Graphics are great, no bugs encountered after 5 hours of playing. The sniping mechanics are far superior to Sniper Elite.And the slo-mo bullet cam kills are incredibly realistic (not that cartoon-ish X-ray stuff of Sniper Elite). No, here you have to use skill with several different styles of rifles and scopes to place the perfect shot with slo-mo reward, and when you do, it's indescribably satisfying to see the blood splash out of ears, eyes, ass or wherever. No X-ray crap. It looks and sounds real. with blood splatter staining the walls/floor as well.Missions are terrific and varied.I'm immersed in the story line, The only mechanic I don't love is the driving, which is pretty basic, but aside from that I feel this game should get a new review based on the bugs being fixed---and I'd give it a solid 9.
@Shoegazer1 100%!!!! NEEDS new review!! This game has been fixed and is incredible... I promise you this is absolutely a 9!! Thanks

1. I hate short games.
2. I hate no replay value.
3. I don't care for the majority of "indie" games.
4. I LOVE this "game."

This is one of the most phenomenal pieces of art I have enjoyed in a long, long time. The discovery in this game is top notch, along with the stories surrounding each character.

I purchased this game for $20 on Steam and it literally took me only 2 hours to complete. Normally, I would be frothing at the mouth and enraged for the previous sentence I just typed. For whatever reason, I was fine with the length and I think it primarily revolves around the deep emotions you quickly attach to many of the family members.

The two that hit me the deepest revolved around a bath tub and a fall out shelter. While I won't go into any more detail than that, each one of those events contained multiple feelings: joy, happiness, sadness, humor, dreaded fear. I could go on and on. This "game" could have easily been a book or even a movie, but making it a video game was the correct choice.

So, I've never played the original, and I picked this up over the weekend and played a few hours here and there.

Although the graphics are really nice and the leash is a novel idea, I can't really say that this is a great game.  I know shooters are "linear" in general, but this plays like a rail shooter.  I feel there's very little room to explore; I don't need Fallout or Elder Scrolls sized spaces to wander, but a few minutes to look around would be nice.

So I'm happy to see that the Unreal engine looks very nice on my machine; I'll have to look up more games that use it.  I wouldn't mind another Unreal Tournament, but I suppose that's a pipe dream.

@ThePurpleMarauder I hate saying this to people (but some games you do have to explain it) but, you're playing it wrong.

This game's main mechanic is about skill kills, once you get that idea into your head and pursue it, the game opens up.  It's not a game about exploration (there are some cool set pieces though), play it like an old school arcade game that's all about racking up a huge score.

@ThePurpleMarauder  bulletstorm dosent need wide open spaces to explore, this game is about pure action which is the way all shooters should be. think of all the potential this game has for a sequel...

Enjoying this game as it does feed the nostalgia fix i look for in platformers.

The music is great (as to be expected, they got the guy from DK country and the guy from Banjo Kazooie for the music...enough said) That blizzard world music is amaze balls.

I'm impressed with all of the worlds (even the casino one Marty didn't care for much) my favorite is probably Moodymaze Marsh. the borderline adult humor and innuendo and the characters are charming for the most part.

One issue with it is the camera (like pretty much everyone else says), not the worst camera in the world but definitely needs a tweak. 

My biggest concern however are the bugs that force me to restart the game and lose some progress. I don't know if anyone else is having this issue, or if it's only happening on the digital copy vs. the physical disc but it's a buzzkill. it got so bad on the blizzard level that it would not allow me to enter a section of the Crystalline Cave and i had to restart and lose progress. 

Another issue in the same world was the objective with the snowmen wouldn't allow me to complete due to the dialog box not opening and locking me into the conversation without being able to back up. They have a patch coming soon and i honestly haven't wanted a patch so bad in my life.

I'll preface this by saying I'm someone who frequently replays BK/BT, so my review may be a bit biased. I had no issue with the camera, it's certainly far smoother than BK/BT. I also had no issue with the quizzes taking too long like I've read in many negative reviews - each took me less than a minute to complete, especially considering a rapid answer moves you two spaces ahead. If anything, I hoped the quizzes would be longer, however not a whole lot of character building happens ( one great feature about the original buddy duo games was getting to know the character you were helping out in each world). I was iffy about the first level, but as soon as I got to the second I was hooked, especially with the lush musical score ( familiar but refreshing). For me, YL hit a sweet spot of comfortable but new, despite being a bit slow to start for such a short game. The cheeky humor and classic 'wha-wha-wha' voice acting was very much appreciated too.

I bought this game on a whim and am really enjoying it. I found it incredibly frustrating at first, trying to learn the controls was a pain! However it's paid off taking the time to learn it because now I'm loving the heck out of it. I had small issues with the camera but no worse then a lot of other games I've played. Honestly I thought the checkpoint system was just fine, anything else would have just made it much easier. The checkpoint system works fine. It's what gives the game a challenge. If you finally get that difficult coin go and find a checkpoint, there is usually one close by. Let's say the game didn't use checkpoints and it auto saved after every collectable. That would make the game too easy. You could simply do a leap of faith to get the coins. Then it would get a negative review for not using checkpoints. Sometimes no matter what a game does people will complain. The game is frustrating as hell. But that made me want to master the controls and eventually I got pretty good at it. Now I am on level 8 with all collectables collected. There is no way this reviewer beat all 15 levels in 5 hours. If he did he obviously only collected the required 3 gems. If that's the case he has no right reviewing this game. The camera does suck and has caused me many deaths. That is my only issue with the game. But overall it's a good unique game. It's not for everyone but if you're interested I'd recommend it. It is a very frustrating game especially the beginning when you are learning but if you stick with it you will get much better. Also don't expect a story. There isn't one. You just go to 15 world's collecting gems, blue orbs and coins. I'd give the game a 7.5/10.

this game has many elements that I love. I love the gameplay, but what i dont really like is once you die, like the review said, you are back to square one. I'd like it if there was some sort of progression or something. To give an example, let's say I want to fight that Captain Hook like boss after failing once, chances are i will rarely see him again. it makes me curious for the many other bosses this game offers, but constantly going back to zero kinda kills it. all the effort i did to beat a certain boss is lost.

All I can say is either the reviewer didn't really play a dozen hours or he somehow didn't understand the basic fundamentals of the game. More than likely his claim of playing a dozen hours is untrue. While the game is unforgiving and doesn't explain much, it's almost impossible to NOT learn through trial and error.
At 90 minutes in, I felt a little frustrated. I'd gotten to the second boss (which, by the way, is the final boss) three times but just couldn't quite clinch it. I had read this review and felt maybe he was right, however something clicked over the next 30 minutes and I just understood the combat a lot better. I realized what a powerhouse the rogue is with +10 melee damage items, how invaluable the monk was with new spells and faster spell recharge and how potent the warrior was with +percent damage and defense. Judicious use of the easily obtainable non elemental spells early on and smart lane swapping saw me getting to the second boss in a matter of under ten minutes each run and before the end of 3 hours I had beaten the game and unlocked my first bonus hero.
At this point, the game really begins. Beating the game unlocks 75+ new objects for the game. New items, new spells, new enemies, new biomes, new rooms/areas, new bosses and one new hero (the Bard, a replacement for the monk who's more healing focused). Every time you beat the game you unlock a similar amount of objects for the game as well as a new hero and you add one new area to the game length. So.. to beat the game the first time you need only clear two areas and two bosses. To beat it a second time, you must clear three areas and three bosses. To beat it a third, you must clear four areas and four bosses. This pattern continues, with the final boss always being a new elemental variation of the same final boss you fought early on (albeit with some new tricks and minions each time).
Reviewer is lazy :(.

Small correction of the review: On console you can’t see an item’s description the first time you find it. Once you’ve picked it up once, it’s stats will be displayed when you find the item in a future game.

I read this review, but bought the game anyhow. ...and when I was at a place in this game where our reviewer was, (able to sometimes beat the first boss but not the second) I was dead set to agree with this review. This game seemed overly hard and the mechanics weren't well explained.
But then it clicked. It’s not just about using the warrior to cause big damage, as described in the review, which only works well on enemies with 3 or fewer stamina. The trick to battling is to permanently remove enemy stamina by stunning them (dropping their stamina to zero without dealing any damage), and then hitting them with any hero to reduce their stamina by 1, permanently. …And an enemy with no stamina is a sitting duck, even if it’s a boss.

By using spells and abilities in addition to basic attacks, you can find many creative ways to rapidly strip enemies of their stamina.

Apparently the reviewer didn't put any effort or time into this game....

Been sinking quite a bit of time into this game since launch... and this reviewer is a sad excuse for a gamer.   This game is at least an 8.0, with a lot of gameplay depth...  it requires thought and to be successful, planning.   With tons of unlockable heroes that have their own stats, it gives plenty of ways to build your group of heroes...  each hero has different spell slots that buff certain types of spells if you put them in that slot and tons of items that alter your heroes melee dmg, spells, stamina and health.... not to mention that spells can be used in succession in order to have additional effects.

You need to manage the amount of hits your hero does with the amount of stamina the enemy has to manage stuns, which result in being able to do more dmg.....   I could go on and on.... but you probably don't want to read another long review.

TLDR version... the game looks simple, but has a lot of depth...  its the thinking man's version of Plants vs Zombies. I love Plants vs Zombies... but Has Been Heroes is simply, better.

I've been using the x5 ghost throughout and have to say I'm surprised no one is appreciating it for the beast that it is. With my mods and stat boosts it does 80 damage, has a 128 bullet clip and fires of those rounds at a 600 fire rate. With the auto reload with 5% health mode and an incendiary ammo add on, this basically means that I can chew through anything at medium range within seconds. It's not for long range but that's what I have the black widow for. It's incredibly satisfying to just hover and unload my x5 on pretty much anything with the 35% damage boost and watch as even a behemoth gets helplessly chewed up. I barely use any of the powers either as this one gun carries 90% of the work in every battle!

@BeknIghted
Feels like the accuracy isn't what the stats say...or its just me

The 7.7 seems a bit low and I suspect it's been calculated based on the difference between the reviewer's expectations from the game and what the game has been able to deliver. 
Clearly, the sense of wonder that the first Me inspired can not be replicated by a game in the same franchise, that's a trick that only works once. But on its own, ME:A is a lot of fun and my score for it would hover around a 9. The combat is frenetic and a hug d improvement over previous games thanks to the added mobility and the story beats are also consistently interesting. For e very decision that seems inconsequential, the possibility of it making a difference in dlc and sequels is ever present. The only major weakness is in the form of companions. They are fairly generic and the bonds between them and th ed protagonist are not crafted as vividly and organically as in past games. Plus the limited control over how they level up makes them all interchangeable without any one standing out like Garrus did. 
It's still a very enjoyable ride that satisfies while creating excitement and curiosity for the sequels and has a couple of good plot lines that flow well together and provide surprises and thrills a plenty.
There are a lot of improvements required, such as making both the shopping and crafting system more meaningful and providing either a narrower focus for abilities or greater access to utilizing the available choices, but I'm hopeful these will fit ironed out with future games.

So, help me out here. I have a Switch, saw the 9.0, and I was on the fence so I bought the vanilla for $5 on steam. I played it for an hour and-- to a lot of you who "love" it-- what's the appeal?
Impressions:
Really grim, lots of death, blood and poop lol. 
Some creative creatures, I'll say that. The art and color is a bit bland, even tho I know it doesn't want to be Mario-sparkly.
Lots and lots of wet sound effects of little tear-bubbles splatting. Didn't love the "feel" of it. Not as satisfying as Enter the Gungeon or others.
Had a hard time figuring out collision of bullets
Amazing music. (best part IMO)
Story is meh, but has a very distinct atmosphere (I researched the story a lot on Edmund McMillen's blog)

Overall, I think the feel of the controls were the biggest turn off, and I didn't really love the atmosphere. Maybe I just don't get what's so great about it. I guess I don't like wallowing in sadness covered with blood, poop and flies.¯\_(ツ)_/¯

@suprkong  The controls absolutely take some getting used to, especially the feel of shooting. It's fairly heavily momentum-based, and is rather odd at first, but once you figure it out it comes rather naturally. 

The dark feel is part of the appeal, really; kind of like FNaF, the game is supposed to be rather grim, with a story that already feels bleak at the top level, and only gets more and more miserable the deeper you go. Personally, I love stuff like this, but I can certainly understand why one might not enjoy it.
@suprkong I really enjoy just shooting things and seeing how every time you play the environment changes. In a weird way, it feeds the Contra games shooting fan in me.

I was a huge fan of the original game, but I never beat it. I could rarely get past the 3rd boss (Photophage), so I didn't ever beat the game. IGN did a review of the Wii Virtual Console version back in 2009 (http://www.ign.com/articles/2009/12/15/blaster-master-review?page=2), and mentioned one of the most irritating things about the original: it was so hard, very few people beat it. The Wii Virtual Console introduced a save state feature that made it more likely. This version just turns the whole thing into a faceroll.

However, it's obvious for any fan that this game is an homage to the original in just about every way. If you spent days of your life working your way through the original, the combat in this feels like payback. The save feature feels like reprieve, and so many of the frustrating control issues have been resolved. They even cleaned up the story so it's at least quasi-plausible!

I don't see this reboot as a serious remake of one of the best games for the original NES. I see it as a tribute, made by fans, for fans. It's so refreshing to cruise through the game, following a built-in walkthrough, while enjoying the cleverness of the hybrid platform design. It's a thing of beauty!

I was a bit worried.  I almost thought this was the sequel.
It technically is, but this isn't the crowdfunded game. This bridges the gap between Psychonauts 1 and 2 while setting up the villain for Psychonauts 2.

I wasn't a big fan of this game.  It was ok, but I think my nostalgic memories of the original made my expectations a little too high.
It was cute and witty, but the teleport-based movement is getting annoying (many VR owners are getting tired of the teleport style), the puzzles were rather simplistic, and so much time was spent just following along a linear path (of fish) to get to different areas.
I understand it is just a bridge between Psychonauts 1 and 2, and glad its cheap, but it won't be a VR titles that I have strong memories of.

Well, until they can find a way to lessen the motion sickness when you move without teleporting, teleporting is the cheapest method we have... unless you want to spend $800 additionally on a 360 degree "treadmill" to track your movements in real life.

More games need to have a choice between teleporting and smooth movement in their settings. I think the motion sickness from VR movement mainly hits those that don't have their VR legs yet, but once your brain is used to playing VR, there's no need to use the teleport. At least that's my case. Got plenty sick first couple weeks of owning a PSVR, but now I feel absolutely fine playing games with the comfort settings minimized.
Games like Resident Evil 7 have proved to me that the teleport movement system is simply not necessary. Blink turning, and full locomotion all the way!

@pocketcommie  And that will be the case for many people. However, many people won't have that be the case. There are people who have spent decades riding and driving in cars and STILL get motion sickness from a car ride. I myself am not super susceptible to VR motion sickness, but I have a friend who plays more VR than I do and still gets sick every single time. Heck, I read an article about a VR developer who literally has to take medicine to help him develop his VR games because his body naturally won't get used to it... a VR developer for crying out loud, someone who uses VR LITERALLY everyday for his job... Everyone is hit differently, just like people who get sick on airplanes or have sea sickness.

@THANA108  Simply not necessary... for you. Some people who were used to VR still got sick with Resident Evil 7. There isn't a one size fits all; just because you didn't get sick, that doesn't mean others don't. I say this from experience, as I am like you, I don't really get sick with VR. But I have a friend who has a Vive, Rift, and PS VR and plays it 10 times more than I play my PS VR and he gets sick each and every time he plays. Everybody's body is different and reacts differently to VR.

Resident Evil 7 also was very slow in its movements, so it was vastly easier to cope with for many people. And that will work... for slow games like Resident Evil 7. But playing a game like Quake 3 in VR? That's a different story.

@WTGHookie @FortescueHaljournon My comment was based on actual people from two global and one Australia PSVR Facebook groups where a reasonable majority of people do not experience any notable VR sickness, and the vast majority of those that DO experience sickness get over it after a short while.  There are indeed a few who don't seem to get over it and sell it, but I can't help but wonder how many of these may do so prematurely.
There's definitely merit to the notion of taking pills, or ginger, or even having a fan blowing on you to help you get past the sickness... but these are just a means to an end.
The point is... VR sickness is not as bigger issue as some would have us believe, and I certainly don't think that they should restrict movement options based solely on the few who can't get over it... again, at the very least, it should be an option for each game.
Your other point about the cause of VR sickness certainly sounds logical... but the problem I have with that theory (I have debated this with many others!) is that it doesn't explain how I can be sick in one full-movement game but fine in another.  e.g. I can spend hours in RE7 with smooth turning enabled... but I still get a little queasy no longer than an hour into Robinson.  Both have similarly detailed graphics, both have the same controls and smooth turning options, both have visual anchors (guns in RE7, the scanner in Robinson)... but in spite of these similarities, one causes mild sickness in me.  Then there is the fact that some people get sick with Robinson but are fine with RE7, but then there are others that are vice versa, getting sick from RE7 but are fine with Robinson.

IMO you are basing your opinion on theory. You say moving faster would make motion sickness worse for 360 movement. But that's not my experience, in The Windlands you are sprinting and swinging around like Spiderman, and I don't get sick from that either. But if I turn on smooth turning it's instant sickness.

I see a few people bitching about repetition... frankly that's just about every game in the world Kill,attack,go to,save, protect so on so forth for me it's expected with every game. What I'm amazed at is the person who did the review for this game didn't bother to go in depth of the story its self and is not the same person who did the review for GRFS and gave this game a 7.9? More so this title deseves a 9.0 or 9.2. From the score of Ghost Recon Future Soldier of a 8.5 to me this review is bias and possibly overlooked. For what this game GRWL is intend for it's well praised for now. I personally think this the game could use some improvements overall. I've played this game solo beat it in less than 4 days lvl 30 with SP and got my Platnum Trophy. For me it's a solid 9.0 maybe a 8.8. I could care less about the Co-op option for me it's not needed to score this title. This game does play tacticly when your not playing on any difficulty other than extreme with low gamma,Brightness,and contrast with Zero visuals and no hud which yes makes the game hard as Fuck! It's a Great way to play only on a local connection not connection to some dude states away or a country even. But if you are a casual gamer then your option is just that... but if you take gaming to another level, no not MLG level because they half-ass saw a COD stream wasn't impressed. The point is if your are not nit picky about everything...Well you don't play games to score them... And ideally everyone has different things they like in a game. This title however, IMO hit all the spots where it counts and what I look for is a successful title and to keep me playing and enjoying it that's props. Note: Keeping in mind this game just released and there has been a few updates already and no additional content aside from Ubisoft club content. No DLCs or expansions as of yet from the SP but Ubisoft club has The "Conspiracy DLC" has been there for a bit. So this score and review is fairly irrelevant for the time being. That said, Game on!

i like this guy too but i must say he botched this review. nintendo switch is an amazing and unprecedented console. aside from top tier graphics that ps4 and other consoles may have an edge with, games like nba 2k are going to be full featured on switch, and the endless exclusive titles offered by nintendo, plus the overall customization that the hardware offers make this console perfect for more reasons than any other console can list. i can play a game on my big screen tv at home, then take it on the go seamlessly in hand-held mode, and then end up at a friends house, split the device up to have two separate ( and perfectly working from my experience) controllers and play mario kart with a friend, no other console can even relate, and that alone is worth $300.

This console is a joke. Selling a half finished product a year before its online services are operational is like selling a cellphone without cell towers. This 300 dollar pile of Zelda will be outdated on stone age tech before it even becomes operational.

Seductive, but full of planned obsolescence and unnecessary costs
So, I made a video on why and how I think the Nintendo Switch should be redesigned. 

DISCLAIMER: I have not purchased the Nintendo Switch. But I have seen many (dumb) issues with its design, which is why I flatly won’t buy it. For instance:
Planned Obsolescence
One of the most iconic consumer complaints about this product is that its kickstand is flimsy and poorly angled. Another issue is that the touchscreen is made of plastic, which gets scratched easily by the dock. Speaking of which, it’s hollow and therefore is likely to break if you drop it. Nyko has made an alternative hyper-portable docking kit, which you can check out here:
https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2017/06/nintendo-switchs-dumb-dock-gets-beaten-by-hyper-portable-nyko-option/
Unnecessary Costs
First, the dock. It covers the entire console when you slide it in. There's no reason for it to be this unnecessarily huge. Which, again, the Nyko dock illustrates. It’s RIDICULOUS. All of it. Second, the touchscreen. 1) It doesn't need to be as big as it is. 2) Nowadays, Nintendo consoles usually have touchscreen, cameras, accelerometers, gyro controls. But might you be holding something in your hand or have something in your pocket that has all these features + more? I'm pretty sure you get where I'm going with this. But just in case you don't, it's your mobile phone or PDA.

"Local online multiplayer is also available, but each player needs to own a copy of the game." That's the biggest horse shit I've ever heard.

You can still do up to 4 players on the same system. If you want to link multiple systems up (for up to 8 players), each needs a copy.
It's not that surprising.
@MinimumWageNinja  "LOCAL ONLINE multiplayer." Go back to kindergarten. Learn how to read. Of course LOCAL ONLINE (multi-console) multiplayer needs multiple cartridges.

@sixty4bit @MinimumWageNinja  Actually, it's probably a bit inbetween.  I suspect the reviewer meant "Local Wi-Fi multiplayer".  Many games allow you to put 2+ Switches near each other and play over Wi-Fi without an online connection.  Going a step further, some games will let you do this with only one copy of the game.  In this case, the other Switches without the game will copy the necessary files from Switch with the game.  Typically this is reduced multiplayer functionality, but still neat.  

I suspect in this case the reviewer is saying that you can play locally (peer 2 peer) over Wi-Fi, but each Switch needs a full copy of the game.

@sixty4bit @MinimumWageNinja Oh I'm sorry, I couldn't read the statement of "multi-console" you magically added to the statement. Local online multiplayer, like Mario Kart, is where you have split-screen online play with one purchase of the game. Multi-console I can understand, but wasn't specified.

Hey folks, Brandin here. I wrote this review. Here are a few tips for anyone picking up For Honor this weekend that helped me out in the long run.

1. Do the Basic and Advanced Practice tutorials first. They're helpful to get basic mechanics down and they'll net you 3k Steel right off the bat.
2. If you plan on playing a lot in a short amount of time, invest that Steel into a Champion Status buff (it gives you extra XP and Steel for every match, and stacks with other players in the same match.) It pays for itself.
3. Watch the Basic and Advanced Tutorial videos for any heroes you're interested in. Then, pick one you like, and practice that hero. Get good with one before you start bouncing around between heroes. The better you are, the more you win, the more Steel you get to unlock new heroes.
4. Have fun. And thanks for stopping by!

I want to love this game, I really do, but this thing is a absolute wreck. Lets start with just trying to get into the damn game, you will most likely load ..load.. then get booted back to home screen. when finally get in a game, youll probably loose connection and get booted to home screen, it will also boot you to your Xbox one home screen and youll have to completely reload the game, if youre not deterred yet and play something else, you will finally get to play an see some action. The combat system is great but flawed. PvP you end up getting teamed up on alot an its next to impossible to do anything. second ppl have figured out how to spam unblockable attacks, repetive moves makes for not much fun. Also, the executions, these are the highlight reel of the game, worst thing about them is, you can be fucking killed while performing one and you cant abort mid way through. now i find this totally bullshit, either make so while doing a execution you cant be hurt which would be preferred or make it so we can atleast fucking abort and defend ourself for fuck sake. Instead youll be all amped cuz your guy is gonna cut his guys head off then whoop some one hits you just before and you end up with no head. trash. and some of the executions can be lengthy, so even if you went one on one some one might arrive just in time to stop you dead. this shit will make you wanna toss the game in the trash or delete it from the hard drive. now for the currency, and leveling system. idk how many years they expected ppl to play this, but you have to go 20 levels to get 1 larger level of which there are 30....what?that means to lvl 1 character out you have to lvl up 600 times!, and it is a slooooow going grind. this is for each character. omfg. I have yet to even see someone lvl 10. and the higher the lvl the better the gear, but good luck keeping interest in one character for 600 lvls with all of your 6 hack an slash moves and 5 different executions, cmon, then all the aesthetics are in the thousands for currency, yet every match you do pays like 50 silver and the orders (challenges) pay a few hundred. wtf where these developers smoking. what a dissapointment.

From the comments, it appears SE4 has reeled in a lot of first timers to the series. Welcome all!

I've been on board since the original SE a decade+ ago. I have always been impressed with Rebellion's work on these games, as I am a gamer who much prefers stealth and strategy. I remember emailing Rebellion 10 years ago asking when a SE2 would be coming. There response: We currently have no plans to make anymore Sniper Elite games." I'm so happy we are now at the 4th one.

To all you newbies out there, I would encourage you to check out the previous games (SE1 graphics ARE dated). All the games are great.

Also, to any PC gaming junkies out there: This game is optimized wonderfully! It's such a great thing to see when so many so-called "AAA Developers" can't get PC optimization done correctly.

EDIT: I know the video review says it took him 14 hours. My first playthrough on Normal took my just under 26 hours. If you play this game correctly (as it was designed to be played), you will get much more out of it.

I've been playing Sniper Elite 4 for a couple weeks now damn near daily and even if I'm not going after Achievements, I don't care, I just LOVE this game!!! When's the next piece of content releasing dammit I WANT MORE!
@juggalochef2399 what would you rate it 1-10  ?

@gotobestbuy @juggalochef2399 Honestly a solid 8/10 which makes for a thoroughly enjoyable title. You know what you got coming going in if you've played the prior titles and are totally blown away by how impressive it looks. Then there are the levels that with every consecutive playthrough, affords you new ways to attack and explore and achieve goals set within the level. SO much replayability in this title and a great developer that supports their fans!

It has been a long time since I have found myself enjoying a game to this extent, and looking forward to the next session with such anticipation, and have each one being completely satisfying. This is mostly playing single player mode so far; haven't tried multiplayer, but I did play a nice 3-hr co-op with my brother (who at one time was rated in the top 10 Halo players). He was thoroughly impressed with the game and the Co-op. SE4 has knocked it out of the park here! So fun! Great mechanics! Deliciously satisfying head (and kidney shots), amazing maps and gorgeous scenery. Usually I don't like 3rd person shooters that much, but this one has shattered that mold and has become my favorite game to play, since Alien Isolation (which I played 4 times through and started another, lol).

I was really hesitant to get this game, because I was extremely frustrated with Demon Souls, Dark Souls, and Lords of the Fallen. I decided to give the "soulsborne" genre (in the form of Nioh) one last chance before giving up.

why is this series annual and can someone tell the difference between this game and its yearly counter parts

Forza started with Forza Motorsport, which is a simulation racer in the likes of Gran Turismo. Forza Horizon is a joint development between Playground Games and Turn 10 (the creators of Motorsport) and started as a spinoff. It's an open world racer that is a hybrid between an arcade racer and simulation. It revolves around festivals in which every races is spread across the world. They're totally different racers, and I personally prefer Forza Horizon series more. Both are some of the best racers on the market.

Motorsport: Serious racing on race tracks, more simulation based
Horizon: Open world fun racing on pretty much everything, more arcade based and has a story revolving around a festival.

It's not really an annual series but two bi-annual series, they do share the same core hence they are both called Forza.
