I was a little hesitant to get this game especially at $30, but I finally caved last night and I am so glad I got it.  I have played for several hours now and it appears that the bugs mentioned in the review have been patched.  Such a fun, immersive social experience.  The community is very helpful and make this game a true joy to play.  You can vote to kick any players who are ruining the experience and it really helps to keep each round enjoyable.  This will be my go to VR game for a long time to come.

I love the game, and i have played eve Valkyrie, surgeon simulator, lethal vr and a host of other vr experiences. The games are always super fun, and delightful depending on if you know how to fool groups of people. Id rate this a 9 in my opinion. How this game got a 6 for bugs that I have only experienced once is beyond me.

The mic bug and book bug have now been fixed. Yes there are still other bugs with the game but they don't happen as often as this review has you believe. You can quite easily play a good 2 hours without encountering even a single problem. The problem isn't with the PSVR mic either, again the review seems the indicate this, it was a problem across all platforms, but UbiSoft are working on more patches to make it run smoother.
In all honestly the is one of the few VR games that I continually go back to. Each game is different depending on your role and the tactics your opponents tend to use. The community is also great, not once have I encountered a single hostile person on there, everyone is willing to help newbies and even when in the lobby waiting for new players you can get into some great conversations with people from across the globe. In terms of the 7 minute time allowance, this is PLENTY of time use your detective skills as a group and figure out who amongst you is lying, any longer would be too drawn out especially if you manage to get a good group of people who are on the ball then its possible to weed out the werewolves in a few minutes. I have had this game for over two weeks now and still find myself wanting to go back for more. Especially when you want to get that elusive unanimous deviant trophy.
If this was a bugless game I would probably give it a 10/10. But until those small glitches get fixed id still be happy to give it a 8.5/10. No its not the best looking VR game out there nor is it the most immersive, but is one of the few VR games that can keep you coming back for more over and over. Great communities, great attention to detail and hilariously fun. You can beat the feeling knowing you pulled the wool over a group of strangers. 8.5/10 with lots more potential - BUY IT
If you DON'T have VR, an awesome 3D alternative coming soon is "Throne of Lies: The Online Game of Lies & Deceit". Google the trailer :)

It's telling that even now, people are still coming here to share  their profound experiences with this game and the comments here are a complete contrast to those posted when the game came out. I can appreciate the frustrations people were having with the controls & camera (not an issue for me), but on the other hand, by focusing so much on these issues I think that some people missed something truly spectacular here that will become a landmark in gaming history. This game is much more than the sum of it's parts and having finished the game now, I can say that in my 35 years of gaming, for me, very few games have reached these heights in being able to convey such depth of emotion, beauty and wonder. I think that for so many of us to be saying that this experience was so deep and will stay with us forever points to a possibility that some reviewers were so focused of the technical shortcomings that perhaps they ended up not being able to see the woods for the trees - and by overly engaging in such negative feelings as a result, unfortunately missed out on a profound gaming experience. Not that I necessarily disagree with all their observations - I swapped out my old PS4 with a PS4 pro at this time, which helped tremendously with the frame rate - but I think that a 7/10 was a misstep here. Of course this is one reviewer's view, which is understandable, but looking at IGN as a whole, I feel that to put this next to the myriad of other games that have scored a 7 is a disservice to Ueda's genius and vision in giving us this incredible game.

@Andykars It's like creativity is being sucked out of gaming, when games like this don't get there due. The game was frustrating but it was a deliberately so, which is lost on so many people, when you finally get Trico to do what you want. It's pretty creative.

Finally finished playing through this game. The character's controls do feel wonky but only for about 30 minutes and I felt completely in control the rest of the game. 
I understand this game's idea that Trico is a wild animal and at times you have to be patient for him to do as you want but there were a few times in the game that it REALLY teetered between feeling like it was designed to struggle and the game really just completely not complying with you for no apparent reason. 
Camera controls and character controls were very difficult for me to get used to right away but after a little while I had it mastered and never really found it to be an issue for 90% of the game. 
All that being said, this game 100% nails the relationship building between you and Trico. Every single complaint about this game got thrown out the window because I loved watching Trico interact with the world, you, and foes in such a natural manner. 
I was absolutely willing to look past these shortfalls and press on because when this game hit its highs, it absolutely destroyed the ceiling and kept going. 
Definitely not a perfect game but one that I will remember for years to come because I truly have never experienced anything quite like it.
The few "problems" with this game are actually part of its charm. It deserves a much higher rating than 7. Anybody with any patience will have no problem dealing with the little quirks.

The interesting thing about this review is that it really doesn't read like a 7.0. It reads like someone who wants to give the game a much higher score, but feels obligated to give an average score because of issues that some people might not be able to get past. Which is totally understandable, because everything he says is true; it definitely can be a very cumbersome and trying game.
But a pretty good argument can be made that the elements many people take as simply poor design are actually intentional, because as far as I can tell it would actually be pretty easy, for example, to program Trico to respond immediately to your commands. The fact that he doesn't is almost certainly part of the design, not a "glitch" or whatever.
I might be reading too much into it, but there's a proverb that says "the horse knows more than the rider." This might be part of the design philosophy behind TLG, because in a time where people are becoming more and more impatient with any loss of control in gaming, and more insistent on immediate satisfaction of their impulses, TLG constantly forces you to hit the brakes and patiently wait for something wiser than you to find the way forward.
Did they do it perfectly? Probably not, there are definitely too many parts that are excessively obtuse and frustrating, even if that was their intention. But a case can be made that TLG succeeded at what it set out to do, and maybe it's something more of us would do well to appreciate.

Someone earlier in the comments said that turn-based combat is not for AAA games anymore? Well, I must suggest him to check on Persona 5 with 9.3 score on metacritics and easily one of my favorite JRPG's with solid turn-based combat with countless summons, classic magic system, guns and swords.

I'd give FFXV not more than 7.5 and even this score is basically for pretty graphics I guess because gameplay itself, at least for me, feels like something forced, like an activity I'd want to finish asap, like a homework I don't want to do, or something similar.

Sure the graphics are great, and new characters and locations makes it worth playing; but since they have released a game every year, the games go untested and get released with far too many bugs. I was hoping that the bugs in the earlier games like AC2, specifically in the controls should have been resolved. Instead they made unnecessary graphics changes to NPCs that only shows their lack of respect to their fanbase. The PS4 controllers are much more sensitive, and trying to control Ezio is a fast paced challenge such as a race or whatever makes it so damn hard to control that infuriates me to no end. I have not gotten to Brotherhood yet and I am still hopeful that the changes are better for that game but so far, I am disappointed in the changes.

Im beginning to have some doubts about the future of the PSVR. Its not that the headset doesnt completely blow me away. I mean, Sony did an excellent job, as most reviewers admit, but now something is becoming quite obvious. Putting great hardware into the hands of Developers doesnt mean that they know how to make VR "Fun". I've played a multitude of PSVR games and experiences, and its not that consumers are at fault in any way, but being inside a game is only entertaining when the game is entertaining, and so far for me at least, the London Heist was just about the only game that is entertaining. What happens when gamers get accustomed to being within the environments, and it does happen, how are they going to make people "WANT" to be there? Robinsons entire "magic" is based on immersion, but you arent really doing anything notable. Look at it this way. Is the gamer mentality based on sight seeing? I mean, when was the last time you saw gamers comparing pictures of nature excitedly? That doesnt even happen. I bought Robinson day one because I really needed convincing that VR will have a real future after the rash of tiny over glorified tech demos, masquerading as real full length games, and what did I find? I found a super linear guided tour of my local parks Greenhouse with Animatronic Dinosuars. If Sony wants to make this device successful, they really need to get their 1st party Devs working on a "Must Own" game real quick for the sake of their product and consumer base, they need to come out with a graphically impressive, absolutely entertaining, "Actual" full length game , or their going to have a modern "Sega Dreamcast" on their hands. Sega's hardware was great, but lack of support did it all in. There is sooo much potential to be had, but it all hinges on the imagination of what the developers are offering in the department of fun, and so far that problem seems to be why Sony offered such a huge demo disk of experiences. It appears Sony couldnt get any single experience to pass through the door that separates what gamers would consider "Great enough to keep them interested and playing for 10's of hours", from something they'd consider a "Quick kiss on the cheek,and goodbye forever" sort of experience.

Don't feel too bad it's the same problem on the Oculus, and the VIVE! Everything is very basic tech demo type games. The only game I play for long periods of time with the Rift is Elite Dangerous. Almost all other games are just gimmicky quick "experiences". I agree if developers don't start making full on games for these devices they won't survive. I want to see Fallout 4, Skyrim, open world AAA games, and none of that warping crap to move!
....why does it move soooooooooooooo slowly????

Because there is nothing that makes sense any better than putting a basketball hoop in the middle of fantasy nowhere, just to be as unplayable as phuk. How do I alter the controls to stop the motion sickness. What should the controls be set as? I have played around and lost the original settings and now cannot play because of the motion.

I'll get back to you on that. I personally use smooth and set strafe to normal. I'm not prone to motion sickness, though. If you can, play sitting on a swivel chair, or standing. There's a bit of cable management to do, but it means you can play without spinning the view. Also, when you do have to spin the view, either go at a slower pace or even close your eyes. you can also focus on the glove which gives your brain something steady to focus on while spinning.
Thank you for your help. I have been playing around with the settings and now don't know what default was. I will just have to keep playing and see if I can overcome this. Very expensive to give up.

Hello! If you don't mind playing standing up, I would really recommend that. It's more immersive and you shouldn't get motion sickness from robinson walking in the direction you're facing. The default controls were pie chart in the turn section, the strafe option on, and horizontal speed correction on. When you start climbing or drop down a ledge, close your eyes as you initiate because the view spins the surface to face the camera!

@TheLateGamer Nope

Apologize for posting two times in a row- however, I would like to retract my previous review of Skyrim. Almost immediately after writing it, I said, "Oh, fuck it, I'll complete this first Thieves Guild Quest", and slowly but surely, the game completely turned around for me, and I started to get it. 

Since then, Skyrim has become incredibly engrossing and addicting, to a point that I almost feel ashamed of it(I don't want to spend every breathing moment playing games!). I wanted to leave my previous post up though, because I felt that a lot more people might stick with Skyrim a little longer, if they saw that (for me-at least) the game DOES get better, and that even in a post-witched III world, Skyrim still stands apart as a unique and enthralling experience.

I think the hardest thing to get out of my head was the aimlessness I felt after doing a few of the main quests, which really did seem quite lame. After killing my first dragon I suddenly had about 15 side quests thrown at me, had no money to get a horse, and was losing patience going out 'exploring'. 

However, it turns out that this 'aimlessness' is actually what makes Skyrim such a cool game, because you can become whoever you want to be which is one thing The Witcher didn't allow for.

Word of warning: you cannot switch the DLCs off in this game. This means that once you hit level 10, the vampires from Dawnguard DLC start appearing whenever you enter town, and start killing important folk such as traders, trainers, side quest givers or whoever happens to be there.
This is pain in the butt, as the only way to prevent these deaths is to avoid towns after level ten, and immediately complete the Dawnguard DLC once you have hit level 10 (start by heading to Riften). After completion of the Dawnguard DLC, those vampires should stop spawning in towns.
Why did Bethesda leave these game breaking vampire attacks to the DLC? They ruin the whole game, and they know it.
@Classicnerd Thx for the heads up. Fixing to buy this game. Haven't played it since 2012, and none of the DLC.

I would rather wait 5 to 7 years for a masterpiece than wait a month or 2 for some really cheap throw-together-to-make-a-quick-buck game.

I don't agree at all with this review, although I agree with most reviews about the episodes.

In the end I enjoyed this entry of hitman, although the hate it got and the average to bad music and voice acting.

Anyway, this is my top episodes list: 1. Spianze (Ep.2).
2. Colorado (Ep. 5).
3. Paris (Ep. 1).
4. Hokkaido (Ep. 6).
5. Bangkok (Ep. 4).
6. Marrakesh (Ep. 3).

"The end result has been slightly uneven (the season began with a strong pair of missions but subsequent episodes were never quite able to match them)"

Would this be in a review if the game wasnt released as episodic content. In every previous Hitman game some mission were better than the others. But the whole package as a game were great. This is way it just makes it seem like you need to skip buying certain episodes because they are not as good as the 2 starting ones, at least thats the feeling i get.

And with this season 1 ending thing it means there could be season 2 or even 3 which makes me think, should i wait until all seasons are out and done so i can just buy best missions from all the seasons they release.

@BrutalDoom If you want to wait years to even play it I guess you could go that route, although, there's a chance that as the seasons pass older seasons will get severely discounted and repachaged with the new ones and it could be the same price to buy a handful of the "good" episodes or just get a package deal on the whole thing.

Some episodes are definitely better than others but even the weaker ones add variety and more content to play. My least favorite is the Colorado episode but even that one is unique, has four targets instead of two, it has the best sniping (although Sapienza is a close second in that regard), it's got the toughest escalation contract, and it's got peaches (yay!). Plus, if you're missing any episodes you miss out on elusive contracts that utilize they levels in new ways and if you're playing on PS4 you won't be able to do all the contracts for The Sarajevo Six if you're missing content.

Dragon ball xenoverse 2 is the worst game invented in dragon ball history, i loved the idea of playing xenoverse 1 when it came out because it gave you the opportunity to fight alongside goku & the other z warriors, & also create your own character, perfect sounding game right? so i bought it, played it, loved the story, then i got more into it and started playing player matches, endless battles, and mostly ranked matches, and became very high up on the score boards. THE absolute main reason i loved this game is because of the combat, the fact that you had to be patient and watch your opponents move, perfect block it, take your time, make them look like their week even tho their trying so hard. It was an absolutely great game especially for that reason, now on to the reason that xenoverse 2 is so not worth your time or money, in xenoverse 2, 90 percent of the same idea of xenoverse 1 is duplicated in xenoverse 2, the story mode is almost identical which is repetitive and very boring, #2 xenoverse 2 combat style smh, & i cant stress this enough, the combat style has been brought down to a mediocre level, its straight up attack as fast as you can and break guards, and blast blast ki blast and die, especially with the added flight attacks that are almost impossible to block, its such a downgrade, its no longer fun, its becoming like one of those games that someone with no knowledge of games can just press buttons on and win the battle, i would never give this game a 7.5 star rating, especially compared to xenoverse 1, xenoverse 2 deserves a 2 star rating and thats being generous, i would of hoped for a xenoverse 3 but after seeing xenoverse 2 i can only imagine what else will be ruined, & dont get me wrong im a huge dragon ball z fan so you gotta understand my frustration, theres much more on this topic that i didnt even get into, but ill just leave it at that, ill just stick to watching the dragon ball super series, & i also have a few complaints about that too, i dont want to see anymore side episodes, i dont watch dbz to see them play baseball or be corny, i love the action and villains the brutal fights, but thats for another day, i know im not the only one that feels this way about this topic & if not lets see if we can make a change, peace

I don't know why people get so offended when "motion sickness" is a part of the review. If only one thing was worth mentioning it would be that. In a "NO REFUNDS" closed market run by Sony it's the one bit of information anybody needs. The rest is just fluff. If you don't get sick then great. Play the game and enjoy it. This review will do nothing to stop you from doing that. It's time the gaming community gets it act together and stops treating reviews of games they like as if the reviewer was insulting their mother and they needed to vigorously defend her.

@Lionheartwolf135 I think you're missing the point. Motion sickness isn't a problem if it's mentioned as a passing warning where the reviewer admits they simply don't have the stomach of rit. But blaming the game for motion sickness, and having it affect the tone of the review or score, is a problem. It's like reviewing a concert negatively because somebody spilled a drink on you and you had to watch the whole show with wet pants. It's a commentary that has nothing to do with the game if you are someone who doesn't get motion sick.

If he was experiencing motion sickness, he shouldn't have reviewed the game. 

I get zero motion sickness from this game and I think it's super badass ! It does an excellent job of making you feel like your a genuine part of your mech and the feeling that your competing in a real sport. The weapon aiming with the headset is perfect. I had trouble finding things I didn't like about the game.

this is an interesting detail about reviewing VR games. The motion sickness that some people get when playing is sure to turn them off from the game, however, how do you, as a reviewer, get past that and judge a game for people who DON'T get motion sickness?

I dont suffer motion sickness but for the first few sessions I felt slight sensations of it. however they subsided to nothing after a while, most people I know that have tried it for say 30 seconds then declared "it's just making me feel sick" are missing out in my eyes.

I thought that Ariandel was DS3's strongest area yet. My character was at level 200 or so when I went in to the expansion, so I expected to have an easier time than most -- and I suppose I did. But There's more to Dark Souls than challenge; the level design, boss fights, new weapons, environments, and lore additions are awesome. Like I said, I can't think of a pre-existing area in DS3 that was as impressive to me. I feel like this DLC is getting a somewhat negative rap for not fixing all of the issues that players had with the core game, and that seems totally unfair. There are a TON of fixes / improvements / new ideas I'd like to see fully fleshed out in the next DLC. But for now, I really appreciate the addition of this new content. I've learned not to care so much about insurmountable challenge in the Souls series, as much as fine-tuned mechanics, and the awesome ability to craft a character from RPG sinew that I can then take to a street fighter arena.
For this price point this DLC is not worth it.

I hope they release GOTY edition of DS3 that includes these DLCs. On the disc. For us who do not have fast internet for donwloading stuff like this. 
And BTW I do not get the complains about this. This DLC looks better than the actual game, so you should be happy!

@RaveNRolla oh my god man, thank you so much for this comment. While I felt DS3 is so much better than DS2 (it felt empty without Miyazaki being directly involved), I was a little letdown with the game. Mechanically it's great, pretty memorable boss fights, and it's damn beautiful, but man, I'm glad the series is supposedly over so it doesn't officially run into the ground. I don't know why, but I was expecting the same level of innovation and experimentation with dark souls 2 as we got in the leap from Demon's Souls to Dark Souls 1. Then, Dark Souls 3, comes out and it's basically fan service to dks players, and lacks a lot of mechanical creativity that made the series so great in the first place, but demon's and dks1 most likely set the bar so high for me, that my expectations could have never been met.

too many bonfires, I've already found 5 or 6 in a few hours. There should have maybe been 2 or 3. Also it's not really all that challenging, I died only 3 times on the way to the keeper and the wolf boss. I'm in NG+ and only level 110(chose my most under leveled save) and I'm still 1 or 2 shotting most of the enemies. 

It's still fun and seems like it'll end up being decent enough length without the PvP to warrant 1/2 of my 18 dollar season pass but I would have welcomed a tougher challenge. The weapons and spells I've picked up this far are kinda lackluster as well I kinda just want another baldur swag sword again tho, I've been missing it's moveset since DS1.

Nevermind that was the whole DLC minus the boss fights. 2-3 hours to light all bonfires and grab every weapon, spell and shield without even trying... 

The bosses were decent but the over abundance of bonfires made this way too easy... 7 bonfires. I understand not wanting to chase people away that suck at gaming but please don't make me handicap myself in order to find a challenge. I'm already way under leveled for NG+ and playing near no armor fashion Souls.

I think if you are not into PvP this DLC will be a bit of bummer due to the PvE content. The Arena is a welcomed and much needed addition to the game. 

In Regards to the PvE content it's certainly among the worst From has Done. However it is still pretty cool, the new spells are a bit of a mixed bag but the new weapons are Sweet. The new enemy types like the Milkwood Vikings were certainly for me more challenging to deal with than anything in the base game. (Weapon art spamming gits).

Optional Boss is pretty meh but Sister Friede is the Highlight of this DLC for sure.
A mix of Ornstein and smough, Priscilla and Lady Maria rolled into one. 
I think most of the time was spent attempted to defeat her than going through the levels. Cool Boss and Exhausting to fight.

Seeing as these are the last bit of content From is doing for Dark Souls possibly EVER. I just expected a more meaty send off.

Honestly, this game was actually great when it first launched. But right now it's... Absolute trash! I'm not sure if DICE
consciously put stubborn cretins in charge of this game to kill it ASAP or they simply don't realize how incompetent they are, but this game was going downhill from the get-go. Patch after patch, every single one of their updates was slicing off a big chunk of player base. Their "moment of glory" happened two months ago when they decided to "fix" something noone ever asked to fix - the netcode. According to devs new netcode should punish everyone with >100 ping. WHY? Well Driveclub was always an awful game - and still is (and yes I have it). I was really interested to see how this would equate to VR however as the PS4 just doesn't have the power to run AAA titles in VR. That's not bashing the PS4, I own one, but it's just a fact that the PS4 wasn't made for VR and doesn't have the horsepower to run stuff like this and make it look how I think many people will think they'll look. I've owned the Rift DK1, DK2 and the retail CV1 - and VR is incredible - and for simple graphic titles the PS4 should be able to get it done, but something like this requires a ton of power to run at a good framerate. I'd be interested to see what they could do with the PS4 Pro on this title, I'd assume it will look better and run better - but the problem is that it's still Driveclub and that game stinks since the handling is garbage and the game is boring. But still in VR pretty much everything is amazing - so it has that going for it.

I really hope Driveclub VRs graphics aren't a real representation of as good as a racing game can get on PlayStation VR. Racing games were one of the things I was looking forward to the most, but one 5 minute run on the demo was enough for me for DCVR. Hopefully GT will be much better.

@thebadjesus I'm not bashing with the PS4 by saying this but the PS4 just doesn't have enough power to run what you think of as AAA titles. I've owned all the Oculus Rift's since the first DK1 - and on a PC with a Core i7 6-core processor and two 970s in SLI, Project Cars doesn't even look all that great and it doesn't even run well - and that's probably at least 7x the power of the PS4. Believe me in VR you always want performance over looks, if not you get motion sick very quickly. I'd take much more cartoon looks for better draw distance however, one of the great things about racing in VR is a sense of depth - if the sense of speed is correct you can judge how fast to take corners just like in a real car - meaning you can turn off all those racing lines even for tracks you don't know. It's very cool in person. Back to your point however while the GT group is amazing they're not miracle workers - the game might look good on the PS4 Pro, but the PS4 version will probably be in line with this - but regardless of looks we know it will play 5023212x better than Driveclub.

@bigrod69 @thebadjesus while driveclub vr might not be graphically great - thats a long way from saying ps4 cant do good looking vr - eve valkyrie is stunning though perhaps not a very challenging genre - but rigs... now that does looks great with mechs and arenas all with great lighting and shadows, textures and shaders and its probably the best vr game out there right now and its a full AAA game

i admit i've only tried the demo for driveclub vr and it was graphically disappointing but so far its the only game i've played on psvr thats been that way and even though it didn't look great - the cars handled well and i could judge cornering perfectly just like in a real car - something i've never mastered in a racing game before - so never know either with a bit more optimisation or the ps4 pro it could become a good game

@Isondead @bigrod69 @Takechiyo Saying something as brain dead as DriveClub handles better than Forza 5 is like saying your local 7-11 is a taller than the Empire State building. It's such a dumb illogical thing to say there is little reason to have any type of response.

@Isondead @bigrod69 @Takechiyo Yes, I bought my last BMW on a lease - but I wasn't going to get it, I was going to get another Cadillac but their infotainment setup is horrendous. Also the 4-series had just came out, as in it was only the 2nd one the dealer had gotten and they're one of the biggest BMW dealers in the nation. The 3-series BMWs for the most part just didn't look right, I like the older ones better, the newest ones that I looked at and drove just looked trashy, very low class - but the 4-series was brilliant looking - it's a bit lower and wider than a 3-series and it had less stuff hanging off of it, it was just clean and classy. The ATS looked much better than the 3-series, but the 4-series looked better than the ATS - that along with the great infotainment system made me go that direction. Also as a side note they did not have any 435i's at the dealer, but I drove some 335i's with handling packages and some 328i's and the 428i with the M-sport package, and I must say that while the 35 series is certainly faster, the 28 series is so much more fun to drive as it's not so nose heavy. The Caddy ATS line was the same deal, with their V6 being able to throw you back in your seat my like 400hp GTO or my Vette could do, but going into corners it would nosedive - meanwhile the turbo 4 that Cadillac offers with their GM ride control setup they licence to Ferrari, well it was so much fun to drive, you could do anything in that car and it just stuck to the road. The 428i I ended up getting was similar, but not as nimble - but a tad bit faster than the ATS's I was looking at.

disappointing, as racing sim/games could be the catalysts for myself and i presume many other track/racing enthusiasts to get on board with VR. i know of racing purists would solely a console to practice/train on racing games(cockpit, wheel ec).

@darlok21 Racing games are fantastic in VR, but you need a ton of power to run them - the PS4 just doesn't have the horsepower. iRacing on the PC with VR is great, it runs great (if you have the specs), the driving model is great, you can drive like in a real car - as in you can "feel" the speed and judge how to take corners, etc, it's very impressive. Playing with a wheel and pedals it's great - you go over a hill and you actually get that light in your stomach feeling, it's amazing when it's done well AND it runs well and doesn't make you want to puke.

Shame the weather didn't make it but to be expected really with how much power VR needs. The main problem with DriveClub VR is the lack of AA and blurry image, more so than other VR games. Makes me think its running at a low native resolution.

If the PS4 Pro patch can boost the native resolution and add AA or bump up the res over 1080p and use super sampling, then it should look a lot better and improve the experience loads. The actual gameplay itself is still more than fine though and the price is fine, as I have the season pass on the standard game, so the discount is welcome.

I scrolled down a little and hear people state that it's either too easy or not fair in the way you can lose.
This game is good, it's no smackdown 1 or 2 on the ps1(an all time favorite wrestling game of mine) but they are getting close. There are a few things this game as failed. One being reversal, the timing is awful. There have been times I have reversed on que yet I get that annoying message that says I was too quick. Then there are times I'd go for a big boot, clothesline, etc., it's ignored by a grapple or Irish whip. The logic in that is frustrating.
Now we move into the glitches and thus game is full of them. I realize it's relatively new and i know they had testers but someone has to think they just don't care. Probably one of the most annoying glitches is the grapple glitch and there are a few. Imagine yourself doing a run out, you land your first hit then pick them up only to have them reverse the attack and they knock you flat on your ass. You miss your first chance to reverse their attack by the questionable reversing and now your sitting up and computer just continues to try to grab you but never ever does. You can't get for some unknown reason. You're just stuck watching some guy drain his stamina bar grabbing air and you're hopelessly sitting there. Your manager just stares in an eternal awe at an idiot who can't grab you and you with drool coming out the side of your mouth. Well, that's one grapple glitch, there's another where you're grabbed by your opponent and you stay in yet another forever glitch. Just ugh.

Not really sure what Dan was expecting out of this one.  The name of the game pretty much sums up what you're going to get.  As I played this demo as well, I had about 45 minutes with it.  The robotic companion in puzzle games "theme" is certainly growing old.  However, the games' premise is straightforward and simple.  There's not a lot of gimmicks here.  The most frustrating part of the game for me was the fact that my controller kept going out of bounds and I would get the dreaded "red controller," signaling I was outside of the game's play area...which seems to be undefinable.....even moving the tower up and down to various positions didn't always help.  The best portions of the game for me was when I could place a block down slowly and with precision....then I actually felt like I was building something, instead of plopping down blocks hoping they wouldn't fall over.  I also looked around and found a Hidden Block that wouldn't have otherwise been given to me, had I not taken advantage of the 360-degree functionality.  The demo I would have given about a 6.5 to a 7.  It's not quite as bad as the review score lets on.
I guess if it was named Call of Duty: Tumble or Battlefield Tumble, IGN would give it a 9.5

5.8  How? Are we playing the same game?

Lets see here, a full game experience for 9.99 that offers creative and challenging puzzles, a bit of humor, and fully utilizes all of the motion capabilities of the PS VR? Oh yah, I can totally see how this got a 5.8.

Seriously though, this was the first game I bought and I absolutely love. "Just stacking blocks" is a hell of a lot of fun when you have to figure out the physics of the game as well keep the pieces under a limbo bar or fit every oddly shaped piece onto a platform.

All it is is a disguised return of motion controls.

I played the demo, but not full game yet.  I understand some players experience nausea from VR, but reviewing the game based on a personal nausea experience seems not needed.  Stick to the game details itself.

I loved the visuals, more in particualr the surreal elements that work so well in VR, But I pretty much felt lost throughout the whole experience, the narrative didn't gel with what was taking place. There is a multiple ending element to the game also, but you will have to replay it from the start to see it, not that I have, because I dont think I have the patience for another 4 hours of slight disappointment.
I could not enjoy it unfortinitly. So far this was the only vr game to make me sick. Never had any issue with motion sickness until i tried this demo.

I'd give it a 6/10

It's not THAT bad although I also had to take breaks. VR Sickness is person dependent though, it's not ALWAYS on the developer. I've had people try this game and NOT get sick. What VR games make you sick is different for everyone. 

That being said the graphics are kind of nasty. It's like someone smeared Vaseline on Sin City. 

Dual Stick controls in VR is poison. They should have made it so you can stand/swivel chair and use your head exclusively as the camera. 

At the same time though, VR sickness is something you can build a tolerance to. After level 3 I stopped getting nauseous. It only happens because your brain thinks you're moving even though your body tells it it's not so what you get is internal confusion. Some developers use comfort controls (teleportation) to fight this but that doesn't work in stealth based first person horror adventure games. 

Also, just because you weren't intuitive enough to understand the deep meaning behind the symbolism doesn't mean the developer doesn't understand their own story. A post they made on the PlayStation Bog actually talks 13 different horror inspirations behind they different aspects of the game and specifically call out what influenced what. Just because YOU didn't get it doesn't mean it's not there to get. I got it just fine.
It makes me wonder what RE7 will be like in VR.
Pretty darned good, Imo.

The game graphics do leave more to be desired but the experience is good once you get into it. The thing with VR is that its not like any other game play experience you can get from a TV or monitor. Being fully immersed in a game is night and day compared to looking at it on the TV so its weird to hear all these folks trying to compare the "graphics" when they should be comparing the "experience". Drive Club VR..yes the scenery graphics takes a hit but the experience of being in the car far outweighs the shitty graphics...and shitty graphics can be fixed. Like it or not VR is the future of game play. Sure its a bit hit and miss at the moment but as some have said here, Version N+1 or 2 will make playing on a screen totally redundant. 

As for the PS4 pro, anyone who thinks this wasn't brought out to improve VR is crazy. Sony can t come out and say as much as it would risk alienating existing ps4 owners but what they are essentially saying to developers is.."here is your path to take your games and VR experiences to the next level"...I'd be dumbfounded if all game developers aren't writing patches right now to take advantage of this.

My two cents of course...;-)
I couldn't agree more
I played the demo. I actually fell off my chair. This game is freaky. I don't get scared by scary movies but scary VR is a whole different level.

Get anything besides this crap.

1. The grahics are shit, the trailer is really a horrid lie. Trust me, after playing you'll ask if you're playing a crummy upscaled 3DS game. The graphic in this aren't worthy to be on a PS3, let alone the PS4, the fact that it's VR is no excuse, and in fact the horrible graphics no doubt add to the motion sickness.

2. Horrible camera controls. Two options: You "look" in a direction and it slowly, (I mean SLOWLY) turns you to face that way, in this mode pushing the "look" stick on the controller fades to black, and forcibly turns you, it's like a teleport effect. You can also turn the head steering off and look faster with the right stick, BUT when doing this the screen constricts as you move.

I honestly don't understand why? Why implement shite like that? I've played a ton of the VR games, what's wrong with 1 - 1 head tracking, or using the stick alone to move??? Nearly every game in Worlds did this, and I didn't get sick at all. (I also have a pretty decent tolerance, I can read in the car, never got sick on a boat, etc. Yet this is the ONLY game I've felt so sick on. Not even Until Dawn on the rollercoaster of doom did I feel nauseous.

It was too short and ends abruptly with a not so difficult big Baddie.  Now, leading up to the final battle is a real horror show.  There are back to back to back to back to back to back... you get the idea - battles that obviously take health and ammo to get through, and no place in between to replenish.  It's too fast paced too much to do, so you really can't enjoy it or engage, you just run jump and shoot for an hour straight trying to stay alive.  The graphics aren't what you'd expect for 2016, either.  Oh, and it is locked down with software regulated crawling and crouching, so you can't sneak up on anyone as you want, it does it for you or leaves you standing in the open and gives you no choice.  Over all it's not that great.  Too linear, bad story line, too short, limited controls, lacking graphics.  I'd give it a four out of ten.  Far Cry 4 was better than this, if that helps you any.

So I'm super late to the party but I got around to playing the game late and it took a while to finish. And man, what a fun ride it was. The best story from a game in a long long time coupled with some great action set pieces made for a memorable experience which more than makes up for the sometime boring and repetitive game play. Just stick with the story missions and ignore the peripheral stuff like raising takes for rackets and this is an unforgettable experience! Also the voice acting is just phenomenal! Lincoln, Donovan and father james deserve Oscars for how well they are portrayed and I'm super psyched by the extended interaction with the irrepressible Donovan hinted in the post credit cut scene. All in all an easy 9 for me with perhaps the best story experience since the last of us.

Mafia 3 on PS4 is a good game. Apart from the graphics.
Visually the game is very last gen, about the same level as Saints Row 3. Draw distance is very short, and far away detail is obscured by fogging. Yes, fogging, the kinda fogging we used to see in N64 games... Also, the quality of light and shadows is very poor.
The game is also very buggy, even with the 3.6GB update. The hero and his allies constantly get stuck to the environment, requiring restart of missions.
This is all a great shame, because apart from those ugly looks and bugs, the game is very good fun. Good gameplay, solid missions, and the big world is fun to explore. And its also fun to just walk around and listen to the npc chatter, which is very well written and acted.
As it is now, I give the game 6. If they update the looks and iron out the remaining bugs, then I will give it 8.

I own Playstation VR and must say that my most pleasant surprise is Eagle Flight from Ubisoft.It is a full fledged vr title with story mode as well as 3 vs 3 multiplayer for only $40.The free vr movie apps in the playstation store are excellent and I hope youtube supplies an app for their 360º videos soon.Overall very happy with my Playstation VR and the best is yet to come without a doubt.Honorable mention to The free jackal assault vr experience given free to all by Activision.They need to make a full game because the experience is an awesomely fun tease.Looking forward to Star Wars X- Wing VR.Eve Valkyrie is fun but Star Wars is..Freaking Star Wars.I do not feel like I overpaid for my vr bundle.If you think $500 is too much to have a virtual theme park in your living room them by all means wait.I waited 7 months and was not disappointed with my preorder.Only game I have difficulty stomaching is Scavengers Odyssey.Other than that everything else is very playable for me.Users of vr must treat vr like reality for certain games like Battlezone and Eve Valkyrie.If you spin your vehicles in a circle back and fourth or over and over expect a real world sensations in your stomach like you would in real life minus the g forces.Play smart and you will have a blast.

So I own a bar arcade and own two PSVRs and most of the available titles.
Battlezone is by far the best. The graphic style allows for easier vr. The ps4 is cranking out 120fps to make 60 in each eye. As a launch title using this style allows them to make a smooth playing game. It looks very clean and even better on a PS4Pro. They achieve scale on a terrestrial environment like EVE does in space.
That is a highlight. Smooth. Drive club will make most people sick and RIGS is just not there yet (aside from the ridiculous hour training). The tanks hover and slide which keeps your stomach in place.
The map is a bear. Yes, there is a straight path to the last level. Take that route by yourself and you are doomed. If you collect enough credits working through the map, you will have a well beefed up arsenal and tank.
Single player is only good to unlock weapons. That's about it. It is meant to be multiplayer. Then you can heal/revive teammates, target artillery for teammates, and survive. Having multiple tank classes mixed really cements the team aspect needed to dominate.
The AI does something I have rarely seen done well. It will track you and fire shots in the direction you may possibly evade. It knows where you are and tries very well to predict where you are heading.
Keep the faith, the are releasing updates and I think a real campaign.

Just finished this rather short DLC.  I will admit it's well done, fairly challenging with a decent premise. But it is definitely not worth $12.  I feel ripped off.  This should have been $5 or better yet included in the main game where it belonged.

With Deus Ex: MD, Square Enix have proven themselves to be a bunch of shysters  The main game was half as long as it should have been and really had only one explorable area.  It should have been called "Deus Ex: Prague Divided" because you're stuck there for 80% of the game.  And now the DLC's are in effect adding in what should have been in the main game.  Palisades Bank already featured prominently in the main game.  It was only natural to include the Blades mission later in the game (since it is a bit more challenging than the main game PB mission).  System Rift didn't even bring anything original into the mix.  At least if they had set it somewhere else (say Hong Kong, Shanghai, anywhere really) you could give it points for location.  But no, they threw in a new 1x1 square block area of Prague and set it there, with no ability to travel to any of the other areas.

All in all, these DLCs set a dangerous precedent that now Game Devs don't need to sell complete games anymore.  Just lop it in half and sell the other half as DLC.  I am sure their profit margins on DLC are significantly higher as well (ka-ching $$$).

@tannhausergater more than half the gaming publishers model their games like this. It's your choice to either live with it, play games only suit your standards or quit gaming. Deus Ex MD is 13 hours long, that's a pretty good benchmark and your rant on content is probably not justified. (I havent played the game yet)

@Drakrami @tannhausergater Yea it always gives me a chuckle how people get pissed about games getting chopped up and sold separately, when the people doing the complaining are supporting the trend by continuously purchasing the things they hate.  It's like nightclubs & bars... why does a bud light bottle cost $3.50?  Because we keep paying the asking price.  Hell they could make the DLC $40 each, and people will still pay.

@Drakrami @tannhausergater Witcher 3, DA Inquisition, Fallout 4, all full and complete games not chopped into pieces for said pieces to be sold as DLC so basically, you're as full of the brown stuff as they are.

Honestly, I was just a little disappointed that you only really get one main area to explore through in the game besides the 1-mission only areas where you fly to and back again.

It's not greedy if the original game had enough content to start with. I would understand if the main game was left small as a result but Prague was huge with plenty of content to justify the price

I love basketball. And when I see a game with this terrible of an online experience, it disappoints me. When you have a lineup with 8 diamonds on it, you could expect to make at least 2 threes a game. But of course when 2k makes the game, that won't happen. Shots wont go in, there will be constant turnovers, and players will play like they have never touched a basketball before. They seem to have no clue as to what is happening around them. My last complaint is the Blacktop mode. MyTeam Blacktop is extremely unfair. I will choose one of my diamonds to be part of my team and draw two golds. Now there is no possible way to win against a player who chooses a bronze and draws a pink diamond and an amethyst. It just doesn't happen. I wish that the drawing was easier to get a decent player. I am very unhappy with the online part of the game. However, the modes that do not have online play in them are spectacular, such as MyCareer. Overall, this year's NBA 2k was a disappointment for me, only because of the online half of it.

Take Rey from Star Wars, throw her into a 3D type Megaman game, and you've got ReCore. I agree with much of this review though I'd still rate it a bit higher, possibly a solid 8.0 for sure. Backtracking towards the end to find more prismatic cores in order to finish the game is the only part that takes away from the whole experience. But everything else is beautifully done, this is old school platforming and exploring done right - which is what ultimately makes it all worth it. I've played my copy equally on PC and Xbox One, and PC is definitely the way to play if you've got a decent rig, it looks better and loads faster. X1 isn't horrible compared to PC, it holds its own fairly well outside of loading much slower and slightly less details, but yes you do notice the few differences. I got this as a digital download for $20 bucks during Black Friday and it was well worth it at that price. I look forward to an eventual sequel someday.
Love this game, feels like a modern take on an old-school NES/SNES platformer. Great pickup on Black Friday sales too!

The only thing I do on this game is play EASHL and drop-in online games. Overall, I think it's really good. It's mostly enjoyable to play, which wasn't always true of previous versions. Here are a couple of things I don't like, though. Keep in mind that I do like the game, and I'm not here to bash it. It's more like some constructive criticism for EA.

First thing is, the drop-in system is kind of junk. I love that they tried to make it better, by forcing you to pick forward, defense, or goalie before you enter the lobby. That was a good idea, in theory. I will say that it seems to cut back on people that pick D and really want to play offense. You don't really get "stuck" with a position you don't want. However, if you pick F when you go into the lobby, you usually end up in a lobby with 3 forwards on each side, and no defense or goalies show up. Then everyone quits at the last minute. To get into a game of 6v6 you'll be better off going in as a D-man at the start. Otherwise, you won't get into a full game, and there is a high probability that your game won't even start.

Secondly, one of the things my friends and I have done on every other version of the NHL franchise is play 2v2 with our online created players. For years we've done this! It's always fun to battle for bragging rights! With this new drop-in system, there is no way for us to play 2v2 against each other with our online created players. The only way to do it is to create 2 EASHL teams that can challenge each other. The problem is, we are all already on the same EASHL team. So it's just stupid to have to keep creating a new team every time we want to play 2v2 against each other. I can't believe they made this impossible in NHL 17.

This game is frustrating. The Hut is terrible as you can't allow your players to heal or substitute the goalies when they are fatigued. 

all in all - not impressed at all. 5/10 - brutal NHL addition. Happy I played my brother-in-laws first and gonna buy Madden 17 instead.

"With NHL 16 having accomplished its mission of righting the ship after the NHL 15 debacle"- I had to laugh at the first line.   NHL 16 was a disaster, only marginally better than 15.   The removal of customizable attributes basically alienated 90% of the gaming population, you can see on ps4...the PS NHL population used to be upwards of 30k on any given night.   Saturday night primetime there was only around 1250 people playing.   Having to unlock all the half decent stuff for either club and player is too damn long.   While I agree with having unlockable stuff...the prestige thing is just asinine.   Only a VERY small handful of clubs will even unlock 75% of that stuff.   Make it less about wins and more about games played, and lose the prestige stuff.

BAP is broken as usual.   Your player even as a CHL player should be able to execute the most rudimentary maneuvers such as cornering without losing the puck, which he cant.   Penalties are embarrassingly unbalanced in CPU/human ratio.   Trying to back check while constantly not only being bumped but full on checked by the CPU opposition and not having a penalty called is absolutely terrible.  Meanwhile, if you even remotely graze a player you get called for interference, which is even more than maddeningly frustrating.   In the defensive zone, its like you are constantly killing off a 7 on 3 because at least two of your AI teammates CONSTANTLY throw the puck back into offensive traffic, or turn and skate it right to the opposition in the corner.   They refuse to utilize a breakout at all.   IF you manage to get a pass out of the zone, AI defense is basically like a Berlin Wall with a 20 foot reach.   They poke from about 12 feet away and not only does the puck get force pushed off your stick, it then magnetizes to theirs defying laws of motion and physics.
    Pokes from way behind you not only dislodge the puck, but again zip right to the defending player.   Shots are blocked from behind you somehow(Not even close).   You can still tell when your opposition is going to score, when every defensive maneuver you perform kicks the puck right back to the attacking player.   Seamless puck pickups STILL dont work at all.   9 of 10 times the player will get knocked down, your player just freezes while the guy gets back up and picks the puck up.   The forcefield bubble pushes you off of hitting players when you have them lined up.   the "late backcheck" neg feedback seem to appear too quickly. And they need to lose the "bad line defense" feedback BECAUSE it is not my, nor my line's fault that the goaltender lets 4 beachballs in a game on floaters even a tyke player would stop.

One thing they did get right was the skating, to a degree.   Pivoting and stop starts are like skating through glue and ridiculously slow compared to the lightning quick AI.   Overall the skating is more fluid and momentum based which I like.   The gameplay itself can feel like actual hockey with a touch of scramble to it around the net.
Im on the fence with it...Ive played more BAP than anything, and Im usually an EASHL guy, but there simply arent enough online players to recruit from sadly.   Id give it 3 Gordie Howe elbows out of 5.   Much to improve for next year.   That's my honest opinion

On the plus side Kunos seem far more committed in continually improving and polishing their product than Slightly Mad with Project Cars, the latter which have stopped support more than a year prior to the release of their next game in the franchise.

I feel like I should give my 2 cents on this seeing all the comments. I have been an avid racing game fan all my life, Gran Turismo was my favorite series back in the PS1/PS2 years and Forza quickly came to replace that for me.

Now I bought Assetto Corsa on PC a long time ago (since it had a lot of hype for a PC driving sim) and I thought it was pretty fun for doing a bit of hot lapping with well represented factory spec cars, but it isn't anything that wasn't done better in Project Cars, a game that I really enjoyed but thought could never live up to a game like Forza.

The problem with these games is how they aren't very compelling to play. I mean at least Project Cars has a fairly decent approach to a career but it felt like there wasn't any real purpose in playing through it besides whatever enjoyment you get from it. 

What I really don't get is all the comparisons with Dirt Rally and Forza 6. Both of those games are nothing alike. Dirt Rally is a hardcore rally sim with only a handful of cars, really basic tuning, and it isn't any fun to play if you aren't racing. I like it for a rally racing fix but there is a reason why I have poured hundreds of hours into Forza while I have only played Dirt Rally for a small fraction of that.

Basically, get Forza 6 if you want the deepest racing game available today, the depth of it's modifying and tuning presents opportunities for people who like to build and tune custom cars that nothing besides Gran Turismo 6 can even touch. If you want a hardcore sim with cars that feel, handle, and sound realistic get Project Cars, I enjoyed it a lot more than Assetto Corsa on my PC. Assetto Corsa is simply a very niche racing game that can only appeal to the most hardcore of sim racing fans who only use a racing wheel.

The reason it's got such a flogging on consoles is that it's single player mode sucks massively and it has no private server options... as a PC player of this game, I've over 1000hours online and probably 10max in single or career mode.

Awesome physics won't count for anything when racing shitty bots or doing hotlaps that you can't compare with anyone else.

AC has the handling down, but it's featureless, the graphics look last gen, and its wealth of cars makes Project Cars look like an embarrassment of riches.  After all the development I would have thought they would have worked out a decent presentation by the time it made its console debut.

I am a huge fan of AC from the very beginning on PC, and actually I even played its prequel. I still play it as my main game since then. And you know what? The review is spot on.

I managed to go pretty far in the 'career' mode, but it is way too frustrating. Believe it or not, the AI has made huge progress, but the physics are still broken when collisions are involved. With the really fast cars, I usually restart a race at least ten times before being able to actually get into it without being kicked out in the first lap. Cars don't fly out of the track at the slightest bump in real life, especially if you bump in a car in front of you.... This is the worst aspect of this sim. Makes racing a pitiful experience, especially compared to the old GTR2 on PC.

However, I still play it: there is nothing out there where you are that close from the real thing when driving. Due to the complexity of the physics engine, even the slowest cars are interesting fun to drive, unlike every other car game! If Kunos could turn this magnificent car simulator into an actual game, it would be absolutely awesome!

A 6? Really? The most accurate and realistic racing sim that's ever been released and you give it a 6? Meanwhile score the Forza Horizon games close to 10?

Haven't played an F1 game since it had Murray Walker commentating (2001?), so can't really compare this with any previous versions. I've been playing Forza, Gran Turismo, Project CARS, Assetto Corsa and a few others in recent years.
What I can say though is that this is the most realistic racing game I've ever played, and actually makes the "racing" in Gran Turismo look like a children's fun fair ride.

F1 2016 perhaps has the best handling I've ever seen in a racing game. It is really hard to play with all the assists of and with manual transmission; but the game earns the right to be hard, I've spent hours on Time Trial mode before getting into career to master the handling without any assists. It feels like Dark Souls games in a way, the long learning curve is addictive and rewarding. Once you start learning how to handle the car, you really start to feel as if you are a F1 racer. Codemasters have brought easily the best F1 game ever made.

It's not perfect though, the graphics are extremely dissapointing. It's weird to see a bad looking racing game in 2016. The graphics is not even adequte in F1, it's just bad. I can only imagine how amazing it would be for F1 2016 to combine this top notch gameplay with jaw dropping graphics. My second issue with the game was the missing historic cars, pilots and circuits.
Best racing game ever. the feel of the car is so realistic in the turns and cornering...
This is best best racing game I ever played.

Because they're not really all that comparable; the F1 series is a focused simulation of the action and strategy of a single form of motorsport. I know Forza in particular is very good at covering a broad range of racing categories and it features F1 cars - and some awesome historical ones too - but you can't play out an F1 career, on all the current tracks, etc. For mine you really need to think of stuff like F1 2016 as a sports game like FIFA as much as it is a racing game.

This is a complaint about Madden 16 and 17. Am I dreaming or is Madden playing the game for me. Today was my first time playing multiplayer online using Madden 17. My experience has been extremely unenjoyable. Like 16, for some reason when I am the Miami Dolphins, my controls seem to be "taken over" by the computer. For instance, my running back Jay Ajayi takes off running after the ball is hiked but, on many occasions, I am not controlling him. He makes his own cuts and jukes. He also gets tackled when he feels like it.

I thought I was imagining this, so I put it  through the most obvious test. During a game where I was getting blown out by Landry Jones of the Pittsburgh Steelers, I hiked the ball and did nothing more. Jay Ajayi gets through the holes running ten yards a carry. Do I like the fact that he can run like that? Of course, but it is no fun when the QB is also out of my control.

This happened several times, especially towards the end of a game. My QB has thrown to guys that I did not select. Better yet, he is moving around in the pocket, and into a DE without me make that sort of move using the controller. Again, this occurs on both years and I am thoroughly upset with this gameplay.

Plainly, it shows the biasness of the developers. They will claim that they have a really complex algorithm at play in the engine. I highly doubt it; so much of this game I find replicates the players as they are on the actual field. Jarvis Landry is not dropping pass in traffic 75 percent of the time.
Does anyone really like the pay (more) to play Madden (ultimate or whatever?) spend lotsa money to improve your team? blech.

So I've been playing madden since the early 90's and I have to say that there are some flaws with the game that just irritate the hell out of me. first, the run game is trash. the running back runs into the blocks or he runs into a crowd of defenders. the WR's cant catch diving or catches in traffic. most WR's in the NFL can do these things sometimes but I have yet to have a WR catch a diving catch. this last patch update was trash too. all they did was beef up the defense and did nothing like fix the run game or WR catching. there is no way that a CB can read what play I'm running which leads me to the next thing, the way the game makes you turn the ball over just to keep the game close. I can have a guy wide open for a catch and all of a sudden the game glitches and the defender is catching the ball. the broken play aspect doesn't work right either. a broken play is when the defense rushes through the O-line and the QB has to take a sack, well in the game it happens on normal pass rush, then when by the time you realize it you get sacked and automatically fumble the ball. this last patch didn't improve anything, how can you enjoy the game if you cant even do the basics or you'll have an good first half then in the third quarter you can barely move the ball then in the fourth quarter everything just opens up. there's no consistency. EA made the game one sided if you like to play defense your good to go but if you like offense you better know the playbook you using or you're screwed. EA focused on to much flash and not enough football, doing jukes, stiff arm and all that other stuff isn't necessary all the time especially when there's no defenders around and it slows them down. there's just too much showcasing going on and not enough football being played. oh and what's up with every time the ball gets swatted from a receiver the ball goes flying in the air just so the defense can intercept the ball, and how is it that a DB can catch better than an elite WR like Julio jones, A.J.Green, etc. EA knows people is going to buy madden but they need to get back to the basics of the game and stop worrying about all the flash. watch some real football games and see how much madden doesn't reflect it. madden 17 needs a complete overhaul because some of the stuff that happens in the game is ridiculous and nothing happens on its own, the game controls how you play and it should be the other way around.

@nit34 ahaha I just dropped the game in the shredder. First Madden I've purchased since 2003 so I was expecting... I don't even KNOW at this point, but everything you said is true. The issues wouldn't be so glaring if I were playing against a human opponent but against the computer the game's outright bizarre tendencies are far too pervasive to overlook. After I threw the ball to my tight end and saw it pass through his hands, drill him in the facemask, and wobble to the ground for an incompletion (for the 3rd time that half) I knew it was over. Again though, I'm sure the game would be a blast online against actual human beings, but against the computer it's like Tecmo Super Bowl with shinier graphics and half the fun.
Looks like more of that "games as art" nonsense. Will skip this and get the next call of duty

I tend to like 'artsy' games, really liked Journey, but after finishing this one I felt very unsatisfied. It plays mostly as a tech demo for 1) It's programmatic undulating cubic backdrops and 2) It's programmatic puzzle piece assembly scenes. Neither present any new variety as you play, so I feel reviewers have been getting way over distracted by them. Gameplay is very limited, it's largely a crude, linear platformer in the sky, with crude controls to match. Most of the time the level design removes any real chance that you'll be challenged or fall, but in the one or two places requiring skill, you'll tumble repeatedly. Lastly, it fails at the one thing it could have embraced - the dancing mechanic. It's useless. Swap in prancing for a run animation, toe walking for normal walking, etc. and you've got this. It's very superficial. So without any real gameplay, a glazed over trope'y story, and nearly no variety or challenge between levels, this one falls flat. Save your praise for experiential games much better than this.

Ok, I made myself finish it after getting bored in the first hour. It took less than three hours total to get to the end, acquiring half the available trophies too without trying too hard.

I have no problem with a short, calm, exploration-focused game. But:
1. The controls are terrible and *never* became comfortable (despite what this review claims). I tried all variations of Normal/Inverted for both camera and player controls, and tried hardest to make the default work, but it's all just terrible.
2. Boring. Not calm and relaxing for long, because you'll be bored, then frustrated. Not going to meditate when it's the tenth repetitive meditation spot and you're wondering how much longer this inanity goes on and how much this game cost you...
3. Mostly inscrutable story. Or else I did understand it, but it was shockingly basic.

I'm sad I bought this--it made me angry in the end. Journey I loved, but this failed.
Having said that...the scenes with the whales and the giant school of fish were genuinely awesome. Just not nearly enough to carry the rest of Abzu.

Fru is absolutely fantastic and everyone should play it. It is a great example of why all of the asinine anti-Kinect bias that has plagued this industry for the past few years is vexing. We need variety, and in an otherwise stale industry, Kinect provides that.

That said, Fru is not an anomaly. There are more than two dozen Kinect games on Xbox One, and many of them are worthy of recognition. Some of them are absolutely superb (Fantasia: Music Evolved, Dark Dreams Don't Die, Dance Central Spotlight, Fru, and Xbox Fitness [RIP], for instance). Some of them are very good (Fruit Ninja Kinect 2, Kung-Fu for Kinect, Kinect Sports Rivals), and many more are good (Zoo Tycoon, Peggle 2, Shape Up, Blue Estate, etc.)

And this list of noteworthy Kinect games doesn't include the excellent Kinect Xbox 360 games that should've been ported to Xbox One, such as Child of Eden, Kinect Party, Gunstringer, and dozens more.

What drove me insane the moment I picked it up was the freezy, jerky graphics that provide about 100 feet of draw distance. At one point, I lagged (I say lagged, but i was playing a local game, mind you) past a zombie and a MASSIVE building popped into view where there had been wide open sky just a couple steps away. Terrible idea in an apocalyptic setting to not be able to see the ominously looming safe haven in the distance. I literally have no idea what's around me. EDIT: Forgot to mention the zombie animations that make it difficult to discern if they are laying on the ground stunned, or dead. Kicking it while it's down? "Harvesting" it? Just gotta wait for a HUD popup. Realism at its finest.
Besides the graphics (arguably subjective), the controls for console are abysmal. Period. Too much interface for controller use.
It's a very customizable game that has a ton of potential for me, but The Fun Pimps developed a LAZY AF port, and Telltale Publishing just rode out the money grab.
Do yourself a favor and AVOID the console version and get this on Steam.

This is a very bad one sided review. I decided to try this game on xbox because the actually gamer reviews were really good. The game has so much depth and you just get sucked right into the world. Survival is key and with the clock ticking it really gives alot of hard choices to make. Do you scavenge for that food you are desperate for or do you fortify  the base further as you are getting close to day 7,14 ,21 etc. You start with really rubbish tools and you to grind towards higher gear which is really rewarding, upto day 14 you do nothing but try and survive by improving your stats, weapons and base. After that you move onto things like building minibikes, cement mixers , lead battery lighting and so so much other things. The time really flys when playing this game. The graphics are certainly poor but the game play is fantastic and  if like me you grew up playing mega drives and N64s then the graphics really arent a problem. Highly recommend this game to any rpg lover. Bacon and eggs anyone

@lost.at.sea I am heavily inclined to agree with you, but Destiny had its perks and downsides. Early on, yeah, not a whole lot of end game content. You had the Vault of Glass (the only raid in Vanilla Destiny) and the occasional Iron Banner event which wasn't so hot either, and was the only premier PvP event before the release of Trials of Osiris. From someone who has been there from the beginning, this expansion is far from the failure it is perceived to be. Most of us remember the grind in the Dark Zone hunting for exotics only to be relentlessly gunned down by rogues and have our gear stolen. This expansion handed over the Dark Zone to the PvP players permanently and gave us, the PvE players, a place to reliably farm for gear in relative safety without fear of rogues. It's a great thing to have in my honest opinion. It may be a "grind", but I think I speak for a lot of people when I say I'd rather farm with a team for hours and get ok loot rather than risk losing hours hunting bosses all with the risk that I may find nothing good and lose DZ rank in the process.

Hi, guys! I'm Meghan and I wrote this review. I know it's late, but unfortunately we had to switch reviewers at the last minute, so thank you for your patience while I played through it. It's a fun game, for sure. :)

Stumbling back on this article months later, it's really a pity that IGN stayed in the typical expected safe zone to give this game a score that was expected, not the score it deserved. 

Finally we get a bright and colorful game with a truly unique narrative. Unfortunately this game was plagued by skeptics and narratives working against it like "I hate J-pop, so this game will be dumb" and "This doesn't look like a Fire Emblem game!"

These narratives were hard to shake and made this game a hard sell for many fans. The review score seems to reflect a vestigial need to reduce the credit this game gets for being a fun RPG with an addictive battle system. For being J-pop idols, the main characters are surprisingly likable and interesting. The gameplay is very similar to a MegaTen or Persona game, and the Fire Emblem connection makes sense without it disturbing the cannon of that series too much.

It's a shame that even when the Wii U took risks we had the western game media always digging and searching for reasons to slap down anything that tried to deliver fun outside of the box.

I'm really enjoying this game. I'll admit, over the last few years I haven't been finishing many of my games. Especially the longer (40+ hour) ones. But I know this game will be one that I do finish.
It's pretty much exactly what I've been waiting for in a single player game. The experience is laid back because it lets you save, and pause whenever you need to. And also allows for multiple save files. That's a comfy feeling to have those options.
So in a way, a lot of the pressure feels off. But it's not boring. When the action is on, it's on. What it does, it does very well. The turn based battles allow you to take a moment to enjoy the great art style and effects. And because they're turn based, you can walk away and return whenever you need to.
This is going on too long and I haven't come close to making my point. I'll just say if you want a great turn based JRPG, and don't mind a little flamboyantly Japanese coo coo mixed in, you should play this.

Warning to inverted control players...there is none (accept for flying which makes its absence that much more absurd for having none for camera control). WTF!? This is the first game I've played in...I don't know how long...that simply decided not to add it.

Now I expect some "meh.. inverted controls suck, outdated, blah blah, I like the smell of my own farts" comments. But for any gamer like me who has been an inverted player forever, it's almost unplayable for me and I feel cheated out of my money.

Anyway, just a heads up.

@iguy78-tk what a bummer!  Thats insane.  To compare that to the standard control tweaks generally expected in a PC game, its a complete disservice to remove a simple toggle like that from their options for a console release.

Also, sure day 1 purchases are tough to turn down sometimes, but heres my trick:  buy used from Gamestop.  I'll go in and buy like 3 games used, try them all out, and keep the one that i like the best.  For example NFS Most Wanted was amazing-- but the damn FPS view stuck the viewer on the front of the bumper!  Like, why did they stick the camera so low?  Obviously, if you're driving, it helps to have a higher field of view, not on a bumper.  Oy.  So that was a deal breaker and I returned it...  Anyhow, that method has saved me some $.

@docleephd @iguy78-tk For sure that is by far the best practice to save $$. I never played a lego game, but saw a 9 rating and I liked SW and the humor in Lego Movie and just thought "ok, this will be a no-brainer...digital download, take my $$". I need to practice better restraint like you for sure.

I'm going to keep trying to adapt to non-inverted, but it's proving more difficult than I would have thought, and making my experience frustrating.

This game by no means deserves a 9... maybe a 7... more likely a 6.5. It is the same Lego Game you've played over and over again, with some tweaks to existing mechanics, while the overall experience has been the same. My wife and I have been a fan of these games as something we can play together but this latest incarnation is resulting in fatigue due to repetitiveness...
- lack of originality
- same poor view interfaces; horrible 2 player split screens and interface
- glitch riddled levels and quests; including one that completely corrupted saved data wiping all progress.


PLUS, I shelled out an extra $20 for this one and there has not in any way been that much additional value added. If I'm paying more for games to cover increasing developer costs, than that added value should shine through in the game. I feel like with this one the developers slapped the game together with tools they already had as a means of making a quick buck and funneled those funds to other projects.
