I was one of those unfortunate backers of this game, and wow..... what a waste of my money. I played the game for 10 minutes until I turned it off in frustration.  Comcept and Inafune had three years to make a great game and this is the result!?!  Any of the classic Mega Man titles are miles better than this shovelware!  It's virtually unplayable!  What a total disaster... The hate is honestly justified.

I just don't get it. I have now almost completed the game and I don't get the hate. I feel like the levels are more challenging than your typical MegaMan and the bosses a little less, but not easy. When you beat levels it not only gives you new abilities, but the boss assists in a level. To be honest, a complaint I have about MegaMan is that often bosses are super glare but if you have the right weapon they are super easy. I feel it is more balanced. This game has given me those moments when I have died several times and then I beat the boss with minimal life left and I cheer. Framerate got me once, but never an issue. While the graphics are stellar and I feel a cartoony style with anime cutscenes would have been better, I don't look at the screen and think it is ugly. The dash mechanic is important aside from combos. All and all I love the game even though I would not consider it for game of the year. All these negative reviews are not justified in my opinion.

@TimSanders You don't get the hate because there's literally no REASON for the hate.  Read through the review above again and try to find the author giving any actual reason for anything.  Their one complaint that maybe might be valid is that they don't like the art style.  Which is fine.  It's not to everyone's tastes.  I certainly have always thought that Beck looked rather unfinished, like some sort of half-built prototype.  But the game isn't an eyesore by any means.  Just look at the background on the Capitol Building level (Countershade's level).  The author's other complaint?  That they found at least one or two styles of combat that they really took to and matched their playing style.  The problem is, that's something that a game should be praised for, not complained over.  I'm personally quite fond of Batallion's weapon, though I would've liked a mode that let us use the gatling.  My brother, a Zero player since X4, prefers Brandish and will literally trash EVERYTHING with it.  But even if these were valid complaints, that's still no basis for a 5.6/10 rating.

One starts to wonder, with all of these really low reviews from critics, but primarily good reviews from users on sites that support such, if there isn't something going on. To be honest, I didn't know about Mirror's Edge until the Announcement Trailer came out back in 2013. Seeing that made me buy the original game, and I played the crap out of it until Catalyst came out. I was a great game, but that is nothing compared to Catalyst. I love this game! I have over 200 hours on it, and I love every second. I can definitely say that this game is on all levels a far better game than the original (and believe me, I have 150+ hours on the original Mirror's Edge, and as I previously stated, 200+ on this one). The story, and the graphics (while flawed at some points) are greatly enhanced in this REBOOT (not prequel, as the critic stated). If you read up on all your lore and got all the collectibles, you'll know that this game is way deeper than the original. Why this gets a lower score than the original? Beats me. The views in this game are absolutely stunning, and it is so fun to just roam around and beat people's time trial scores. The combat is also a huge improvement. If you properly learn how to use the combat in this game, and use your environment, you can be a total badass (but of course, you have to be good at the game). Overall, this game gets a 9/10 from me. I would really like an extension of the story and an expansion of this beautiful city.
@Memo_Rex I'm about to revisit the game for another full playthrough.  It's a brilliant open world perfect for parkour.   I'll be trying to find all the collectibles and such this time.

"Fun fact: you won’t see a single smile in this entire eight to 10-hour story campaign (more if you fill it out with sidequests) until Faith finally cracks a grin in the post-credits scene." 
M8, I literally screenshoted a dozen of moments from the game where the characters are smiling or loling or smiling is implied. You should have someone else review the game and rewrite this because there are people out there who think your one-man reviews are the word of god. MEC is not the perfect game, but it's far from "okay" (I won't even begin with how retarded the rating system is because you're not the only ones guilty of using it).

"A city as bland and devoid of unique and interesting landmarks and hazards as this one"
Judging by your previous "fun fact", I'll assume you didn't pay attention for the gameplay part of the game either. The city is very beautiful, it's full of landmarks that help you navigate, you just have to get to know them (obviously).

Soon I'm about to do a second full playthrough for this game.  Absolutely criminal to give it less than an 8.0.  I give it a 9.0 myself.  Most of what he's complaining about is not something anyone would care about or be paying attention to.   I just don't get basically giving them no credit for what is clearly a huge step forward for the IP, or pretending the first game had some kind of masterful story, combat, and character personalities.  It didn't come close.  It was adequate for the purpose of the game...parkour.  And that's exactly the same for this game.

The open world in MEC is fantastic.  After finishing the story missions, there's so much still to do and explore.  You'll triple your play time at least, making this one of the longer games out there.  But then if you factor in all the user generated content that you can create and share or try from another player, you'll actually never run out of something to do.

The one drawback is it does sacrifice some of the adrenaline moments since you really can't give the AI the same lethality.   Otherwise, they would just snipe you every time from the next rooftop.  You take a lot of hits in this game with the open world.

Another good step forward is Faith's combat moves.   She's far more agile than in the first game.  But the problem with that is it exposes the AI badly which was not a good combat AI in the first game either.

I've just completed the campaign in this and was thoroughly underwhelmed. The story was dull, the combat was terrible and clunky, and the parkour was boring.
The first game was better because it was linear, and you didnt find yourself running the same paths over and over. I am just glad that I didn't buy it and got it with EA access.
@TheManInTheSuit "it was linear" and "you didn't find yourself running the same paths over and over" are two contradicting statements.

How is that exactly?
Linear = single path through the game, no backtracking.
Running the same paths over and over = something that happens in an open world game like this.

@TheManInTheSuit If you're running in the same path over and over, then that's your own fault.   This game is about finding the best path from point A to point B, and it's rarely repeating the same path over and over.

In fact the only part that might be repeated is the fact the open world is split into two areas, with a connecting area in between.  So you will run through that connecting area if you need to go from one main area to the next, but that's it.

This game doesn't even rise to the quality level of a free-to-play game.  I'd give it a 4/10 at best.  Do not buy.

@thedrunkardkid @link723 Eh, I disagree, I think it should have been cheaper at launch.  "Remake" is still kind of a "remaster" in my book.  In fact, THIS is what remasters should be.  Don't just upscale the graphics...redo them a bit and fix/improve things from the original.  That being said, wish this game had a demo!

@JKSonic80 @thedrunkardkid @link723

Remasters are a specific thing, meant to indicate that only the audio and visuals have been redone.  If it's not than that, that's when they nudge their way into remake.

Final Fantasy X/X-2 HD was a textbook remastering.  Odin Sphere Liefthrasir was remastered, and also came bundled with a version that added new content, redid the non-battle maps completely, added/adjusted several mechanics, and rebuilt the battle system from the ground up, meaning it a remake.  Persona 4 Golden was somewhere in the halfway point, and Persona 3 Portable would probably be in Odin Sphere Liefthrasir's level of being a remaster bundled with a remake, and both fully deserved full price when they came out.

And, for what it's worth, Odin Sphere Liefthrasir *does* have demos out on at least the Vita and the PS4, if you haven't changed upon them yet.

@BackInTheDayMike The original Dead Island was horrible - at launch - on console and most PCs when it came to frame rates. It was released with little optimization. Over time it was cleaned up quite a bit, but mostly PCs beat out the issues with just sheer horsepower.
It's Dead Island just on next gen. Review could be summed up in those words.
Lol 30FPS seriously? Christ.
Look, a cool kid. Can I be cool like you? Moron.
@PamperPirate I'm not cool. But 30FPS is a goddamn poor showing for a last gen upscale.

@dart_feld @PamperPirate Not really. The game itself never really received the proper patch support it deserved. It had horrible frame rates, even on PC, at launch and the following 6-12 months. PC ended up just outgrowing the game with sheer brute force via hardware upgrades. While consoles were plagued with the consistent stuttered frame rates.

With that being said, it's pretty amazing that they even took the time to lock in 30 FPS with a slight graphical upgrade. Those who buy this, should be thankful for that.

I consistently get placed against premade groups as a solo player. Getting stomped happens, it’s just the nature of some games. But the consistency. I could not play for a few weeks jump on and bam premade. Vs a premade there is no fun to be had just trolled.

The other is the game designer knows what the people want, such as cool looking skins and such. But make you grind for it for several months, time investment vs reward is not enticing. But this is purposeful so that people will spend real money and if you look at the numbers that had the most lucrative year yet due to people forking out supporting designers that do this. 

At best, I can only hope not to get stomped by a premade, but moving forward where there are no rewards in grasp to entice you to keep working at it.

Why do people fixate so much on what score a reviewer gave a game? Just because IGN gave Shadow of the Beast a higher score than Doom does not inherently mean that SotB is a better game. Reviews are one person's impression of a game based on their experience of it. Everyone who plays a game has a unique experience with it and forms their own opinions based on that. Therefore, a reviewer's perspective on a game is no more important than that of any other player. Furthermore, as a player, if you think Doom is a better game than SofB then Doom is a better game. No one's opinion outweighs yours when it comes to your own personal experience.

This game is fantastic. Love the characters, and the story. The characters are likable, and the story is exciting and interesting; more realistic than the one in the Tomb Raider ones. Its cool that  Nate is almost always w someone (Sully, Elena, or his bother), which allows for witty banter and conversations. I rate this game 3/10.  It's bad.  Marty seems to love adventure games and significantly over-rate them.  Gone Home is a masterwork compared to this.  Also, "long in the tooth" means old, but it appears that Marty used it in his summary to mean simply "long."

I made the mistake of picking this up for $9.09 on "sale" with XBLG. It is an 'ok' game but I definitely felt like it was a total waste of my money for how short the game is. The horror elements are somewhat there, but only in the beginning of the game. The game doesn't do a lot to keep you on your toes throughout and while it is a bit creepy it soon wears off as the scares are few and far between. I have to say I was creeped out maybe twice throughout the whole game and the game has only 2 or 3 quality jump scares. The whole thing is a bit contrived and the interactive objects you find in the world are definitely empty and add nothing to character development or story. If you're going to play this game I would recommend waiting until it falls to maybe $5 on the XBL store or if you want a more quality short psychological thriller I would pick up The Vanishing of Ethan Carter on PC or PS4 (whenever it comes out on PS4).. anywho I think IGN is being a bit generous in the 7.0 scoring of this game... it is more like a 5.0 as it is highly average if not less than average compared to titles like Outlast , the Slenderman franchise (Slender Arrival is only 9.99 on XBL right now), , or Layers of Fear which you can find for around 10-15 bucks around the web as well, all of which are FAR better games with way better story and waaaaay better scares. I hope I save someone the money that I wasted on this game.

This is not an indie game.... Housemarque is a fully funded developer with Sony as the publisher. This is merely a SMALL game. Independent is just that... indie isn't just "not AAA."

@SiLenTPiece Absolutely incorrect.  Housemarque is an independent developer, meaning they are privately owned and not owned by a larger publisher like Sony.  As with ANY independent developer, they do have the opportunity to sell their game to a larger publisher, which they've done to Sony, Activision, Ubisoft, and others.

The existence of funding for a game by a major publisher doesn't render the developer any less "independent".

@DerBeowulf69 @SiLenTPiece Literally the second your game is funded by someone else, you are no longer an independent (ie NOT DEPENDENT) studio - you are depending on the funding and trust me, Sony is in charge.

@SiLenTPiece @DerBeowulf69 Having worked for an indie developer years ago, I can tell you with 100% confidence that you're quite incorrect.  An independent developer can (and will) determine how much control of their game they're releasing to a publisher when they contract with them.

The publishers use the indie developers to avoid the huge risks of fully funding an internal development on an unknown IP.  As long as the indie developer is used to dealing with large publishers, and Housemarque most certainly is, they can control their project.
@DerBeowulf69 @SiLenTPiece Thank you for explaining this.

1 - You can't deactivate gamedpad target entirely (there should be a button that activates it when you press it, different from the shooting button)
2 - You can't inverse the gamepad horizontal or vertical aiming. This is weird because it works the opposite of you movement controls (if you move up you shoot down, and if you move left you shoot right, hovewer you need to tilt down to aim down and tilt right to aim right)

Having played some not all of the games in the series my opinion is this...the game is great...as far as remakes go. I never once had reservations about it being a kid game and while I would offer a kid the chance to play it; it is very much so able to be played by adults. My very first instinct was to try the "tricks/moves" you could do in previous games i.e. flips and evasions only to find out that they didn't add them on here. No front flip no back flip no super cool side flip and no ability to swim faster AND NO HOVER. They also didn't add the skill points which also grinds my gears as I usually play a game to do all the unlocks. To make matters worse enemies like the blarg and the mechpooches can attack you anywhere and everywhere including dangling from a ledge or when you're 100 feet away there are no boundaries/safe spots as those enemies that can shoot at you really can pin you down. I agree with some of the other reviews the game is short but maybe I'm just remembering combined gameplay. I was expecting to be let onto the hoverboard track to take on the neverending reappearing boxes and bolts but again I was to be let down. Almost seems cheap that you have an out to actually collecting the holocards by just getting duplicates. I don't like how long it takes to upgrade your guns although like someone else mentioned if you use the guns on snagglebeast or when battling mrs.zurkon you will upgrade almost immediately I didn't "cheat" and die and level up all my guns, but I probably got a level or two during challenge mode on maybe one or two weapons when I was playing through. MY last weapon to be upgraded was the groovebomb seems pointless but distracts so sheepinator+groovebomb=easy kills. Some trouble with tresspaser locks usually just leave out and come back in for a reset didn't have a need to autounlock. As someone else said trouble on grindrails wasn't seamless they seemed determined to keep you in the track. Also don't shoot enemies so they are knocked back into zones/spaces you can't go or you will be stuck and have to die or restart an area case in point on gadetron world when all the bots are coming out or in the hanger when you are facing the tanks which have uncanny accuracy and their ammunition has a blast radius so if you are pinned down you can still be hit if it shoots past your barrier. Having a super secret spot to level up guns to gold and for an outrageous price actually made the game more worth playing this one kinda seems like everything is handed to you. Catering=Great=8

You left out a glaring drawback to this game. There's no option to save. So after you've spent hours trying to beat just the first boss, and gaining the satisfaction to reach the second area, only to die, you have to start back at the beginning of the game. I haven't been able to beat that boss since, and with no save option, there's little incentive to keep trying.
That's a "feature" of most rogue likes. The difficulty of the genre is what is usually pushes me away. I'm still interested in this one though...

@nonplus86 Pretty interesting - the word 'roguelike' is used throughout the article but it's never really conveyed what specifically that means.

Roguelike implies a couple things:
- Death is permanent -- occasionally there is progress unlocked by something done in-level
- You will die frequently and lose almost all your progress
- Level maps change dramatically each time you die
- There is a pool of random items 

Kind of interesting since roguelike elements creep into a lot of games - Diablo, Minecraft, and Terraria.. but in those games you find ways to save progress. This game here is a 'pure' roguelike. Other examples that follow pretty much this exact framework would include Binding of Isaac, Nuclear Throne, and Spelunky. In all these games it's tough as balls to reach the final boss and I never have.

@nonplus86 You have a point to a degree. The game is hard and having to start again especially if you are having trouble with any of the first bosses starts to make the game discouraging. read to the point where you said you were running two titan z's. 2 gpus per titan z card makes this 4 way sli. of course you're getting terrible fps. 4 way sli doesn't work properly and a single titan is massively overkill for a game this lightweight. what you have is a rendering machine. i can run max settings 1440p at 60fps thru most of the game and that's with only one 980. lowest dips are down to 50fps but thats rare. the game runs beautifully if your hardware wasnt picked out by a 7 year old with an unlimited budget. titan z's are professional cards that "can" game. get a gaming card to game.

The most surprise of this game is the episode in between Acts. At first, I thought it was just some cut scenes with real life actings. Remedy did great with Quantum Break. It's a solid game and has a great story. It has similarities with Heavy Rain and the game's combat mechanics felt to me like a hybrid of Uncharted and Infamous.

Holy crap, this is a great game. It's more of an adventure game than a shooter, though the shooting mechanics are much better than what a lot of people have said, and the time control mechanics are fun to use. The environments are beautiful, the voice acting and music top notch, and it has to be one of the best time travel stories ever told. If you own an Xbox and enjoy 3rd person adventure games with a strong narrative, do yourself a favor and pick this game up. The lukewarm reception has more to do with high expectations than any fault with the game. I bought an X1 for Quantum break and almost ignored it because of negative press. Happy to play.

Gameplay wise, I thought this game was really standard. It was a basic shooter with the time-based powers thrown in on top.

But the story was great. After how great the story in Alan Wake was, Remedy didn't disappoint in this one. It was it's own twist on a time-travel story. You definitely needed to look for and read every document throughout the game to get the complete picture, but I was genuinely interested in a lot of it. 

Hoping for a sequel one day. Although it's not left as open as Alan Wake is at the moment (hoping for a sequel to that too!), there is still more to the story to tell, won't go into spoilers to explain what I mean, but everything about '2021' still needs to be told.
@SidewaysBigM I am hoping for a sequel too.

Just finished it on hard. Dead on, completely agree with the review.
Although I think some story elements could have been communicated better (and I did quite a bit of reading as I picked up any Intel I came across). I didn't immediately get Hatch"s relationship to the contained Doctor gone shifter. Or that his eye drops contained chronon particles. The episodes were surprisingly decent and seemed to improve after each act.
The combat was generally a blast, although I think the game would have benefitted immensely from more imaginative weapons, even perhaps a melee item, combined with dashing, could have been great. The guns on offer were relatively drab. Still combining powers and shooting was a lot of fun.

@argiveajax I'm not ready to play the game on hard yet, but I really enjoyed it. The  shooting mechanics in the game, are a little on the weak side. But the graphics, and storyline were very impressive.  I played the game when on the Xbox One when it was first released. I am just waiting around for the Quantum Break Steam release. The graphics are going to be 10x better on the PC, so I am excited.
@argiveajax That definitely sounds like it would help the combat.

The end fight is the worst thing I've ever encountered balancing wise in a video game. Reduces my overal rating of 10/10 to 7/10... seriously. Permanent AoE, bullseye enemies, not a single moment where you can actually aim.
Remedy why have you done this

Just finished on hard, agree that the final fight was tough and a bit needlessly frustrating. Turned out you really just had to stay on the move to avoid Pauls time blasts and pick off the grunts while avoiding the heavy gunner. Then just being aware when the big explosions start going off. I'm just glad there wasn't a 3rd wave to takedown. Only need to drop his shield twice.

@ThatGuy048 It was a very stupid way to end the gameplay. It wasn't even a 'final boss', despite the presence of a central antagonist. It was really just fighting a few waves of enemies while dodging the red blasts which can be hard to spot and kill instantly. Then the bigger blasts in between waves which killed me the first few times because I had no idea what was going on. 

I'm fine with challenge, especially at the end of a game, but not when cheap deaths come easy. As you said, it's bad balancing.

For the most part I agree with the review. I'd give Quantum Break 8.5/10.
Story is great. I loved the cg cutscenes and the live action shows. (Quantum Break would really hold up as a great TV series).
Only part of the overall story that became tedious was reading through the many discoverable emails and documents. A lot of reading! I feel like these filler parts of the story could have been delivered better. However after watching through all the cutscenes and live action shows, and reading through the emails and documents, my appreciation for the story was heightened. (I suggest downloading the show to avoid the buffering problems)
Combat is fantastic. The time powers are awesome to use. The way the bad guys bodies get thrown around like rag dolls and freeze in mid air is cool to watch. My only gripe with the combat comes because of the slow, heavy, clunky feel of the movement mechanics. It doesn't feel smooth and flow as freely as max Payne did. Also the cover system could have done with some improvements.
But when you clear out a room of guys when using all of your time powers to do it, that is a sweet feeling.
Bottom line, Quantum break is overall an awesome game. One or two gripes should not prevent anyone from playing this game. Glad to have given remedy my money for this great experience.
@davidandgoliath A couple of tweaks could have gone a long way. The game is definitely a great experience.

Finished my 2nd Playthrough and Gotta agree with the review and 8/10 is about right.
I Did enjoy my time with it but I overall I would still hold Alan wake and Max Payne to a higher echelon than this.

The Story is what really shines here. Time Travel story can always be convoluted and hard to pull off, but I think Remedy told a really well put together story here that was gripping throughout and some noteworthy characters in Martin Hatch and Liam Burke. 

Where it lets down is in the gameplay, I feel it lacks any great depth especially with the powers and it's shooting feels strangely janky from the guys that done Max Payne I expected more, It wasn't terrible just not up to the quality as I have played in other 3rd person shooters.

Also The Live action show while Pretty good I felt it was kinda unnecessary and could easily just be in-game cuts. Especially when streaming them NEVER WORKED for me & I had to download the files of a Whopping  70+ GB...!!. 

Still I would recommend playing through, it's fun and the Story in particular is real captivating.

I am pretty late to the party, but I bought the game during the summer sale and have thoroughly enjoyed it.
I think that the reviewer is mostly spot on, but I have to strongly disagree with one of the criticisms.
I don't feel like they gave you the powers too early. In fact, I would have liked a little more time to play with them. There are many different ways to keep a game fresh. Holding out on giving powers usually isn't one of the better options in my opinion.
They kept it fresh by introducing new character types, requiring you to use your powers differently, and by adding in the idea of playing in and out of time studders.
I think that did well at keeping it fresh. They also let you enhance your powers through the game with collectibles, and I never got to max out some of my powers. I missed a lot of pick ups early on though.
I will say that the aiming reticle for time powers was way too small and hard to see. It was really hard to aim the power sometimes, as I couldn't be sure where I was aiming.
The cover system and platforming mechanics could have been better as well, but overall, I really enjoyed the game. Better than I expected it to be.

Totally agree with you man. I love that remedy gave us our powers early. It actually gave me time to practice and use the different powers in all sorts of situations. And once we have honed our skills with the powers, we can switch up the style of play later to keep it fresh. Although combat didn't get stale at all for me. I thoroughly enjoyed the combat all the way through.
It would have been disappointing to receive a power late in the game, to only have the opportunity to use it a few times.
One suggestion for new players is to find all the chronon sources to upgrade your powers as you go through the game.
Also agree with you on the cover and platform mechanics. They should have been better.

@davidandgoliath yes. I had no idea about the chronon sources for the first two acts and missed a lot of upgrade opportunities because of it. I definitely want to play it through again to make different choices and get more upgrades.

I can't seem to get through this game..I'm thinking it's because the action is kinda boring to me and the controls seem a bit clunky. I love time traveling stories but honestly I'd rather watch this game than play it..

The story was amazing, and really well done. Well worth a play through. But, I will agree that some of the controls could have been vastly improved.
The cover system kind of blows, and the reticle is very hard to see at times, making it nearly impossible to aim some of your powers.
I can kind of understand the cover system because if it's were done too well, people would just pop and shoot, and not be encouraged to play with the cool powers.

As someone who couldn't stand Harvest Moon games, I think this game's standout charm is the "simple complexity" of it all.  There are subtle thing that happen that emphasize the thoughtfulness of the developer.

I wouldn't call it an 8.8.  It's more like a 7.  There are too many annoying things that have long since been addressed by developers.  

Certainly the battle engine didn't need to be overly complex, but at least try to do something like Secret of Mana did ages ago if nothing else.  

You equip hats, shoes, etc. but not the sword, which just wastes space.  

It's way too hard to find people for quest completion.  They'll throw out a name you've never heard of, isn't referenced on the map and you're expected to find them somehow for a timed quest.  Annoying.

The shop mechanics are also a mess.  Most every game has a clear separation of buy vs. sell - not here.  It's all one interface, and that's fine except I ended up buying things I didn't need or selling things I didn't plan to.

For me, playing Hitman is like setting yourself up for a date with a prostitute.
Little background. As someone who has played through the franchise since Codename 47 and having seen the demise of the series, I have to admit, I agree with most of what the developers have done with the latest iteration.
Back in the good old days, Hitman was all about finding ways to complete a level with the best possible outcome. This meant tedious hours and days of level exploration, trial and error, and outwitting the game outside of scripted events. I remember playing the Lee Hong Assassination for several days before finally being able to complete the level. What a relief that was.
This gaming mechanic followed the series through HM1, HM2, Contracts and Blood Money. After upsetting the purist fans of Hitman with Absolution, the developers seem to have been trying to go back to the roots and have 47 spend more time in each level.  The challenges and episodic release have done just that. And rather successfully, the awarding system is well thought through and it has kept me upping my mastery without becoming a festival of boredom. In a way the developers have achieved their goal. You spend plenty of time in the levels and experiment with different possible outcomes, but it’s not real. The means of keeping the player immersed should have come from a more difficult level design, not so straightforward solutions and quality of the content, not achieving the same result artificially.
PS. Silent Assassin, Suit only challenge brought me back to the suspense Hitman used to be all about.
What's up with the checkpoints? - and how can u leave that out of the review? Easily the most hated aspect of Absolution. Can I now save my game where I want?
@jmars89 yes
@jmars89 Combined auto-save and manual save exists in the game, letting you either safety-save before an action, or rely on the latest auto-svae when things go sideways.

I am really enjoying this game. If you like story-driven games, this is for you. It's not an action game. More in the same boat as Telltale games, Murdered: Soul Suspect, and Crimes and Punishments: Sherlock Holmes.

This game is very different and fantastic. Play it and prepare for an emotional feast. It's INTENSE! It's completely worth living. This review doesn't know what it's talking about. This game is clearly not for this reviewer and as such it's extremely biased. 

The main characters aren't shallow, they're just regular human beings and that's what makes them more engrossing in this case. It's supposed to be like a movie. The sex scene works well and organically because it happens spontaneously. Under the tremendous pressure which the characters were, things like that can and do happen. It's not always behind candle lights and cashmere sheets after flirting and making plans for the future; the setting didn't allow that but people always have feelings!

Yes it starts slow but it's not a bad thing as you NEED to get used to the mechanics because they're so different. It also gives you a chance to immerse yourself in Ethan's great life and just as you get comfy with your new virtual architect life and connect with the character, it's all swallowed in darkness and tragedy occurs. It's great and poignant!

B-grade story?? Common now, it captures you early on and you're hooked till the end. I was so hooked and had to know what was gonna happen that I played the whole thing in one sitting! I came back afterwards to see all possibilities and platinum the game. It's one of my all-time favourites.
@kewlguitar totally agree w/ everything you said.  super game.
7.5- too heavy water

--> What is the point of this review? "A game that was amazing and set the standard 6 years ago now feels dated and old, so we're downgrading our score."???

Yeah. That's called PROGRESS. All games build upon the successes and learn from the failures of the games before it. That's called EVOLUTION.

That's like re-reviewing Unreal Tournament, or Quake 4 - games that were REVOLUTIONARY wen they came out - as mediocre games now because every developer since have used the lessons learned when playing UT or Q4 to improve their own games, pushing progress forwards, and ensuring that modern games now play better than those classics did back then.

If you're serious about gaming, then give this game a try, REGARDLESS of this Australian's knee-jerk review. The story, and the gameplay mechanics in HR, will have a HUGE impact on you as you play through the game, regardless if you were playing the original PS3 version six years ago or the new version now.

This game is great. Sure, it has its issues, as do all other games, but the experience the player lives through is worth whatever second rate gripes this IGN reviewer may have against the title.
@fatbastardcanada I agree. IGN gave this game a ten? only several years ago. It's the same game. Makes you wonder if games coming out now are really tens or just hyped (:P)
@fatbastardcanada The reviewer needs a new job. I've been looking forward to this remaster since the PS4 came out.

@fatbastardcanada There is a difference in appreciating something as a classic, versus a contemporary cutting edge product.  I enjoy the idea that video games progress so much year to year because of how much technology informs the medium, but that does mean what was once great, is often replaced with better offerings.

Heavy Rain, like many video games over the past 40 years will be remembered for what they accomplished for their time by historians and admirers of the medium, but like so many silent, black and white, and special effect films, they will be replaced by better technologically advanced offerings.

I was looking for reviews on this game and was baffled as to why it was so highly acclaimed. Apparently, people highly applauded the story and amount of content but missed the key point of why many go to fighters in the first place. Turns out that the reviews were just a sweet dream and the reality is that these kinds of games will always fall shy of the more technical games like MK or SF. Unravel is one the most involving games I've played in a very long time. Comparisons to other games are useless as they are mere surface comparisons. All 2D platformers are not the same. Limbo was stylistic but oddly vacant and mainly required the player to make sure the character jumped at the right time, but is considered a classic regardless of its limitations. Child of Light has a wonderful style, but is combat based rather than puzzle orientated. The ingeniuosly, frustrating Ori and the Blind Forest is difficult, but not due to the games design, but your abilities (I died 744 times in my first play through. I felt like a king when I finished.)
Unravel has a beautiful, strange world that is both realistic and magical. Yarny, a bright red taut piece of wool, shouldn't work in the environment, but he blends in majestically. The story is weaved in subtly and with heart. Enemies make perfect sense, and the encroaching darker tone that preceded chapters was excellent. Death comes easy sometimes, but as there is an achievement for never dying, I'm going to rise to the challenge and keep Yarney alive through the his entire quest.
The best character in a game for years isn't a wise cracking, gun-toting moron super soldier. It's a red piece of wool called Yarney. Roll on Unravel 2.
This was a very good game. Beautiful, fun, and sweet. Much better than Firewatch, yet for some reason it's almost an entire point lower on IGN...oh well. I give it an 8.5/10 and Firewatch a 6/10.

This game is so amazing. It's very underrated. I don't think it's too easy or boring either. I love the way they incorporate puzzles into this game. Going from the witness to this was a delight. I gave up around 350 panels completed in the witness. It became mentally exhausting. Trust me I want to finish it one day but I don't think I can do it without a guide (which I refuse to sully the game with) but with unravel the puzzles are more straightforward and flow easy with the platforming (which is also extremely easy imo but that's not a bad thing) but the game still manages to keep you immersed and actively engaged every second with great scope and context. I don't think they wasted a frame in this game. It's so well made. One of my new favorites. I love the house hub world too. And yarny is a charming character for something that should be so devoid of personality.
This game is like the more interactive version of Flower.  In other words, perfect, relaxing gaming bliss :D

Im having a blast with this game.  Also, if you want to make your own Yarny, here you go - http://www.unravelgame.com/unravel-make-yarny-guide.html.  $20 for this game on Origin is a nice price and if you do not like it, you have 24 hours to do a refund on it as well

The folks at Campo Santo should be rewarded for their damage control! Firewatch is in the fire-extinguishing business after all. Always best to put out small fires before they get wind and out of control. How come no one discusses how short and clunky the game is? or that nothing much happens and its so drawn out and boring? Yes, it has one or two nice pretty pictures which you see in the advertisements but nothing much else in-game. Their concept would have been better suited for a coffee table book or public message poster. Henry fumbling around in the amateurishly drawn fake bushes for 3+ hours does not a great video game make. For a game to be considered truly “great” it has to show some promise for innovation and gameplay otherwise its a digression into the murky past. Firewatch is at best a mod or a solo game designer’s final school project.

@wcas62731 It won't be 60fps on PS4. For fuck's sake, it can't even maintain 60fps on PC.
The PC version is widely considered to be one of the most well-optimized console ports in recent years; if your set-up cannot run it at a stable 60FPS, that is your rig's fault, not the game's.

@GodParticle Believe me, I am well above the recommended specs, and I'm not the only one who gets unstable framerate. See, the thing is the game might be well optimized, but it's not consistent. So you start the game, play for a few hours and it runs perfectly fine, and then you get to the Soviet Installation which straight up murders your framerate. And then you keep going, and you leave and your framerate goes back up for a while, until you get to the Geothermal Valley, which kills your framerate even more than the other place. When you're in the linear parts of the game, everything's fine, regardless of how many explosions and other special effects the game throws at you. It just can't maintain the same performance once you get to the open hub areas.

@christophe2315 @GodParticle Sounds like its an issue with your PC. The vast majority say its well optimize and even Digital Foundry found the same. Played the game on Xbox One, but when it came out on PC i couldn't help myself. Bought it again, with the DLC. I gotta say, the 2nd play through on a harder difficulty is so much better for me. I think the game was just different than i expected, and now i'm really enjoying it for what it is (lots of snow.) I just began the DLC, and to me it's what the game was missing. I liked the first game due to the supernatural, creepy stuff. Now RISE has it too, so that helps.

This feels like a DLC that will work much better for people who play it during the course of the game, rather than those going back to play it. The gear is probably not worth it unless you play it as early as possible, and even then limited in use, so it would have been nice to have something more functional for late game. I also think the time factor would have been worse for people jumping back in. For me, it was an aside from the building climax of the main campaign that was very enjoyable, but didn't keep me from my task for too long. I thought it was a great piece of additional content.

The boss battle is brilliant and the story is fairly solid, but this is WAY too short. It cost about £8 in the UK and lasted about an hour and half, which I think we can all agree is poor form, even by modern DLC standards.

Oh jeeze, not you too IGN!  This is NOT a frackin RPG.  It's drastically closer to XCOM than any RPG, and xcom had more RPG elements.  Do not buy this game thinking you are getting an RPG.  There is base building, upgrades for troops, perma death on your troops.  The only role they mention is in the 30 second intro at the start where they say you are the heir to the property. This game is really amazing, but set your expectations accordingly. This isn't in the same vein as The Talos Principle. Mystery is not the driving force. Its all about the puzzles. When you solve puzzles, you don't get new story fed to you. The reward is more puzzles. If that doesn't sound like it would click for you, then you should look elsewhere. 

In an odd way, this is to hardcore puzzle fans what Call of Duty or Halo is to shooter fans. I know it sounds crazy, but just like those games, a lot of people are going to hate it for what it is, or isn't because it lacks the elements they care about the most. It doesn't mean they aren't justified in their opinion. But because its core mechanics are just so good and it is delivered in such a slick presentation it is more than enough for its fans.

This review is INSANE! The game looks pretty and I do enjoy some solitude and mystery in a game, but there isnt much mystery after me playing for about 3 hours. The puzzles get VERY boring after doing just 50 of them. So far they are all the same: you guide a line through a maze with each set of mazes having different rules. Some are fun, some are annoying. There isnt much sound going on, there is no real path to take (not yet at least) so you wander around not knowing if you should be solving those puzzles or not (I just try and solve all the ones I can when encountering them), and there seems to be no story. At least you have a run button. I ended up gettin it on sale for 16 bucks. Not worth it. I just bought a game called The Fall for $2.50 and it kicked ass... sci-fi with a great story (even though puzzle solving was a bit tedious and didnt always make sense.) I'd give it a 6 so far and thats just because of how pretty it looks and how they did a decent job constructing the island. It could've been a more Myst like game with a deeper puzzle mechanic. Sorry if Im judging this game too quickly because of my mere 3 hours into it, but after 3 hours it isnt showing me anything new.

I just finished the game and now I clearly see this review doing advertising for this game...and this is FALSE advertising. "is a game brimming with secrets: daunting and multilayered mysteries " ...there is NO mystery here, no story, no answers to anything...no nothing. I won't spoil the ending, but dont expect to solve "mysteries" of the island or all the fascinating things that the advertiser of this review want to convince us about.

I wholeheartedly agree with everyone's dumbfoundedness of the 10/10 score of this game. It is a GOOD game, no doubt, but it isn't the BEST... not even the best puzzle game. Full disclosure, I LOVE puzzle games. I grew up on Myst and the 7th Guest... this game pales in comparison to those greats. It is certainly a beautiful game, but the puzzles are incredibly unvaried... the same puzzle with different rules is still the same puzzle. And there is almost non-existent sound in this game, aside from footsteps and an annoying buzzing sound when you try to solve a puzzle. If you're on the fence about buying this game, here's the premise: Imagine never seeing Sudoku before in your life, then you're thrown on an island, and the only way off is to solve an entire book of Sudoku...only thing is, you're not given any instructions or hints. That's the entire difficulty in this game... figuring out what you're supposed to do... once each puzzle's gimmick is found, then it's just tedium of solving the same type of puzzle 30 times.

Puzzles are amazing and mind expanding, but fall flat ultimately because of the disappointing world building and story telling. You can't just keep rewarding puzzles with more puzzles, there needs to be something more. It's just a world full of quotes and simplified philosophies.

I bought this game last week. I regret wasting my money. It is impossible to win.I played the regular game about 50 times, could not win a single time. Problems: All my crew take 2 or 3 health damage on every health damage event, even though the event only lists 1 health damage.Passing through an event area lists as giving 1 damage, they always give 2 damage. Every turn I get a minimum of 2 events (usually 3) with 18 to 28 fix points for each one. About once every 3rd game play I get an event with 250 fix points. Die rolling does not calculate correctly. If my crew member shows having 1 die, then they roll 1 die. If my crew member shows having 2 dice, then they roll 1 die. If my crew member shows having 3 dice, then they roll 2 dice. If my crew member shows having 4 dice, then they roll 3 dice. If my crew member shows having 5 dice, then they roll 3 dice. They never roll the number of dice shown. I cannot count how many times the roll of the dice has totalled 1 point less than what is needed to complete the fix, at least 50% or more of the time this happens. Statistically impossible. I Love the Burning Mission: You start out with a ship with 8 HP (modules) and 4 crew. At the start all 8 modules are on fire, so you can save 4 of them at most. OK, did that, lost 4 HP, got 4 left, and 4 modules burning. New event, the 4 modules I had saved are now all burning again. So now I have 4 HP, 4 crew and 8 burning modules. Impossible.This could have been a great game, very original. But it just does not work.

And seeing the replies they got, I live in Michigan and have been driving rear wheel, front wheel and all wheel drive cars for 31 years in this crap we call the 4 seasons. Both give no sense of side and you tend to hit walls even when it feels like your in the center of the narrow road. If I get stuck against a wall (happens alot because the brakes are useless) I barely hit reverse and the car flies backwards, but to go forward it slowly drags to finally get momentum. This game was fantastic and I loved every second of it's story. I did have some problems with it and I want to know if anyone else was bugged by this. Feel free to vent.

1.) The item system was nightmare inducing. You can hold 999 of any type of item but can't sort them to save your life, specifically armor. You can only sell them 1 at a time, and usually a lot of the same ones to sell. You also can't mark items so you don't accidentally sell one you like in a list of 40 of that same item. I also found myself constantly forgetting I had good enhancements on gear and ended up rediscovering them when I was selling armor.

2.) The pre-rendering on the game is very bad. I actually thought nothing of it until I downloaded the 2 GB worth of extra data to help models load faster. I learned that this was a lie and didn't help anything. I still found myself shoved out of cars spawning on top of me after standing still for 15 seconds. 

The biggest problem I had with this one was the enemies. Having a pack of enemies spawn on top of me in a spot thought was safe infuriated me to no end.

3.) The character expressions in the game were static. Too static. I normally have no problem with this, but when someone gives a big motivational speech and everyone is staring off into the void, I felt like I was watching a puppet show.
Dear lord...finally got around to completing the main story. Great game. Ain't perfect, but the sheer depth and scope is amazing. I would love a sequel to cover those loose threads at the end.

No More Renown in Solo PvE Modes? What??!!!

This is a comment that started as a post in reply to a video by IceyCat on YouTube. It has since been posted on the Ubisoft forums in one form or another as well. It has to do with a stupid and very frustrating solution that appears Ubisoft will implement soon regarding renown hacking. Instead of warning/banning those who exploit the game or coming up with a "proper" design fix, they will eliminate gaining ANY renown in PvE modes (Lone Wolf Terrorist Hunt and Situations that are replayed). I am outraged with the proposed solution. Here is my comment.

NOOOOOOO!

The game is fantastic and I love that they're continuing to support/update/add new content instead of jumping straight to a sequel. I wish more games would take that approach in the future. They also do a great job at balancing the operators and making previously lame ones more useful. 

My only beefs with the game is the team-killing and matchmaking. I wish they'd do more to deal with team-killers. A team-kill in the preparation stage should be an insta-kick, as there are no attackers in the building and there is really no reason a teammate should die during that stage unless it was done on purpose. They should also institute a point system for team kills that includes short ban periods and goes up from there. A 5-10 minute ban for a few team kills would deter a lot of people from being dumb. 

For the matchmaking, initially finding a game tends to be fine. It's the replacing players that leave that seems to need work. For example, last night we had a teammate leave the game at the very beginning of the first round: he was never replaced by a new player. The enemy team had two people leave throughout the match (not at the same time) and they were both soon replaced. We played the entire match with 4 people, while their team was constantly replenished. There also needs to be a way to add friends mid-match if there is an open slot, just like in most other shooters. It's kind of annoying that if a friend gets online and wants to play with us, they either have to wait in the lobby until our match is over (which can take a long time), or they hop into a game and quit out when we're done (which screws over their team).

I'm glad Brandin enjoyed The Old Hunters as an overall experience but I tend to disagree with much of what he has to say when it comes to his feelings about enemy design and bosses. This murders nearly every other DLC in the past year and in some ways exceeds the vanilla experience. The environments, enemies, weapons, and bosses all felt unique and were a marvelous addition to the world of bloodborne. Sure you could argue its a little more of the same, but it's supposed to be isn't it? This is an extension of the original game, not an entirely new one. At the end of the day it is all subjective, but its hard to sit back and read a review written by someone who only scratched the surface on what this DLC meant for the story and how much attention to detail is included. I understand it, someone who reviews games for a living can't necessarily get caught up with the little details, but at the same time I feel like it doesn't do the game and developer justice to only review the game at a surface level. The review is right in that its a multiplayer game, like pretty much every board game out there, and some of the mini games are hit and miss.
If you're curious about the game there are some things the review surprisingly omitted, like that you can customise the villiage using landmarks that changes how the board works, or how every month you choose is unique, or that points you earn by playing level up your amiibo, which unlocks new emotions and costumes. Using amiibo cards, you can also choose who moves into this board/village, and up to 8 villagers can join with customised housing.
Just thought id point this out, considering both my wife and i are AC fans and we're enjoying it. It wont blow you away, and its not for everyone, but its definitely fun and ridiculously cute

Retailers are trying to give the Amiibo away. The Festival Bundle is going for 33 bucks and individuals for 7-8 bucks. Nintendo can't base Amiiibo around a single game, SSB is based on many, and now that people know that Amiibo wont increase in value, the demand has dropped by a large margin. We are at a point where retailers will start to take a loss and have their shelves congested if they order many more. 

Kids don't want these obscure characters and adult collectors, who now view them as worthless, are starting to pass. The reality was that most people passed on Little Mac and Villager and did not cry out for them until they saw that they were valuable. The outcry for reprints was really about adults who kicked themselves for having passed up on what would become a rare/valuable items not because so many of them really wanted that Villager or Little Mac Amiibo in their life. 

Take away the concept of expected inflation, and Amiibo will become a very hard product for retailers to move now that they are viewed as common. Call it the Amiibo paradox. Obscure Nintendo Amiibo that are not expected to inflate in price will begin to go unwanted as they would have in the 1st place if Nintendo hand't purposefully constrained certain ones. Compare this to when people stood in line and could not get enough. It is always better to leave the public wanting more instead of over-saturating the market.

Since this game has had bad comments and reviews i would like to put an update for any potential new players, since the last dlc for this game is coming out in few days. I have played this game since beta on PC and im still playing it, and its a great game. Its ONLY multiplayer, but whats wrong with that? You play singleplayer on Battlefield and jump straight to multiplayer. It has tons of maps and tons of different multiplayer games. Its still alive, it still has a lot of players, on pc and consoles. No, theres no server problems anymore, ocasional hackers but fairfight is baning them constantly. But i must agree, this game is not worth 60$, not even close. So my advice is to pick this game cheap, with all dlcs (cause you will have more fun), and give it a shot, and see for yourself that this trashtalk is just from the players who cant give up on their old star wars games. @Chimichanga0 "Its ONLY multiplayer, but what's wrong with that?"

Apart from the horrible load times? And the fact that multiplayer games are universally filled with overpowered players who obsessively play a game meaning others can't get involved, they just die and respawn repeatedly?

Apart from the fact that my daughter who's 10 can't do anything with the credits she earns for playing the offline missions. The collectibles are evidently linked to her EA account, which the game will not allow her to access?

No, its awesome. Really!!!


No, nothing wrong with only multiplayer at all...

@Uncaged3 @Chimichanga0 You expect the motor skills and hand eye coordination and 3rd person and first person gaming experience of your 10 year old daughter to be able to compete in ANY multiplayer PvP game??
Do you want some sort of Kiddy Pool mode for your daughter where she can play with a bunch of other 10 year olds who simply aren't experienced in video games enough to know how to learn the ins and outs of a map, the game mechanics, how to manage cover, lead targets with a gun, learn what guns and what abilities work well on certain maps or even certain areas of maps, pick your targets, work with your team and be situationally aware of the enemy position and angles and not just run head first in the fray like your kid is clearly doing.

The years of fast twitch muscle fibers developed in the dexterity of the hands alone, whether on console or PC in order to be even mediocre at a video game of an action shooter genre like this is smething that I at the age of 29 am still not GREAT at. My KD ratio in Battlefront is 1.24. It's not bad, but it takes a lot of time to figure out what you're doing wrong and what to do right in a game like this. 

I went like 50 and 4 the other day in a round of fighter squadron and at the end I still managed to crash Luke's X Wing into a piece of debris. No player is "overpowered", sure there are some guys who are really great gamers, because they play a lot of games. But there are A LOT more of mediocre players, myself included, however the fact remains that your 10 year old girl didn't grow up playing games that took, practice, focus, timing, teamwork, timing and skill to excel at competitively like my generation did.

The environment is massive, the action set pieces are amazingly fun, the tombs are fantastic, and the story is compelling and highly entertaining.

If your a Tomb Raider fan, do not miss out on this one!! IGN's score was right on with this one.
This is in the $12 edition of Humble Bundle by the way.  I'm definitely grabbing it for that price!

Over all, I'd agree with the review. From the first playthrough of the game clocking in somewhere at 20+ hours (survivor difficulty), it's a very sold experience that I'd rate around at 9.2, and even assuming I'm being slightly generous atm, a 9.1. Again, this is without the additional game modes or any other features.

It felt like much the same game as the first one initially, albeit more polished. Then more and more opened up and added variety to the experience. 

There is nothing I can knock against the game aside from some occasionally awkward jumps where I felt cheated (broadhead arrow platforming, I'm looking at you), but that is par for the course with the genre. There are some notable moments in the game, same as there were in the first one. There are games that have more of them, like people have implied in their comments here, but that's why those games are worth more than a 9.1 in relativity to my scoring. 

On a side note, I find it funny when someone mentions Zelda when that series is known for being relatively stale and the same thing over and over. Apparently Breath of the Wild has changed that, although I haven't yet played it. I just know that ever since Twilight Princess in 2006, one site *cough* Gamespot *cough* said that the formula was getting repetitive, and people got butthurt. It seems that people are too busy defending sacred cows to judge an individual game on its own merits.

...that one review site *cough* Gamespot *cough* has given them lower review scores since Twilight Princess in 2006 under the claim that the formula was getting repetitive, and people were getting butthurt over the critique of the sacred cow franchise. This game was at least as different from the first one as each Zelda game was from the last one, so to use that as an argument against this game/series and not against Legend of Zelda seems rather unfair.

Overall, this is a very solid experience that stands on its own.

Could say alot about this game but I'll keep it basic.

Overall the Game is Really Good. Put in 45 hours.
New Crafting Mechanic is GREAT adding further credence to my views that the gameplay is a bit more layered than Uncharted. When you also consider the more open level design for different approaches and the Skills unlock/Progression.

Now...

Same thing can be said about the last game...

Story, Characters, A particular awesome moment either by gameplay or a Scripted Setpiece...NOTHING. Nothing I will remember a week from now let alone years.

The gunplay is just 'okay' but I can deal with that. 
Tomb Raiders biggest issue comes from having nothing that is memorable something that Sticks with you and can Identify as "Oh THAT Game, THAT moment, THAT Character".

That for me is the biggest difference between this and Uncharted and what they should strive for going forward, particularly for a Story driven Action Adventure title.

It's cursed by how good the last game was. It just feels like more of the same, even though that's good enough.

Also, the rapidly crumbling landscape thing is overdone. It's constant. It's 10 hours of sheer luck that she doesn't die at any given moment. scale it back.

This game IMO gets a solid 6/10. Why you ask? Well, let me list the cons and you decide the pros on your own, ok? Here I go:
-No character development whatsoever. The villains lack a LOT and don't feel like antagonists but more like background enemies. You don't care about anybody or anything because characters are just... empty.
-The story has been made way too many times. They had a good setting with the whole Prophet and religion thing, but it came to naught. They could've taken it way further but decided to make it a 100% predictable story; you know the ending of the game since the game begins... at least I did.
-Exorbitant amount of guns, skills and clothing that you will never use at all. Skills that you'll end up getting them all eventually, causing Lara to become The Terminator.
-Not enough puzzles. The puzzles are great, but they went for the mercenary Lara Croft instead of the archaelogist historian that Lara Croft is. Optional tombs are the best part of the game because it distracts you from the constant battles and the empty story by giving you cool puzzles.
-Lack of emotion. It seems as if everybody was trained to not have emotions. Not a single character in the entire story has any type of feeling in them except anger, for no reason at all.
My verdict: The game feels rushed in every sense of the word. Characters are lacking emotions, background and development. Gameplay is extremely linear, but with a wider map filled with annoying rabbits that you'll eventually have to hunt in order to get those pelts for your weapon/inventory upgrades. The graphics looked good, but they weren't an out-of-body experience to look at. The replay value is extremely low.

I'd like to weigh in as someone who has started FO4 for my second time through last week, (I finished my first time through about a year ago). I'm a pretty big Bethesda fan. What a great decision that was, for me.

My first time through Fallout 4 was rushed, and had me comparing my experience with other games that had also come out at that time, through comments from reviewers on IGN, Beyond, and in forums, like this one. Unfortunately, (and I blame myself for this), I allowed other people's opinions and observations to cloud my gameplay experience. This was new for me, as I had only been on IGN for a short period of time.

I'm loving this game much more than I did my first time through. The graphics, little details, crafting, storylines, gameplay, exploration, and overall atmosphere seem much more robust and all-engrossing for me...that's Bethesda. I'm so glad I gave this game a second chance, a year later. There seems to have been lots of fixes since last year, and I'm reminded about what a massive, in-depth world Bethesda creates. Also in the middle of Skyrim Remastered, and starting Dishonored 2,  I'm reminded about why I love Bethesda games so much. With the freedom to move and interact with the environment while engaging in a variety of heartfelt and immersive storylines, it truly does put you in another world. I also have much more respect for the gameplay, crafting,  and combat systems, this time around. I've played some of the other big titles from 2015-2016, and I'm happy to put Fallout 4 right at the top with them, again.

Waking up to discover that the world is no longer what it was, and that everything you once knew has been reduced to a desolate wasteland that is filled with unknown and dangerous creatures. Fallout 4 is the game that has taken the hearts of adventure and survival gamers everywhere. This game not only contains a extremely interestingmain story line, which centers around the main characters journey through a post-apocalyptic Boston frozen in the 1950’s as he/she searches for his/her child, but it also has an interesting and captivating sci-fi and steampunk type of theme. This theme allows for several interesting side quest to this open-world masterpiece, spanning from starting colonies to exploring the crash point of an alien spacecraft. On the subject of Fallout 4, GameSpot states that “you become attached to the new you”, showing how engrossing and life like the experience truly is. Although the game may seem a little easier than its predecessors, It is easily compensated by the advanced and more realistic interactions that can be made with the multitude of characters within the game.
A captivating story may be important, but nowadays it just doesn’t cut it. A game needs to have more in order to stand out from the others. The aspect that I believe makes Fallout 4 stand out the most is not the story, but the graphics that plunge the player into the game headfirst. The game has been designed with so much scrutiny that  the artists even managed to put life into a barren wasteland. With the hyperrealistic human expressions, and the terrifyingly realistic monsters to be found within the “commonwealth”, the players feel as if they  are viewing it all with their very own eyes. When Bethesda worked on the previous Fallout games, they spent years working on every detail of the game. Though all this work however, it was apparent that movement was something that was very difficult to portray in a video game. However, in Fallout 4, they mastered movement, down to the way a dog’s hair bristles when hostile.  It should be noted, however, that all of this comes with a price; that price is the long loading screens. This screen will be a common sight while playing the game, because of how vast the game is. Although the continuous loading may be tedious and slightly vexing, it is quickly forgotten when the gameplay resumes.

It's fairly entertaining to watch Minecraft Story Mode on Youtube. As a game it just doesn't look like there's much of a game going on. There's some quicktime events, there's dialog choices and a scant few puzzles, but over all the player seems mostly capable of choosing the tone of how events unfold. In the previous installment you're caught on a bridge with monsters approaching from both ends, you have a choice of whether to fight or jump. Whatever you choose, you soon find yourself jumping off the bridge (and a neat opening credits scene happens). Later on you're given the choice of whether to make a tree house or a dirt house to take shelter in for the night. It seems largely cosmetic since events proceed much the same in either case. Maybe there is a payoff later down the line based on which of your friends' suggestions you endorsed. It seems as though in episode 2 the character you don't go to recruit questions you a bit on your choices. 

Over all It's like a semi-interactive cartoon rather than a traditional game.

Oh, and @ reviewer, Jesse can't build his way out of the pit because for some reason he's not carrying any tools.

A 7 year old is not going to be able to write "Likewise, most of Assembly Required’s drama also feels muted, relegated to tension between the reunited Order members. ", much less 1000 words on a deadline.

2) 70 million Minecraft players, many if not most are adults. YouTube search Let's Play Minecraft: Story Mode and see how many are adults and how many are children.

@applesngrapes @Pokeparkranger We've actually done experiments with this. If you look back at some of our Skylanders reviews, some were reviewed by parents, who enlisted the help of their kids. As a father of three, I can tell you that I have a pretty good sense and understanding of what my kids enjoy (and don't enjoy) in games -- but they still have a hard time articulating it. 

That said, we do take the target audience into consideration with game, movie, and TV show reviews. Minecraft has a very broad audience -- if Story Mode succeeded at being entertaining for kids, the reviewer certainly wouldn't ding it for that.

@applesngrapes Actually, I bet my 9-year-old daughter would kind of blow your mind. She writes very eloquently and totally understands what she wants to say and how to put it into words. Her vocabulary is excellent. Also, the 1000 words on a deadline she would absolutely slay that. No problem. 
Your second point is not logical at all. Most kids are not on the internet and are less likely to be documented as Minecraft players. I understand that there are many adults who play Minecraft, but if you think Minecraft:Storymode is made for adults, you're disillusioned.

@Pokeparkranger @Peer-IGN @applesngrapes I think it's super-important that reviewers keep the target audience in mind -- but that also shouldn't exonerate the developer from dropping smart features that can hold back the experience for a significant portion of the audience. Splatoon is actually quite a complex game, control- and strategy-wise, and appeals to teens who are used to voice chatting and skyping with their friends. Garden Warfare is a good example of a game that manages to serve both younger and older gamers, but doesn't limit the communications options. Likewise, Splatoon could provide parental controls or even, more radically, limit voice chat to friends or teams only.  Instead, the game offers ways to play, but not communicate, with friends. Given that it's such a strategic title, that's a fact worth bringing up in a review. Games like Minecraft and Terraria are enjoyed by thousands of kids every day who spend more time playing in no small parts due to the fact that they can chat with their friends while exploring the game worlds. Now, those games benefit from cross-chat functionality on other platforms, which Wii U unfortunately doesn't have.

I haven't downloaded Storymode for my kids yet. I hear you on the difference between kids' viewpoints and adults'. LEGO games that score in the 7s are often better (and more enjoyable) choices for kids than open-world games that score in the 9s. It's the challenge of writing reviews for consumers that seek out reviews (kids don't care about critics -- they play what their friends play) and not easily solved on a site that doesn't specifically cater to kids. But given that we've got more parents on our team now, doing more frequent parent guides with selections of games that their kids would enjoy may be a good solution.

@Pokeparkranger @applesngrapes Yeah, Minecraft is one of the most popular kids' brands of all time. The audience isn't limited to kids -- but kids are the biggest part of the audience by far.

@Pokeparkranger -- your daughter sounds awesome. Maybe have her contribute a "my favorite games" blog on IGN from the point of view of a 9-year-old. We'd totally highlight that!

@Peer-IGN You're right--kids don't read reviews to decide what game to play. I know it must be challenging to review these types of games on IGN. I find myself defending my daughter and kids all of the time. Maybe it's overkill. It's just kind of sad to see that video games have become more of an adult business where marketing decisions are based more on what adults want. I'm 43, but I stay very young-at-heart. I like games like Splatoon way more than stuff like Metal Gear Solid, COD, etc. 
Btw, my daughter has really been enjoying the Minecraft Story Mode episodes. She plays it repeatedly, so I would recommend it for your kids.
@Peer-IGN She's amazing, Peer. I will tell her what you said and I am sure she will do more than consider it :)

@Pokeparkranger @Peer-IGN You sound like my twin! :) I'm 44 -- and really enjoy games like Splatoon and Mario Maker. I've got three kids, so we also play a ton of cooperative games. That said, I'm also not one to turn down a good open-world or mature game. MGS5 is really good. Bummer there aren't more T-rated titles in that category. We're way overdue for a "go-anywhere" Star Wars game, for example...

You actually feel like your playing chords and changing between the white and black buttons feels like you are moving around the fretboard. Its really cool. But the "Career Mode" is pretty disappointing. We have played the game a handful of times and only have two setlists left to unlock. I get it, filming all the live action stuff is probably a huge undertaking, but they should have thought about that before switching and maybe went with a CGI first person view. The online portion features a HUGE library, but not being able to play what you want if you run out of plays is a real bummer. The guitar is great, the music is great, the software it self is lacking. Hopefully the next iteration will solve these problems. I'd still recommend it.

Just finished the series now.  It is interesting but at too many points you just sit there through unnecessary dialogue.  If this were a TV show that would be fine, but in a game where you are looking for interaction and gameplay, this can be quite annoying and tedious.  This is most prevalent in episodes 3, 4, and 5.  % was very good but I got the feeling that nothing that happened in 1 through 4 even mattered.  Ultimately, i only continued with the series to get all 1000 achievement points.  They are very easy to get.  6.5 for the whole series would be an excellent score and quite accurate.  I'm glad I played it and have been exposed to the story line....but I'm also glad it finally over.

I always play games so late.  Anyway, subjectively speaking, I'd rank this game between 7 and 8 solely based on the story telling and not the overall game play.  It was a good game and fun to play, but I do agree with many parts of this ign review: The game is linear, most of the characters were flat and underdeveloped, many decisions didn't have a weighty consequence, but simply a change in dialogue (I can accept this as the overall story was very good.), and Episode 5 did feel like a different game.  HOWEVER, the episodes were climaxing towards this "mysterious storm" and I think episode 5 was developed to illustrate the chaos, turmoil, and thrill we associate to ominous, cataclysmic, events.  And, yes, no matter the choices a player elects throughout the game, the ending is polarized with one very emotional finale and the other an unsatisfying outcome.  BUT, for me, the point of the game was not to streamline choices for a tailored ending (although I'd like to experience a game likes this one day), but rather to witness this strong friendship reunite after a long hiatus.  The game was thought provoking for me.  A real treat.  I give it an 8.  I'd give a 6.5 to games like Until Dawn.
I agree completely
I have to admit the final episode felt a little off but it did not distract from the game as a whole. It was a difficult decision...to what extent would you go for the person you love?

They tried too much in episode 5 and changed it from the great story telling of episodes 1 through 3 into a stupid rewind-fest all through the episode (episode 4 also wasn't good). In the end I chose to sacrifice Arcadia because I couldn't care less about any of the characters at this point.
The high of episode 3 is where they should have stopped this series. Then I would think of this game as a classic for the ages. Now, I have a bad taste in my mouth because it outstayed its welcome.
