I definatley have to disagree with the reviewer. I absolutly loved the game and that ending had me in tears (Sacrificed Chloe). The only thing I dislike is the same thing with all these "Choices matters" games, They sell it as something it isnt. Your choices dont matter. The story while amazing is completely linear and your choices dont matter. For example why the hell do I care whether I saved Kate? She is going to live or die anyways based on the ending you choose. In the Walking Dead, why do I bother choosing who lives between two characters if they die in the next episode anyways? Choices dont actually matter and it feels like false advertising. That in mind I think it is still worth an 8

@xShoot4WarAmpsx I don't agree with that. Yes, it didn't make much of a difference all the way in the end but it defined your entire playthrough. There's a moment in episode 4 where you talk to Victoria and she will only agree with you if you were nice to her all the way back in episode 1. It's stuff like that that is important in the game. It defines your playthrough.

@trollscanburn @xShoot4WarAmpsx I get that but my point is, whether or not she agreed with you didnt matter. It was a pointless choice with no consequence. Why do I care if she believes me or if Kate jumps, if in the end, none of that will matter?

@xShoot4WarAmpsx @trollscanburn I understand what you're saying but I don't know. I didn't see it that way. My final choice was determined by my actions in the game. I decided to sacrifice Chloe based on my friendships and love towards the rest of the people in the town that I had made during my playthrough. If I hadn't went through it all I wouldn't have cared whether or not to let them all die. That's why I felt that my choices mattered.

Plus, when they say "your choices matter" it's not them saying "your choices will determine the ending of the game and there are like 4 bajillion endings based on that and you'll get to see the conclusion of every single character based on your choices." No, they mean that if you don't pay attention to Kate or discover something about her or truly know her then you're going to watch her die. If you aren't nice to Victoria in ep1 then ep5 she won't believe you or have your respect. Those are the choices that matter. The only reason it doesn't matter in the end is because it's a time travel story. Most of the time to fix everything in time travel all your choices end up not mattering anyways. Butterfly Effect comes to mind. He spend the entire movie trying to save everything and everyone but in the end he goes back into the womb and kills himself and everything is fixed. None of his choices now mattered. Doesn't make it any less heavy.

@trollscanburn @xShoot4WarAmpsx But those are two different things. Sacrificing Chloe was heavy because the story was built around her and we grew attached to the character. The little decisions we made didnt attribute anything to that. You are right, it is exactly like Butterfly effect and that was the problem. That was a movie, so by playing this game we essentially just watched a movie. It gaves us choices but it never changed anything. For me for my choice to matter there needs to be a consequence. When it came to sacrificing Chloe or saving her, that choice mattered. You made a permanent decision and have to deal with the concequences. There didnt need to be many endings, just character endings. How did you decisions effect Allysa, Kate, Victoria, Warren in the long run? Something similar to the Witcher 3 where there where multiple endings but those endings where based off 4 areas.

A lot of people disliked the ending but I thought it was great. People complain that you don't know who will die if the tornado hits. That's the beauty of choices, in the moment of you often don't know the repercussions. Also, people complain that all your choices building up don't matter. That's a whole different complicated idea that fate may play a role in life.

Started out liking this but got bored of it. Gameplay is a little too simple.

Yeah, try fighting the big fights without armatizing though. The last boss fight part 1 and 2 before losing that ability. As well as the dark turtle boss in katz korner end game. Those aren't simple without armatization, the dark turtle boss especially. He's actually impossible without it, and the final boss fight part 2 you have to pull off a set amount of damage before you can sacrifice an arma, so if you didn't power lvl before you'll die because the option won't pop out for the gun.
End game is much harder though. The game up until the end is easy, unless you suck at video games. Part 2 of final boss fights is the hardest of the parts if you didn't grind otherwise it's easy.
But the hardest 2 bosses are edna's brother, and dark turtle. Heldalf is a noob in comparison. Those two bosses are a dozen times steonger, they hit very constantly, and they can wipe out 75%+ hp if they use their best attacks. Edna's brother is lvl 80 and has more health than almost every fight of the final boss parts combined. He hits more, faster.
But dark turtle is the strongest boss despite his significantly lower health and defenses. He never stops moving more than about 2 seconds, he's alway spamming whoever you control, his attacks can take out about a thousand each little combo he does, his best skill can do as much as 7000 to a character if you're unprepared for it. Even if your prepared and lvled and geared he puts up more of a fight than anything else.

I'm one of those players who plays for the story and characters, especially in non-FPS games.  Sadly, Zestiria's characters and story are extremely boring and cliche.  You have the cliche main hero who has absolutely no personality aside from being the most pure and naive goody two-shoes.  The rest of the characters easily fall within genre tropes.  Which is unfortunate since the gameplay itself is pretty fun.  The combat system is decently entertaining (though not without it's own flaws) and the overall feel of the game is decent.  If you like Tales combat and don't mind a boring story and cliche characters then play the game, otherwise its definitely a pass.

News flash, every rpg game has cliche characters. And by your standards every video game character has no personality. If these ones have no personality to you, you need to look up the word since you obviously don't know what it means. They have personality, but you obviously didn't pay attention to the talking at all. Every video game character is designed with a personality, some might be less believable or really annoying or any of the above or below. But theirs no such thing as a character without personality, you just either don't know what the word means. Or you didn't pay enough attention to talking which is a constant in rpgs even more so in jpgs.

Overall i am happy with the game. Alot people are disappointed in the lack of prior features but for the most part i dont really care about most of those. There are only things i did not really care for are.

1. No online play - While i did not use it much in the past and it would not be a deal breaker for me, i do feel it is an important feature that should be added.

2. No song stats - This feels like an oversight honestly that will hopefully be remedied in the patch in December as it is annoying not seeing my stats after playing

3. The semi-transparent chart - It is a problem because it feels like it shrinks the chart down a bit and makes it harder to see the incoming notes in a reasonable time

4. The Set-list is meh - I feel it is about the same as RB3 overall. RB3 had more really good songs like "Beast and the Harlot", "Freebird", "25 or 6 to 4", "Caught in the Mosh", "Crazy Train", "Before i Forget", "Crosstown Traffic" and "Bohemian Rhapsody" (probably one my favorite songs eve) but it also had some the worst songs in the series like "Oye Mi Amor", "The Killing Moon" and "Rehab" (screw Amy Whinehouse, now your dead, perhaps rehab would been a good idea afterall). RB4 is just ok through out and not man song stick one way or the other. RB1 and RB2 are far superior setlists

Garbage....what a waste of money.  First off, if you HAVE to have this game, just get the guitar bundle, it's easily the most fun of the three instruments.  But turn the "solo" option off...it's a total waste and is just going to end up breaking the equipment due to it's call for straight button mashing with no rhyme or reason.  Plus, you'll save 100$. The mic is miserable...it's lag is almost a full second behind when you speak into it, which makes the singing option NOT an option.  There's also an effect on the mic that cannot be changed.  So not only is it slow to respond, the effect combined with the lag makes for an "echo in a cave" feel...it really is so bad you can't even use it.  The drums are completely garbage.  After calibrating literally over a dozen times, they still lag like crazy.  The kick pedal can't handle double taps in quick succession, causing repeated drop notes.  And even though this can be frustrating, it's not the worst part.  I don't know who was responsible for transcribing the drum beats into the software but they whiffed BIG TIME.  There are beats in the game that aren't in the real songs...and the random "Drum Solos" are a joke...do yourself a favor and turn that option off.  If you have no clue how to play the drums, that probably won't bother you as much as the lag compensation.  However, if you do play real drums, as I do, the inaccuracy of the songs will drive you absolutely ape isht.  I fully realize this is a game and the goal is to give the consumer the "feeling" of playing in band and is in no way meant to be the real thing....that said, I think the least you could expect would be accurate translations of the music into the game...and it falls well short of this.

So I just got this game earlier from Redbox......  It was supposed to be a free rental and it even said $0.00 when swiping my card, but somehow charged me anyways.  So that's the first bad news....I actually had to pay $3.20 to rent this game!!  I got it because growing up Pro Skater 4 was my FAVORITE game.  I'd play every single day for hours and hours.  I had high hopes with this because it is 2016 and compared to the other games out now for Xbox One I though "omg this game is going to look AMAZING...I can almost imagine how much cool new customization modes they'll add and how awesome the graphics will look"....was I wrong.  This game is terrible.  Sure it's online multiplayer, but where's my customization and why do the characters look like it's still 2002.  I can customize my character in Sims 4 more than this!!!  I feel like it could still be good.  They need to really fix this game.  I want to make my own boards, my own characters (not just with lame presets where everyone's character will look the same).  It's 2016 now....embrace the technology you have at your fingertips and if you can't do it hire someone who can!!!!!  huge fail and DEFINITELY a missed opportunity.  2/10

NBA2K16 Online game play is the worst it has ever been. It's completely computer scripted. Too many unforced turnovers and way too many cheesers this year. There is like 4 new glitch moves that everyone uses. Most people chuck 3s all game, but for the people who like to play a Simulated game, it is wonderful until the CPU decides to make your hot team all of a sudden go ice cold and allow the other team to make a run and get back into the game and even win. The momentum factor is up way too high. Somehow a center can magically beat everyone back on the fast break for a computer block shot. It's unreal. The graphics continue to get better, but the game play gets worse and worse every season. 2K16 also changed the controls yet again, so instead of a steal button, it is now the intentional foul button and it gets in the way of your game. I give NBA 2K16 3 stars out of 5.

Well, for starters the 1st touch is a shambles for any player who isn't 80 or above, the passing is abysmal, the crossing ability is much worse, even if you do manage one, the keeper will come out so fast for a catch and/or clatter you.  
The offside rule's more tragic than ever (it's a simple rule).  
When on the back foot, defending is mostly pointless as the A.I will call your defenders from the back line up, rather than making your others bust a gut to track back. Shielding the ball has become a losing battle.
The refs also call foul on the most niggley little challenge, yet when you're smashed into from behind...Nope.
What happened to L1/Lb being 360 control/face goal?  Oh wait, now it's do silly little feints?!  Isn't that what the R-stick is for?!  I'm not ham fisted by any means but, the controls are far too finickity.
Plus, during set-plays, you get all these nonsense cuts for fake-sky ads or what not.
Not to mention they've not added any new injury-sub scenes., i.e; a player with a broken leg will walk off and tweak his ankle about... Really?!
Oh yes, how could I forget, why have they not added (for career ((which they took away from older versions)) a tactical scout for your next match?  How do I set up? who's in form? where are they're weaknesses?

Ouch.
These comments are harsh.
Thank you very much.

One of the biggest problems of the game is still present, the loot system, yes it is better than the original but you act like it is completely fixed. First place players in both the crucible and strikes can still get nothing while last place can get two legendary pieces of equipment. Also legendary gear is not dropped until level 38-40 except the one legendary you get after beating the main game. While the story is better than it first was that doesn't make it good, it's only mediocre now at best in comparison to past Bungie titles. You also have completely looked over the fact that this only expands the hive back story (barely) and deepens one of the vanguard's backgrounds (again barely) yet still hasn't addressed ANY of the other plot holes or expand any other story. Why has no reviewer said anything about the fact this is 2 years after initial release you are allowed to be overly critical of this game and you should be, over 1 billion dollars have gone into creating and fine tuning this game and yet there are still so many glaring game issues, lack luster multilayer modes, broken matchmaking for strikes, no matchmaking for raids, terrible RNG loot system, insanely large plot holes, and finally the fact that if you bought Destiny and the Taken King individually at full price you just spent $100 (in this scenario you also got the season pass) so is this really a $100 game?

Until, I had friends who were running into the same issues. Wait, I am sorry I am getting a head of myself. I love the story line even through the original story had parts that were cut. I can't speak for Naruto, but the reason I first started watching One Piece was because it was... fun. The story made no sense, the characters were stupid and over the top, and the fight scenes were often very underwhelming for all the hype - but it was fun. For the first hundred episodes or so, I often genuinely laughed at the stupid shit on screen, and the on-and-off great voice acting and writing. There was something very simple and enjoyable about the series.
Now, unfortunately, that has kind of diminished by now. Now, the show takes the story very seriously, it tries to tug at your heart string every few episodes with catastrophe after catastrophe, and everything has to raise the bar. Even with the filler, there's rarely an episode that's just fun any more - there has to be so much drama. Which isn't to say the early episodes weren't like this, but they were still funny. I stopped watching One Piece when it stopped trying to make me laugh.
I don't think One Piece transitions well to video game, since the focus on humour and really drawn out drama falls kind of flat with a controller. One Piece always hypes everything up, and there's no way a player will be able to satisfy that hype - in my experience.
I hear you. Its madness was one of the things that did bring it to my attention. I may someday go back to watch it in earnest just to see if I can get into it.

This is a frustrating review, because Sullivan, the reviewer, obviously wasn't super-familiar with DAI and didn't seem to have either finished DAI or done so with much attention to detail. It's the only way I can understand someone saying that the only satisfying decisions were those involving the aristocrats at the summit... I mean... GAH. I literally sat here wondering if she had played the same game I had.

Because the outcomes in "Trespasser" -- especially those involving Bull and Solas -- are dramatic, absolutely 100% in-character and tied to the major decisions you made in the main game. Trespasser's potential for devastating outcomes for two very popular characters should silence anyone who said our decisions in the main game didn't matter -- boy, did they, and the results can be seriously tragic (and yet also absolutely believable).

As far as loot, again, I don't know where the reviewer is coming form -- as other posters have noted, you get the superb "Skin That Stalks/Hand That Cuts/Eye That Weeps, etc." armor/equipment series if you take part in four optional tough demon miniboss battles, and the staff you pick up from beating the boss on the bridge in the mines (the Staff of Rage) is FANTASTIC. Enemies kind of just melt away, it's amazing. Best of all, if you use the Golden Nug to sync up during the game, whenever you replay DAI again in the future, most of those recipes will be available to you right at the beginning of the next playthrough.

But my biggest nitpick is that the reviewer also didn't seem to have paid attention in DAI at all -- she misspells Fen'Harel, then (worse) doesn't seem to realize WHO THAT IS despite the reveal at the end of DAI (which I have a feeling she missed), or the significance of the character, or WHY we're learning all the lore we uncover in "Trespasser."

Anyway, I'd give this review a 7 -- and Trespasser a 9. Ultimately, I loved the DLC and thought it was a love letter to fans. It provided a satisfying and powerful closure to the game before what I hope will be a new chapter in DA4. And don't miss sitting through the end credits, they'll give you a laugh when you really need one (depending on who did or didn't survive for you).

I had high expectations for this game which is why i must talk about the disappointing parts of it... because there are too many for this to be a 9/10 game. Dont get me wrong, I want this to be the perfect game but it didn't satisfy me to say the least.

1) Player Incentive: 2/10
Lets start with the worst: Way too many Money and Car Spins!
So this is supposed to be a game and I understand it should be fun for everyone... but making it so easy to jump into a Ferrari or max out your M4 within 2 hours of playing the game, really kills the thrill of slowly moving up the performance chain. I'm sure many can relate to the days where making enough money to add a new exhaust to your car and make it a little faster were epic moments. Now well... you just spin the wheel after your first win, get a million credits and crash your ferrari. The reward factor is therefore 2/10. 
I would limit the spins to 10 times less then they are now. I mean seriously I have many insane cars and 5 million credits and I havn't even played 25% of the game. Add that to the fact that I just max out a car as soon as I buy it... just kills the fun really and as a businessman, this is not getting you customers for Forza 7 I can assure you. You must create the addiction and reward is number one factor in gaming imo.

2) LapTimes: 6/10

This game is flippin' fantastic. I feel like an idiot for just now playing it (as a Mad Max fan). It's not a perfect game buts It's just a freakin' perfect Mad Max game. The look, tone, and writing is just spot on. If you're a Mad Max fan at all you really should already be playing this game. 

The only thing I would really change is more interaction and gameplay with the dog companion. I wish he was just always with you.

This is a perfect example of a "meh" game that will inspire a lot of love and a lot of hate, and I think both are valid.  It looks really nice, the car combat is fun and I'm a sucker for a visual upgrading system like the Magnum Opus, the voice acting is good and the story is decent for a Mad Max story (although whatever Paul Greengrass wannabe handled the shaky cam should be fired, especially after the beautifully center framed and steady Fury Road). But even buying it today (on PS4), there are a ton of technical issues, portions of the UI just don't like to load all the time, I encountered several invisible walls just out in the wasteland and the audio, specifically the engine noise, shifted from annoyingly loud to almost non-existent seemingly at random.  Add in some wonky enemy AI at times, a complete lack of enemy variety aside from visual (the first boss you face = functionally identical to every other boss you face), rather repetitive quests and grindy scrap gathering and a completely lack luster end game and imo you end up with at best a very average game.  Do I regret buying it?  Not at $8, but if i bought it at launch instead of MGSV like I originally intended, I would've been sorely disappointed

Been wanting to pick this one up for a long time now. Decided to play it yesterday, and I must say it's the hidden gem I've expected and felt it to be.
This review is spot on; the game perfectly captures the cold and cynical approach of the movies and the approach to storytelling is wonderfully minimalistic. Lots of stuff to do, but not too much for my taste - scavenging spots can be quickly explored and the game tells you when there's nothing more to do here, which I personally welcome since I'm actually not too much fo an open-world fan, when you feel there's infinitely exploring ahead. This game kind of limits the sandbox in the right areas for me.
Combat is bloody and brutally satisfying, and the V8 car enthusiasm should be joy in the heart of every Mad Max fan.

It looks a lot like the lighter side of the Clone Wars cartoon. Gameplay wise it is much like any sandbox game, you have main missions and lots of side quests (usually things like fetch quests or defeat X number of enemies). You fly to other planets (with some space combat thrown in) and get a bunch more quests. Combat is surprisingly good, with upgradable combos . It is simple to play but it recreates a nice Star Wars universe. The Toybox lets you download levels built by other people or build your own, so there's a lot of potential there.
It's definitely designed for children but it's a quality product. Even though it hasn't challenged me at all I've had a lot of fun exploring the worlds.

I bought Devil's Third with low expectations, but even though I already knew that there's something wrong with mainstream reviews I'm still hoping to be surprised. And boy the reviews were not accurate. One note is no one should play this game in "EASY" mode and call it a soulless piece of garbage. It's more inclined with the Ninja Gaiden series in difficulty. There are bosses (except Molotov) that can kill you instantly in one or two hits and that's playing in "STANDARD MODE". This game will definitely test your skill and patience.

The plot is like a B-movie action flick with the typical Eastern European over-the-top protagonist (Ivan) but it's very self-aware. It's like a parody of all action flicks you've ever watched. The hybrid mechanic of third person hack n' slash and first person shooter works just fine, you just need to know when to use it.

Note: If you're on "EASY" mode you can button-mash and shoot away all you like even on boss fights. It's not supposes to be played that way there are certain timing on every move/attack. Playing this game on "STANDARD" and "HARDCORE" mode is the best way in my opinion.

Like Itakagi San said, this game is not for the unskilled gamers. Its mechanics is very old-school, no healing item (auto-healing ala CoD), no extra life, skill-based in-your-face hardcore game. It's definitely a winner to me and I know there are gamers out there who likes punishing games. Graphics is not top notch but still good. I've read and watched a lot of complains about glitches which to me is very minor and I think comparing it to PS2 graphics is just plain mean. Nonetheless it's a fun romp and a very hard one. You should give it a try.

Let me start by saying Devil's Third has some addictive online multiplayer. Yes, the game looks like a last gen game. Yes, it's cheesy and fun violence. And yes it's not perfect. I enjoyed the single player campaign (expectations were not high) and let me start by saying that what Devil's Third does, it does well. It's not perfect and not a big AAA game like Call of Duty. But the online multiplayer is where the game shines so it is too unfortunate that the online multiplayer is what barely any reviews talk about. If this game looked like a current gen game, it would have won critics over. When you play the online multiplayer, there is nothing like shooting at someone up close and then beating them up (with swords, kicks, or punches) a second later. The whole shooter/melee mix works well and the maps allow for a lot to go on in the 16 player multiplayer. The online multiplayer is just as addictive as Call of Duty but it reminds me a lot of the online multiplayer in The Last of Us. The game is more like an 8/10 and I challenge Wii U owners to give it a try. I pre-ordered my copy from Best Buy.

I hope that Jared didn't take off review points because it doesn't have a "rewind" feature like Rare Replay. Because in all actuality it sort of does. On my 3DS version if you hit the right bumper it brings up an options screen. On that screen you can create a save state anywhere you are in the game. You can also load that save state anytime you wish taking you back to where you saved. So if you are doing great and save the game only to get wrecked shortly after all you have to do is hit load and boom, you're right back where you were sitting pretty again before your snafu. Yeah it can break the game if you're saving/loading every 5 seconds, but for some people it may be the only way to make it through the game their first time playing. Had I not done this in Mega Man 3 while having to fight all the MM2 bosses I would have been destroyed. Good thing for second, third, and even 23rd chances to fight the same boss!

This was the first Metal Gear Solid game I ever played, so I cannot compare it with previous titles. MGSV is one of the most amazing games I ever played, period. The open world is beautiful and athmospheric, the gameplay is perfect, the graphic are amazing, the story is surprising and captivating, and the soundtrack is awesome. The quantity of vehicles, weapons, tactics and customization is just staggering (you can build a zoo in the motherbase, and that says it all).
People have different approaches towards what a videogame should be. To me, perfect gameplay only becomes relevant when in the context of a story that I identify with, that I personally want to experience, and this is such a case. The plot kept me constantly surprised (the end is mind-blowing) and has a lot of creative and deep concepts such as the importance of language as a weapon or the relations between humanity and parasitic organisms. It also has a lot of emotional content, if one is not interested simply in killing stuff and getting loot. For me, videogames are a tremendous medium of communication, and this is an amazing example of gameplay, emotion and narrative. Quiet is an amazing character (definitely second only to Big Boss himself in the game) and her story and relation to the protagonist are also amazing, independently of the cristicism that her outfit and depiction received (some of it deserved). 
For first-timers to the the MGS franchise, what actually happens during gameplay is complemented by the numerous tapes you can listen to, and that gave me a lot of context about the universe. I finished nearly every main mission and a lot of the side-ops. I did not finish all main missions because I was playing on PS3, and in the meanwhile bought the definitive edition (including MGS:Ground Zeroes) for PS4. In the future, I definitely plan on replaying everything and finishing all main missions.

Massive MGS fan. I bought the original game on import when it was first launched on the PS.
Having played all the games over and over again and MGS4 being my personal fave, I have to say that I am disappointed with MGSV.
There are lots of excellent things about this game, the graphics are technically incredible, the stealth is up there with the best but I just cannot stand these farking sandbox games.
The game in a nutshell is just too boring, there are only so many times that you can save a wondering soldier or clear a mind field or go back to one of the key bases and rescue someone over and over again. It becomes tedious and a chure playing the game.
I've had this game since launch and just going back to it to finally complete it so I can sell it.
For a sandbox game to work - I have to feel the need to explore ad get engrossed in the world.
I've recently finished ZBOTW - this has no real story but the WORLD climbs the highest skyscraper and dumps all over MGSV - I couldn't put the game down because it was that awesome.
I much prefer the linear, story driven, action adventure, kick arse bosses in the old MGS games.
There are far better Sandbox games on the market (if that's what you like) but don't expect a gripping story line with this game and to be engrossed like the other games.

I've just discovered this game. I love it. I've finished it and I'm still thinking about it. It's the most beautiful game place I've seen. I love this type of game and it is for a particular type of player. I continue to go back into the game on a daily basis and walk around. It's very relaxing.

The voice acting is good as well. I enjoyed games such as The Vanishing of Ethan Carter and Firewatch but honestly, I found this a little too boring and lacking in things to do. The slow movement is okay since I know they want gamers to take notice of the environment and appreciate it in all its glory. However it does become tiresome after a while. The main frustration for me though is there isn't actually anything of any substance to do. The game probably would have benefitted from having puzzles and more of a mystery to solve element. I have mixed feelings about this game. On the one hand I really appreciated the design, both visuals and sounds. I loved the atmosphere and the way the story unfolded. On the other hand, I found it a real grind once the novelty had worn off. Yes, there was a sprint feature implemented, but it's not near fast enough. The slow pace might be realistic but that doesn't make it better.

I suppose the best verdict I can offer is this: I'm glad I played it, but I'm also glad I didn't pay for it (got it free on PS+).

One other little thing that wound me up was the accents of the villagers. I heard west country, home counties, welsh and even a scouser - all in a game set in rural Shropshire! Surely it couldn't have been to difficult to have all the voice actors affect a local accent? It didn't affect the experience, but it was an avoidable and unnecessary flaw.

I just finished the game and I thought it was pretty good. I don't remember what I paid for it, but I would say that $4.99 would be the sweet spot. They're right that you can't die and your brother can't die either, no matter how long you wander around (so it's not like Dead Rising 2 where you're forced to keep coming back). I personally liked the relaxing atmosphere and the no-pressure wandering. I also liked trying to find the story clues and deciphering the pictures. It's a nice break for when you really are just trying to sit back and relax with a no-stress game. Definitely not going to be for everyone, but it's not a terrible game for those that can get passed the lack of violence, action or even a forced pace of any kind.

Kind of disappointed in this review.  I think it was completely necessary to reset the timeline shortly after the beginning of this episode.  I've spent several hours playing this game, learning about characters, and working through mysterious events.  Drastically changing the timeline means all of that was for nothing.  I don't believe it was cowardly at all, I believe it was essential, and I think they did it beautifully.  I also disagree with the "shock value" comment.  This is a game about making choices.  Some choice options may have similar/identical outcomes, but more often than not as the player you have a decent bit of control over how Max behaves.  Not to mention this character is going through a long series of traumatic and transformative events.  This is the shit that causes people to change, and act differently.  I do agree that it got a little slow at some points, but not really that much.  And the evidence thing was not difficult.  I am by no means some "super smart human guy" and I completed that bit in a matter of minutes (probably between 7 and 11 of them) at 4am as my eyeballs burned from overuse and sleep deprivation was setting in.  There may have been a degree of tedium in there, but hey, at least they took the time to flesh out some actual facts and have you do the work to get there.  You are entitled to your opinion, Mitch Dyer.  But I disagree with it at pretty much every turn.  Maybe if you provide more specific examples supporting your assertions, I would be able to understand how your perspective was shaped. But since I can't, I guess I'll have to assume that you sir, are just "hella cray."

Oh, and as others have pointed out: you can click on the evidence while piecing the clues together in Chloe's room. You should be embarrassed that you didn't know that.

Here's the thing: if you're afraid to say what you think because you're worried people will disagree, you're not reviewing honestly. You're just saying what you think people will want to hear. And considering that a lot of people are going to yell at us whatever we say about a highly publicized game (that's a given when we have as large and diverse an audience as IGN does) we believe strongly in saying what we really think.

I don't disagree with anything you just said, but you completely changed the topic away from what we were talking about. I know you stand by your score as you are the Editor. I still think your site over-scored the game secondary to the hype surrounding it or Ryan's passion for Halo. Regardless, it is okay to disagree, I am not trying to attack anyone, just expressing my opinion as it differed from your original comment.

Standardization is impossible to do when it comes to scoring works of art. The closest thing you can do is to have one single reviewer, with the standard being his or her personal taste, but of course there are far, far more games out there than can be reviewed by one person, and that one person couldn't become knowledgeable enough about the huge range of genres out there to give an informed opinion on them all.
So you have to have multiple people to evaluate even a respectable fraction of the games that come out every month, and because each of those people is a human being with their own ideas about what makes a game good or bad, and because you cannot quantify "fun" in a way that's consistent from person to person it's not possible to have a uniform "standard" across multiple reviewers. I know it seems like it should be, but trust me: as someone who's spent the past decade-plus working in game reviews and banging my head against the same problem as every entertainment reviewer who's come before me since the invention of the printing press, I assure you it's not.

1. Look at the big picture and stop crying over the details. If an aircraft mechanic tells you there's something wrong with a plane, and a 14 year old child tells you there isn't; who are you going to believe? Obviously the person with credentials and weight behind his opinion. You have weight behind your opinion. Now please stop discrediting yourself.
2. "It never told me I could run past enemies". Are you kidding me??? Does your mother still make "Chu chu" noises with a spoon to feed you cereal? Hopefully not. If she does then your statement is a little more understandable. You would think someone who reviews modern games would understand them a little better. If someone came at you with a sword in real life, there would be at least three basic thoughts in your head; fight back, dodge or run. Games in the Soul's series respect the gamers knowledge, unlike 90% of modern gaming that will have 30 minute tutorials to show you how to walk, etc.
Since you're so enlightened by "facts", here's one: If you do not have the basic gaming knowledge or skills to push buttons and learn how to do things, or lack the thought process to think of solutions to problems games will inevitably throw at you, then you should be ashamed to call yourself a video game reviewer.

1. My point stated all reviews are opinions; All professional opinions are reviews. You are a professional. It was a review. End of story.
2. Your article was a first impression; correct. But many of the things you were stating as "facts" were not. When something is a fact, it is 100% correct. But the things you were talking about in the article were completely untrue. Do you not think your own word carries any weight? Apparently not.

1: Your point is factually false. Someone being paid to render an opinion does not make that opinion inherently better or different than an unpaid opinion - it simply means that the person being paid probably does this kind of thing a lot, and does it well enough that they've been able to find someone to pay them to do it. That is the only distinction. You can look this up in the dictionary, where you'll find no "Unless that person is a professional" caveats under the definitions of "review" or "opinion." But if you feel that way and are unwilling to accept dictionary definitions of words, then okay. Just be aware that your ideas about this concept exist only in your head, and other people will not know what you're talking about.
2: My article explained my experience with the game, as I understood it. It was, as it was headlined, the story of how Bloodborne lost me; if Bloodborne had done a better job of introducing me to its systems, my knowledge and impressions of it would have been different. It never told me I could run past enemies, for example. Souls fans know this from previous games, but I had no way of knowing enemies are designed to be so stupid and gave them the benefit of the doubt. Having only the information it was willing to give me, that was how I saw it, and that's why I stopped playing.

Yes, but they are not synonyms. All reviews are opinions; all opinions are not reviews.
Around here, a review is something written by someone with experience in a game's genre after they've played through the entirety (or as much as is reasonable) of its content. Generally, it is scored. This, by contrast, was an unscored first impression piece by someone new to the genre.

It’s reviewers like this that really make you question your own version of reality. Hey look, there’s nothing wrong with having an opinion, we’re all entitled to our own and invariably they will differ. That’s not the issue. It’s that somehow, annoyingly, those with a marginal opinion end up with the largest platform and say things that piss many of us off. Remaster or not, God of War III was in many respects a masterpiece. It re-wrote the rule book in terms of digital game art and for what could be eeked out of the PS3. It was epic in almost every regard, and the storyline? The storyline was simply incredible; a true crescendo for the trilogy. It was fearless, bold and inventive, a sick twisted Kratos-centric bloody fantasy which saw our protagonist destroy all we know of established Greek mythology. The brutal, merciless and systematic slaughter of the Gods of Olympus, ending with the death of Zeus by Kratos’ hands (your own) was quite simply a phenomenal concept. The gravity of which is lost on those that don’t, or can’t, see it in context. Where in the history of storytelling does one murder the Gods; not one but all of them, in succession – beat their faces into the ground? It’s an incredibly original and innovative narrative.And now this narrative exists, and only for Kratos the God of War. It sets the scene for using other defunct religions as further God of War landscapes, as is now the case with God of War IV and Odin, with the Norse backdrop. If God of War III was a movie I’d be glued to the screen, if it was a book it’d be gripping, I wouldn’t be able to put it down - but it’s better than that. It’s a game so you become it. And that’s my gripe with this review. Meghan called the story ‘ Meh’! That’s right ‘Meh’! Meh? Wow!! Look, have an opinion but don’t just blast off like that! It’s possible that you didn’t get it and it just went way over your head! And you know, perhaps what’s required to truly appreciate the masterpiece that is and was God of War III is the savagery, barbarity and boldness within that connects to the player. Some balls one might say! Try as we might, some of us will always fall short in that regard.

"Good"? This game is a masterpiece. The atmosphere, the graphics, the combat system. 
I've played over 80 hours of DmC Devil May Cry and even though it's pretty enjoyable while easy, I feel much more challenged in Devil May Cry 4. 
This game resembles a far more solid experience of Devil May Cry. Enemies have natural movement and unpredictable attacks. This makes the game much more interesting. On DmC5 (let's just call it that) the lesser demons are far too easy to fight against with their slow, repetitive and easy to dodge attacks. 
I have 40 hours of gameplay on DMC4 and I still haven't mastered Nero's Exceed system which is one of the coolest features in the entire franchise. The Bloody Palace mode on DmC is much easier and repetitive. It gets challenging at around level 80.

Every game has an impact on a person's life. I felt a much greater impact from DMC4 rather than DMC5 even though I played it a few days after its release not knowing anything about the rest of the franchise. Playing DMC5 first helped me see it as a standalone game and not part of a series. My overall experience in DMC5 was just fine. I did not have any experience with DMC. After playing both games, I concluded that DMC4 offers a better experience than DMC5. It's really a complicated matter and you have to take many things into account. Combat in DMC5 is different. Everything has become easier. You can flash to an enemy or bring them to you, you can evade at any given moment and the enemies' attacks are slow and very predictable. Parrying has also been added. You can stun an enemy by timing your attack to theirs, even redirect enemy projectiles. These are some nice additions. After I was introduced to Exceed in DMC4, all these attacks felt empty. Too simple. There are obviously less moves in DMC5. Dante is a simple killing machine with a limited number of attacks, still deadly and handy enough to dominate his enemies. But that's just it. The game should have been all about style. Killing enemies without getting hit and using a variety of combos while avoiding the use of a same attack twice. This is entirely possible on DMC4 but not on DMC5. The combos of the Red Queen in DMC4 are stylish and very adaptive. It has more combos than the Rebellion in DMC5. DMC5 forces you to use the same attack more than twice in some situations where brute force is required. Like the stupid Rages or the bosses. When you have a giant ape with a knife, you just go into his face and spam rebellion. The Axe has no aerial combo and the Fists have only one aerial attack. The Osiris and the Aquilla are practically useless due to their very low damage and minimal impact attacks.
The actual difference in these two games for me, is the atmosphere. That is what makes DMC4 an amazing game. It's the kind of game that draws you into its world. DMC5 did not give me that feeling. Just raw action.

I'm with most of the commenters here (and less with the reviewer)- this is a great, underrated game.  The details alone are worth the price of admission, like when the "chicken egg" boss recovers from a hit and his pants knit back together as he returns to the foreground.  The game looks like nothing else I've ever played and in this "seen it all" era, that's saying something.

Anyone who finishes the game in eight hours didn't take their time and I guess that's fine if you want to see the ending and say you merely finished the game.  My wife and I spent a few hours on the game to get through everything and have now spent about three times as many hours going back to all the levels to collect everything.  This is important because finding all the flowers means unlocking extra levels that are oftentimes a lot of fun.

If you like 2D games, Mario games, etc., this is one not to miss.  Especially for those who think the Wii U is a disappointment because it has few great titles.  Guess what?  This is a great title.

So I took a while to buy this game after reading the mediocre reviews.

I should NOT have waited so long. It's great! I make sure to collect all of the wool and flowers before moving on to the next level (which unlock Yoshis and bonus worlds respectively). Doing this keeps the game really fun. I usually only have to play through a level once or twice to find everything as I take my time going through.

There are more than a few great levels. I think most of them are pretty good, and some really shine. The first world is weak (especially the first few levels), but it seems to get progressively better in each world. Make sure to get all of the flowers as the special levels are the game's highlights. 

I can understand if you just go from one level to the next finding this game a little boring, but if you take the time to look around and collect the wool and stars, it's a rewarding game. It also has all kinds of clever uses for yarn and looks incredible. My only gripe is there is absolutely no story or dynamism in the overworld at all, like even worse than Mario which usually has some cut-scenes, and events to keep things exciting after clearing a world...

Overall it's a [8.5-9.0]/10 IMO.

i had to write a video game review for school and i cant find anywhere to post it besides here so

Batman Arkham Knight brings an exciting Franchise series to an end. In Batman Arkham Knight you find yourself in an abandoned Gotham City only filled with rioting thugs and supervillains. As you fight your way through Gotham you will face challenging foes and battles.


The game has stunning graphics while sounding phenomenal and introduces the well-known batmobile as a key component to saving Gotham city. You fight alongside Catwoman and Poison Ivy but also your trusty sidekicks Robin and Nightwing enabling a team up element to the game bringing down sinister villains such as the Riddler,Scarecrow and even Penguin while adding mind blowing combat move mechanics.This is only a fragment of what you can do in this game, you will find yourself in situations and sequences that will add much more depth to batman Arkham Knight.


The gadgets are another key element which are quite amusing to use while also being handy in the game. In the game your opponents try to come up with many ways to stop you in your quest to save Gotham, batman however has many tricks up his sleeve to bypass such trojan horses and be badass while doing so. Some gadgets can manipulate your enemies into the palm of your hand while others can pretty much render their weapons useless to a strategic attack, the controls are standard and if desired can be changed.

Really, an 8? I played this up until level 23 and I got bored, none of the main questline was fun or memorable for me; if I didn t have any context as to what was going on I would have thought they were side quests. Also the first dungeon I played was also very boring, there are multiple roles that the game assigns you to, tank, dps, and Healer. In the end none of the roles mattered since every enemy and boss was just a blade sponge in a different skin. Then there is the matter of weapons and gear. NO DIVERSITY! All the lower level weapons look the same, I couldn't find any in quests or drops that looked different or had some special ability, I grind a get the same sword with more damage, same goes for armor (although it is a little better) The combat feels fun up to level 10 when constantly button mashing gets boring and dull, which brings me to the skills, classes, and races. All races have ceartain specialties and skills so do classes (there only three by the way) making it very hard to enjoy playing when your race basically decides which class you should be. Example: Kahjitts are good for making a stealthy thief build so the skills are based around it are for stealth, there is only one class that encourages stealth combat which is the Nightblade class. So what happens when I want to be a warrior and a cat person? I get a mix of different skills that don't compliment each other at all, you end up using only one side of the skills instead of all of them. The graphics are terrible for a modern game, that's definitely not a big one considering everything else but it's still a problem. Last but not least this doesn't even feel close to an ES game. The big thing with ES games is the world building that happens and revolves around you. Apparently nobody wanted to put work into that so we are stuck with a faux Elder Scrolls mmo. I wanted to like this so bad I pushed myself to play it, I love Skyrim and Fallout 4 so when an mmo made by the same company set in the Es universe is realeased I buy it. 60 dollars and no enjoyment later I pm writing this to warn you. Unless you really really think you will like this DONT BUY IT especially not for full price. Also disclaimer I don't care if you like the game or not this is my opinion, you have yours I have mine and we can both respect that. Score 5/10

Not saying you're wrong and you are right everyone has their own opinion but keep in mind this is a MMORPG, if you have played other MMORPGs then you should understand why this game is not like the other Elder Scrolls franchise , all the other Elder Scrolls games are not multiplayer. Hey everybody,
We're trying something out here as an experiment. Normally, when we write a review and score a game, that's more or less set in stone. But today, Jose has updated his Splatoon review and score to reflect what he sees as major, game-changing updates to the experience you get when you buy this game. It's something we'd like to do here and there when games we feel strongly about improve or degrade over time due to major updates or changes.

Here's more on how we handle re-reviews: http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/02/13/igns-re-review-policy

@kidlickurmom420blaze @Arumat No biggie, It's just a crap review honestly, the way he wrote It made him sound like a whiny bitch, that the game was to hard for him so he rage quit and gave the game a 5. If you look at every other score It's all 8s and higher.

@Arumat @kidlickurmom420blaze Hey man -- don't misrepresent the contents of the review this way. He didn't quit four hours in. He explicitly stated in the opening that he spent 20 hours -- right in the opening paragraph. He finished the game before reviewing it (on Hard). 

But I wanted to address your original comment: why did Splatoon get a re-review. Re-reviews aren't done to give a different opinion on the same game. They're done to re-evaluate a game that has changed over time. Splatoon launched with a limited number of maps and features -- more were added over time. Thus, the game on launch day was different than what it is now. Hence: a good game to do a re-review. Alien Isolation hasn't changed -- you're disagreeing with the score, and that's fine. Everyone has their own opinion. But the reviewer's opinion hasn't changed and the game thus doesn't warrant another take. We've discussed the game in other media, though, including our podcasts -- thus, if you want other opinions, you can find them, too.

The best game I've ever played. I'm on my fifth play through now and yesterday picked up a quest I'd never done before in Novigrad.
CDPR really showed everyone else how to make a single player RPG. The depth to the combat style (although wish the boss fights could have had more variety with how to kill them a la Dark Souls), the incredible graphics, the amazing, thoughtful choices in the dialogue wheel, the fantastic stories (some of the side stories can leave a lasting impression (e.g. woman who loves her werewolf  brother-in-law)), the random scenes around the world where there isn't even a quest, but you just have to figure out what's happened by looking at the clues around you (or there probably is a quest and I just haven't found it...) and best of all, the rich, appealing characters. I genuinely fell in love with this world.
Apparently, it took up to 250 staff three and a half years to make this game, plus over a thousand extra people to support. That's insane. But kudos to them because I've never played anything as good as it. And I say that having spent 7 years on Wow, countless replays of the Half-Life series, and God knows how many plays of Uncharted 2.

People that say the game is boring and repetitive... Most of that seems to come from people that can't be bothered to read the books/quest info/glossaries. It's tedious to do in most games, but in this... there are so many great stories. Everything is so well thought out.

I thought this Remaster was a huge upgrade to the original PS2 version (which is the only version prior to this I had played) and was a welcome walk down memory lane into one of FF's more touching titles. FFX has always had this depressing effect on me but it an ok way, it is just the amazing music blending in with the lovable characters and the feeling that something bad is going to happen to one of your beloved heroes.... Its a powerful feeling. The music is without a doubt top notch and manages to capture the moments both happy and sad (especially sad) and really make players feel the drama. FFX was also the 1st FF to have character dialogue and is looked upon by most as a milestone in FF history. And it surprised me just how attached I could get on my 2nd play through. It brought me back years so long ago, when I was playing FFX on my PS2 when life was easy and carefree!! FFX-2 is an awesome game in its own right but doesn't hold a light to FFX as X-2 comes off as a far less serious and playful version of FFX. There is literally SO much content in between FFX & FFX-2 and its all on one disc now, INCLUDING a brand new soundtrack that you have the option of hearing while you play with never before seen DLC (trailers) and the content is surprisingly good. To be so little of it, it is very informative and answered some of the questions I had before. It is such a great deal for this HD Remaster for $40.00 or however much you end up paying, its well worth it. There is over 100 hours of content in between the 2 (actually if your like me well more than that) but I recommend this to anyone who likes Final Fantasy of course, but also to fans who have played the older version. The graphic enhncements are stunning and are easily noted. Also, ANY fan of RPG who doesn't own this should get it now. Beautful story, amazing music, heartfelt characters & a sad life of the people of Spira. Its well worth it!!

This is an old post that I'm responding to. I get that. But anyways...
OrangeCrush specifically said they weren't in favor of censorship, only that gratuitous violence like seen here gives games a bad name. You're suggesting a solution to an extreme they never proposed in the first place. And to accept a medium as an artform isn't to give every entry into the medium a free pass as genuine art.
For example, a person could argue that a snuff film has as much right to exist artistically as any art house flick that explores really dark places in the human psyche. Technically, that's true. In practice however, one explores the underlying issues while the other offers no commentary, only shock value (but without the redeeming values true artists implant in shocking imagery). Yeah, they both have a right to exist. But, as OrangeCrush already stated, one gives the medium a bad name because it exploits the bad with no exploration of what it means. Should it be censored? Maybe, maybe not. Should it be called out for what it is? I think the answer is still not definite, but it definitely seems like more of a yes to me.

I bought this game at launch because I read somewhere that it was a more accessible DS game.  Having played Demon, DS and DS2, and not fairing well, I wanted to try it out.  Initially the game proved to be a bit too difficult, so I shelved it.  Fast forward two years when Nioh comes out, and after doing very well in that game I decide to dust off BB and give it another go, being that the combat felt very similar.  Now I'm two bosses away from the true ending, and have completed all of the depth 3 chalice dungeons.  How this game got a 9.1 and not a perfect score is amazing.  It's as close to a flawless game as it gets in my eyes.  Besides Nioh, it's the only game I can think of that I'll be playing well past NG.

@SneakyDex @AbstractWonder Yeah, I saw The Fire Fades edition on sale and scooped it up.  I read somewhere that it is roughly the same as BB, difficulty wise.  That'll be next once I get through the DLC bosses and then close out the last two of the main story.  Plus I need to eventually kill Yharnam for the Plat trophy.  I played to the first boss in DS3 and I'm finding that parrying is a bit more difficult than BB.  I think I prefer the gun over a shield.  Can't wait to dive in further though.  That first boss is the quickest I've ever beat a boss in DS, only died once.

@SneakyDex @AbstractWonder Also, Ludwig humbled me.  I was flying high after beating Mergo's Wet Nurse and went from her to DLC.  Died about 6 times to Ludwig before rage quitting and jumping back into Ailing Loran to farm some levels (where Blood-Starved Beast humbled me further).
199 thousand comments!!! What in the actual fuck? This game is a masterpiece and if it was ever released on PC I would die of happiness again. and again. and again.

Being a fan of the Souls series I naturally picked this game up a few months after it was out. At first grind I didn't like it and couldn't get used to the battle mechanics of the game i.e. pace, no shields, limited weapons and sorceries etc.
I pressed on and got frustrated with Martyr Logarius and by then Dark Souls 3 was coming out.
I ditched Bloodborne for DS3 which then that sucked over a year of my life---totally worth it---however now after playing DS3 and seeing the new weapon arts as well as reading up on some Bloodborne builds, I figured out what I was doing wrong reanalyzed my strategy and I fired up the game starting brand new.
Best decision ever not to give up on this masterpiece. Approaching it with a new perspective and a build that I can enjoy in the game and not feel like I'm painfully grinding away.
I think my fault before was that I was trying to play it exactly like a DS game and it's an entirely different beast (pun intended).
Additionally before I was going more for a strength/arcane build and stupid me I wasn't even using a strength based weapon (cane) but couldn't figure why I was hitting so weak when my stats were strength and arcane. I figured how the gems work and function better and what to place my efforts on. Overall this is a phenomenal game and deserves the praise it has.

This game is so difficult yet so fair, because you're often your own undoing. The progress in discovery is so rewarding that although the game allows the player to turn back and use their Blood Echoes, it's often too tempting to get a step ahead and getting one more kill towards the next checkpoint. That often results in death and loss of progress but the satisfaction of getting it done is loke nothing else.
PIcked this up for $7.99 PSN sale having never played a Souls game before. Great fun, challenging...reminds me of an old school game with modern graphics.

My feelings exactly.

"Dissappointed my SSB amiibo's will have their data deleted if I choose to use them with MP10."

Not true. Using my Rosalina with Smash data, I could still select the Rosalina board at the start of the game, and I could still collect and use tokens during. The only things I could not do were customize the base of the amiibo (the bases you collect are saved to the amiibo), and select a token to start the game with (found tokens behave the same way as found bases).

It's better to play with an amiibo with no Smash data, since some of the tokens you find (and are saved) allow you to use different boards without having that board's amiibo, but you definitely don't have to delete your Smash data if you don't want to. :)

I consider myself to be one of the harshest game crititcs out there and I give this game a 10/10. Typically this type of game will have you just find your favorite weapon and setup. Then you stick with that for the rest of the game.     This is where Helldivers is truely a masterpiece.   A favorite setup might be really good against one type of enemy.   You can one shot those aliens no problem at all!   Then you go to a different planet where the aliens have shields.   All of the sudden that rocket 1 shot now requires 2 shots.   One shot to get rid of the shield.    This is one of the many examples of how you have to adapt to your enemies.    One amazing setup might not work against something else, which forces you to adapt.   There is also TONS of different equipment to choose from..... The developers really thought this game out and it really shows.    I only have given 2 other games 10/10 ratings so this should really show how impressed I am.    This game can be played by yourself, but this game isn't experienced in it's fullest unless you have some other people to play with!

yep got this on ps plus, im lucky enough to own a xbox one aswell and although the freebies on xbox always tick better quality boxes sony nailed it this month with this game its a gem.
at first i thought what most of us probably thought, that being its just a generic shooter with fairly poor graphics, typical freebie indy stuff but i gave it an hour to win me over. once you start laying down tactical weaponry and figuring out numerous ways to protect or accomplish your mission its becomes a thrill. then my 4 year old son picked up a pad and jumped right in by my side protecting my backside and occasionally shooting me down in the excitement of war and it was hilarious, thrilling and we high fived like a real team at the end of a mission. although its not for children its nothing to graphic and it is too complicated to play tactically for younger players so while the kid has my back ill lay down the backup weaponry etc and its still a riot to play.
i remember playing streets of rage etc with my father and i have a feeling this game will be remembered by my son as he gets older and thats the real test for a co op adventure with family and friends.

Dragon ball xenoverse 2 is the worst game invented in dragon ball history, i loved the idea of playing xenoverse 1 when it came out because it gave you the opportunity to fight alongside goku & the other z warriors, & also create your own character, perfect sounding game right? so i bought it, played it, loved the story, then i got more into it and started playing player matches, endless battles, and mostly ranked matches, and became very high up on the score boards. THE absolute main reason i loved this game is because of the combat, the fact that you had to be patient and watch your opponents move, perfect block it, take your time, make them look like their week even tho their trying so hard. It was an absolutely great game especially for that reason, now on to the reason that xenoverse 2 is so not worth your time or money, in xenoverse 2, 90 percent of the same idea of xenoverse 1 is duplicated in xenoverse 2, the story mode is almost identical which is repetitive and very boring, #2 xenoverse 2 combat style smh, & i cant stress this enough, the combat style has been brought down to a mediocre level, its straight up attack as fast as you can and break guards, and blast blast ki blast and die, especially with the added flight attacks that are almost impossible to block, its such a downgrade, its no longer fun, its becoming like one of those games that someone with no knowledge of games can just press buttons on and win the battle, i would never give this game a 7.5 star rating, especially compared to xenoverse 1, xenoverse 2 deserves a 2 star rating and thats being generous, i would of hoped for a xenoverse 3 but after seeing xenoverse 2 i can only imagine what else will be ruined, & dont get me wrong im a huge dragon ball z fan so you gotta understand my frustration, theres much more on this topic that i didnt even get into, but ill just leave it at that, ill just stick to watching the dragon ball super series, & i also have a few complaints about that too, i dont want to see anymore side episodes, i dont watch dbz to see them play baseball or be corny, i love the action and villains the brutal fights, but thats for another day, i know im not the only one that feels this way about this topic & if not lets see if we can make a change, peace

To be honest- I almost felt the same as the reviewer in the first 2 hours of play.... But then you unlock more moves and learn how to combine more varied combos/attack options. Then I really became impressed! The combat is awesome but it is very difficult to become great at it instantaneously. The great thing is that the game is still enjoyable even if you never even tap into all that you can do in a fight. I was sold when I finally strung together a rush attack mid convo with a dazzling blast ending! It looked amazing and felt even better. Extra points for being accessible to my 7 year old son- the basic controls are very easy and straightforward so I don't think the reviewer ever really got into more technical fighting. It's like any rpg- yes you can spam your preferred strategy and beat the game. But it's more satisfying and enjoyable when you properly use a mix or status, magic, attacks and summons not just one emphasis. This is similar. But wow- the story and environment created to not just rehash the anime for the 100th is greatly appreciated. As others say, any fan of dbz needs this game.

Probably the thing that surprised me most about this game was how interesting the mini-'quests' often were. Many of the cards you play to win tokens will unlock a next level card which will play out as its own little story. It's very well done.
The script and narration is also top notch. It has a stylized quality that, whilst different in theme, reminds me a lot of Darkest Dungeon; another very well written, rather unusual 'dungeon crawler' that released this year (albeit in early access).
The other particularly awesome thing is that there is a spider that occasional appears and scuttles around when on the table screen. That isn't the awesome part; the awesome part is that there is an option to remove the spider in the menu. And I find this compelling game of semi-controlled chance stressful enough as it is without that thing crawling around.

I'm not sure how you can say that the pacing is sluggish when the whole story and gameplay is barely 8 hours, to me that makes zero sense, and I certainly never felt like I was getting bored. I bought The Order 1886 based purely on watching a 3 minute video of the gameplay and being hugely impressed by the graphics, which is something I never do, I also didn't look at any reviews and went in without knowing exactly what the game was about and I have to say I was very pleasantly surprised.

It definitely deserves more than a 6.5 purely for how amazing the graphics, atmosphere and setting are, this is what the next gen should look like. I actually thought the story and character development were pretty good too, and I even found myself growing quite attached to the characters, a lot more so than I do in most other games definitely. Sure, it is let down by its behind the times mechanics and short play time, but this just left me wanting more, and the story was conveniently stopped at such a point that it is obviously wide open for a sequel, with many questions still unanswered.

The Order 1887 anyone?

@Christian.J.Williams Critics didn't sink the game, Ready At Dawn did.  Critics simply accuratley reported on what an inconsequential game this is.  Ready At Dawn released an incredibly pretty game with almost no gameplay and an unfinished storyline. Half the game was cut scenes, another 1/4 of it QTE's, and what was left was such a handheld, on-rails experience that is was as limiting as it was enjoyable.  So much promise, but the failure to develop that promise lies firmly in Ready At Dawn's lap.  It plays more like a demo than a full game, and one that never really lets you cut loose and explore or enjoy its game world at that.  2/5 stars for me.

What's great about this game is that it keeps you challenged even as you max out your levels.  Once you make out all your upgrade you unlock "legend" which now allows you to add small percentage boosts to different catagories (one-handed weapon stregth, health, etc).  So you are always improving.  Also the enemies are diverse and increase in health and stregth.  Single zombies that might of been a challenge and are now one-hit kills begin to appear in large groups.  Specialty zombie appear more and mix in with the zombies.  Some move fast, some are strong, some you can't hide from.  And no matter how over powered I become I still never get over the fear of playing during the night (in game).  The volatile monsters all almost invincible even with the strongest weapons in the game at max strength.The added parkor is a great addition and makes sense quickly with why the jump button is on the sholder button.  You need to be able to look at where you want to grab onto while you jump and allows you to always kkeep both thiumbs on the joysticks.  It is really a well done game.  Very immersive and intense.
Gonna buy this for 20$instead of the 45$ the following edition.Guess is more value for the money,rather buy other game with the diference

PT. 2 - What your survivor level enables you to get is higher damage weapons. This is CRITICAL for the gameplay. With high damage weapons, you can slash your way through the zombie hordes and enjoy the gameplay to the max. Until you get past level 10 for survivor, the gameplay will be frustrating, you WILL die a lot if you get zombies on your tail, and you will not be able to kill zombies very easily. Grapple comes soon after that, and the game just gets better and better.
This game is one of the best I’ve ever played; I give it a 9.5/10 just for how much satisfaction it gives me. Just remember, don’t get frustrated, once you get your survivor ranking up, the gameplay gets exponentially better!

Dying Light is one of those games where you don’t want to stop playing and enjoy every time you start playing. The combat is superb and exiting, the parkour is outstanding, and the story gives you plenty of things to do when you want a mission of some sort. True, the story isn’t “amazing” but it’s certainly not terrible. The side quests are better than some of the story missions, and reward you well for your time. For the new people to the game, you will need to either farm or dump a bunch of time into the game until you get your survivor level ranked up to a decent amount, (17-20). You can do this easily by taking a few hours and simple repeating certain replayable quests to gain the supply packages you need to exchange for points to level up. While this took me 3 hours to get from level 3 to 25 (max), it’s definitely worth it. “The Stuffed Turtle” is the name of the quarantine zone I used to gain supply packages, just keep redoing it over and over until you get 160-170 packages, and then go and exchange them, and prepare for the fun.
story is good. it has it's flaws but it's not bad or "so-so"

Coming off of Fallout 4 and the Order 1886, I think this game is mediocre at best. The game is just frustrating. In the mission where you have to turn on the gas valves, one of them was so annoying to reach, I ran in a giant circle around the whole area, bumping into invisible walls and reaching for platforms/rocks that were blocked by invisible barriers. Time after time, certain zombie types pop out of no where and instantly kill you. Parkour isn't as clumsy as Assassin's creed, but I still fell off of buildings and structures a decent amount. It wouldn't be so bad if you didn't actually lose XP when you die. For a game that is supposed to encourage exploration, that's not exactly an encouraging mechanic. Combat is clunky and repetitive and not fun. Idk how this review exists or why Colin Moriarty raves about this so much. A part of me still wants to hold out for a couple of more levels for the grappling hook to see how I feel then, but at this point I'm turned off enough to be done.
@supatastywaffles If you haven't gotten the grappling hook yet, you haven't really played this game, Stick with it and you will not regret it. It's one of my favorite games of the year.

Threes!: Nine tips, hints and cheats (pt. 1)
1. Work the corners
While some folks prefer to play the center, the most widely accepted method of doing well in Threes! is to get your high-scoring cards in one of the corner and perpetually move cards in that direction. This means most of your gameplay will only involve moving in two directions. With the highest-scored tile right in the corner, it minimizes how much chasing you have to do to match it up. Besides, there aren’t going to be many cards to pair up with your top one, so a central, easily-accessible location is better served by lower-value cards. With other high-value cards drifting in the same direction, it’s easy for them to find their matches huddled around that corner.
2. Don’t chase matches
Sometimes it can be tempting to beeline for big matches without considering anything else on the board. Though you may very well get that big match, you can also find yourself with few free spaces afterwards. Often in these situations, your high-scoring pair will be close enough together that you can clean up a few other cards while still keeping them together.
READ ALL : https://onclan.com/tip/threes-...

Bought both FIFA 15 and PES 15. Both are good with the licensing and presentation on FIFA top notch but i have to defer to PES as the better game due to the actual gameplay...it just feel like football. The numerous tactics that can be used and the player movement and AI movement is excellent. PES is more simulation while FIFA is more arcade like...to me. Both enjoyable game but I suggest PES for those that want a simulation experience or who actually play/played the game and FIFA who for those that just want a pick up fast pace game who may not have actually played the game at a reasonable level. This game is awesome, a solid 9 in my opinion. I understand where the reviewer is coming from regarding the characters and stereotypes and whatnot. BUT, you have to remember that this is a fictional country and most of the characters he is talking about are actually tourists/foreigners.

This game is $20 on Amazon now, more than worth the money. It's a blast to play. The world is absolutely beautiful. The collectibles are strangely addictive to roam around and find and the animals make the world feel alive. Yes, there are constant random events that pop-up like defending outposts and rescuing hostages and the like, but you can ignore them completely if you want. The events make it feel like there is actually a civil war going on and are fun when you're looking for something to do, but you can also ignore them if you're already doing something.
