I enjoyed FC4 much more than 3. I really hated the main protagonist and his pals in 3. Pagan Min was a terrific antagonist and his raid banter with Ajay was hilarious at times. There was one time Pagan chimed in about all the candles and was musing about how they were always lit, it was funny and little 4th wall breaking.

Now for those who
have played far cry 3 and loved it, you'll be happy to be greeted by the sight
of far cry 4 once the intro ends and you are thrown in a diverse, beautiful and
unforgiving world of the fictional Himalayan Kyrat. Because most of the controls,
aesthetics and mechanics of the game is heavily borrowed from Far cry 3, FC4 will feel a lot like FC3.5
instead of a completely new game, however, with its similarities comes also the
differences (multiplayer elements comes
into mind) that adds so much more fun into the game, making this game
feel very different from its predecessor at times.
The fictional
Himalayan Kyrat which the game is set in is a beautiful place with snow capped
mountains and huge scaling cliffs, which also hides ancient looking temples and
mostly interesting secret locations. However, as beautiful as the world is, the
game gave you no real reason to explore these locations other than it being
beautiful, yea sure there are collectibles within these locations but not all
of them are interesting enough for me to continue pursuing them, especially if
you're not one for reading chunks of texts in an action game. Most of the time
you will discover these places and bask in the glory of the beautiful next-gen
graphics and admire the huge world, but after that you will stand there asking
yourself, "what's the point? there's nothing here." The graphics of
FC4 is completely the same with FC3 with different Fauna and Flora models added
to the mix, although many may say that this can be a bad thing, I for one
thinks that it makes the game feel organic, and it doesn't alienate fans of FC3
such as myself. Overall the graphics make a lot of the secret locations worth
visiting, but there are no real depth to these locations, so after the first
few, you will stop caring about these locations and visit them only for the
statistical benefits for your character such as cash rewards, karma or simply
experience points when you find enemies there. but it's still a huge plus to
see that the developers stayed true to the original graphics as it definitely
assures me that I'm playing a FC game, and I love every bit of the action
elements of the game.

@SATONCHAIR Interesting review. I would say I agree with most of your points (save for any co-op or MP stuff, which is not of interest to me). I wasn't a big fan of FC3. I actually only finished it last month, having stopped playing in 2012 without finishing, and then doing a quick run through the story recently. I think the main island was wasted on Vaas, because I thought Hoyt was far more interesting. But that play, with some DLC, took me around 14 hours. Min tops them all, and having the mix of the two friendlies in FC4 I thought much more interesting than the random, no personality friends in FC3. Amita especially I thought came across very well (and we seemed politically similar, which I guess helps). I will say though, I only started enjoying the game after I modded the spawn sets to remove most of the obnoxious wildlife. So my only negative then comparative to FC3 is that it took longer to finish. Basically the rest, I agree, it improved.

I've tried to play this game several times but as of yet it has not drawn me in enough to stick with it. There are little things that just really turn me off...for example...

When I want to interact with something (or someone) I have to be right next to it. In most games, if you want to interact with something you can click on it and your character will move to it.

When I stop to talk or interact with someone/something, my companions look like they drank too many energy drinks and cannot find a spot to settle. During dialogues it looks absurd for my companion's to nervously move around in and out of the camera view. Ok people, just chill! I'm trying to have a conversation here!

I like Ryan Mccaffrey, but he shouldn't be reviewing games unless it's a cold review. Ryan covered Halo:MCC too closely before launch of the game. When you're rubbing elbows with studio heads and getting exclusive access to the game ahead of time, it's a little more difficult to stay objective. Halo:MCC was a disaster out of the gate. Yet even after multiple days of a review in progress, Ryan still gave it a 9.0. The review seemed to be more based on what would eventually work rather than what worked when the game was reviewed. In the future, a game like this needs to be reviewed by someone who has been purposefully locked out of previews and visits by studio heads and programmers.

This game was abysmally bad. Easily the worst I've ever played. Story...what story? You just randomly teleport to different cliche horror environments. Random recycled zombies everywhere, and are never explained. Random notes are picked up, and you'd think they are clues to the story, but no, they have nothing to do with anything. It starts out as a survival sneak around game, and quickly devolves into a clunky over the shoulder shooter with the worst controls ever. This game is so bad I'd wager that anyone giving it good marks is either a member of Bethesda's marketing team, or has a crush on Mikami. The characters have less personality than wet cardboard. There are NO payoffs to literally anything in this game. The two sub bosses who keep reappearing (safe-head guy and The Ring ripoff girl) you would think, at some point, would have some explanation. Nope. None here. The combat AI is wretched. You can just run past pretty much anything. Cheesy zombies that look like extras from The Purge in clown masks with GUNS. WHY DO THE ZOMBIES HAVE GUNS. Which doesn't help them much because they just walk/shamble straight to you while firing like stormtroopers before the give up shooting. Oh, and you only get a small handful of weapons, which is kind of ridiculous because you cant pick up and guns the zombies drop (submachine guns etc) Melee is punching, even though your character uses a bowie knife for stealth kills. What? The dialogue is awful. The voice acting is cringeworthy. the nurse in the save point zone (where you have to endure a screeching nails on chalkboard sound EVERY TIME YOU GO THERE) never has anything to say. Ever. Nothing. Its like the writers got together and said "you know what, what if we make a horror themed game with no story or motivation for the player?" The ending was weak, but then again I didnt expect much after slogging through this snooze fest.

im guess im writing this to any potential buyers of the game, just so you get an insight into the opinion of somebody who wasn't at all phased by the game, also im very bored. The evil within i found to be everything i hoped it wouldn't be. The characters are a huge flaw for me, so boring and cliche. Particularly Ruvic, the main boss, who looks like a zombie emo character from assassins creed, not remotely scary or challenging. i feel like the plot was also very cliche, though sometimes confusing it was easy to work out what the end of the game would be. The Game really lacks in real horror, and the survival elements are fairly hard but take so much away from the horror situation. The zombie ghouls, just an irritating obstacle with no originality that act as a buffer between each boss. Some of the bosses themselves are ok, but for the most part they too were cliche's with little scare factor. its a survival game with a twist that in my opinion really lacks the fear and tension it promises.

I've lived and played all the trully original games of the survival horror style, and i really feel sad about this game... everything is so beautiful yet experienced players have already seen it: police investigating a massacre (parasite eve feels), protagonist being carried out on a gurney, can't kill monster that is a butcher of some sort (sh2 all the way without the atmosphere)...
Pretty often i'd rather suicide to recover a wasted bullet or just because i was bored with my character...
This game isn't immersive, i couldn't care less about anything about it. Just my opinion...
Edit: After attempting to finish the playthough I gotta say that this is a fine game.
If you manage to push through the initial boredom, it is quite immersive. You see bits of silent hill here and there, yes, but it is quite a ride. Facing the boss of chapter 10 without no bullets whatsoever trying to scavenge away my victory was an experience i only had with the demons/dark souls series.
If you love survival horror and is tired to get only empty promisses, get this game. :)

@nachtwandler89 I think this takes explains why so many people give up on this game before giving it a proper chance. Unlike other modern games you need to push past first stage and get to "The patient" before the games settles. The stealth is very optional later on and the game is far more similar to Resi 4 with a twist of Dark Souls and a sprinkling of Silent Hill. 
The story is poor, but then Resi 4 has a very poor story even if it is more memorable. Like the games it is inspired by it won't be everyone's cup of tea but for the right people it clicks and loved. Also if you are in the camp that thinks games do too much hand holding and the trend of open world game play is a little overdone then you may appreciate what The evil within has to offer.
An underrated gem at it's finest.

So, just finished this game. Wow. Bought it on the low-low. Wasn't expecting anything amazing but wanted to give it a whirl. Totally got sucked in. Listen, it's not "mind-blowing" but what it is doing is reinventing the wheel when it comes to SRPGs in a much different way than what Disgaea or Agarest or any of those other games are trying to do. If you like Dark Souls level of combat difficulty and LOVE SRPGs then you owe it to yourself to give it a try. I'd give it a solid 7.5-8.0. The story is meh at best but the combat has so many meaty layers and there's a plethera of combat abilities, ways to approach combat and so many in-betweens that I'm not quite sure how the reviewer actually approached their review. 
 I'm thinking the reviewer tried to tackle it in the same vein as a FF Tactics game or similar and was doing everything wrong. You can NOT approach this game like that. You must clear your head and basically learn a different way and then sit back and watch the beauty of the game reveal itself. It is quite good and I was very much surprised at how many layers there were to discover.

Personally, I'm a big fan of Dark Souls and even I didn't even liked the game. The game was just a mess of unexplained mechanics and not to mention the game was slow and unforgiving. I especially hated the final boss, in which the fight is way more different than any other fights. The story, character designs and graphics are terrible, and the main characters just doesn't have enough backstory for me to care enough. The multiplayer is also a bit of a letdown, not to mention that not a lot of people are playing online.
At best, is a recommendable Strategy JRPG for the hardcorest strategy gamers with a lot of patience. At worst, is an unforgiving, ugly and slow JRPG, that it is basically the worst JRPG on the PS4 (and yes, even worse than Omega Quintet, Star Ocean 5 and the SAO games). For you, is a 7.5-8. For me, is a 4/10. It has some neat ideas but due to budget constraints, they failed to deliver the "Dark Souls of Strategy JRPGS". And I doubt the developer would even consider making a sequel due to the mediocre reviews it got, and not to mention it bombed hard in Japan.

This review should totally be rewritten. It's obvious their not even talking about the same game in here. I played the game first time during last two weeks. First downloaded the PSN Plus free version, the we decided to buy it right away. I've been a fan of Gran Turismo, NFS and Forza as well. And Driveclub for sure has shown the best driving experience compared to all of them, the way you enter the car and you're able to look around while you're racing, the way car interacts with the racing tracks, for the first time car wrecks sound and feel more realistic, also the painting scratches and car damage look much more realistic. Cars handle totally differently from each other and they feel far from glued to the ground. Weather is very beautiful, dynamic and much more realistic. There's so much improvement to realism here. For example, always hated the way car crashes sound in Gran Turismo and also the way tires screech persistently during all curves, it was never realistic. Just watch any onboard cameras in any racing sport as comparison, at Driveclub all of this improved a lot. Game is dynamic, realistic, innovative and exciting. This is a 9/10 game for sure.

Played it, beat it, on PS3 when it first came out... Just picked it up on the ps4 for dirt cheap. This game was amazing. No complaints about the AI over here. You always feel as though you are being stocked, and the way it responds to your movements keeps you on your toes with suspense and tension. Very unique cat and mouse experience. Coming from a huge fan of the movies and the survival horror genre I gotta say this review is wack. I'd give Alien Isolation a solid 8!

Normally IGN and I tend to agree when it comes to games being matched for my playstyle, but this review is totally out to lunch. The AI it claims is frustrating is the whole reason this game is terrifying... you're never safe. Ever. No matter how long you wait for the Alien to leave, it'll be back in a few short seconds, always looking for you. You literally have time to scamper from one bed to another, and that's it.

Plus, it tells you dozens of times in the menus and loading screens... don't run when the Alien is around. It WILL hear you, it WILL kill you, and it's entirely YOUR fault because you can't follow simple directions. If the reviewer finds being punished for their mistakes frustrating in the face of those directions, that's not the game's fault.

As for pacing, I've never had a horror game terrify me from start to finish like this one did. Normally about the halfway hump I have enough weapons and ammo, or am comfortable with the predictable monster patterns, and know I'm relatively safe unless I do something stupid. (I'm writing this while in the steam overlay playing Outlast, btw, and the exact same thing is happening here). Not so with Alien. 

In short, this review is basically a retread of TV Tropes' "It's hard therefore it Sucks!", and I would advise anyone reading this to discount its opinion. Take your time, keep your ears and eyes open, and proceed with caution. If you get killed, it's your fault. Oh, and that sequence of killing androids without the Alien? It's pretty much the only time you'll deplete your ammo stocks if you're playing the game right, so it's a nice opportunity to lull yourself into a sense of security before easily THE. MOST. TERRIFYING. SECTION. EVER.

Surely IGN are supposed to hire reviewers who are competent gamers? 

I've just completed the game in around half of the time this review suggests, on hard difficulty. I imagine the gameplay is likely to seem overly tedious if you are having to repeat the same actions over and over due to constanty dying however this doesn't happen if you are playing correctly? 

This was one of the most refreshing games I've played in a long time, the review seems to ignore stunning graphics and sound and terrific A.I.

I completely appreciate criticism of pacing and moments of repetition although it seems I was less less cynical about these flaws as I played by the games rules. 

Don't run to a save point, the Alien will hear you and stab you, you will get used to death and the horror magic will go, this is obvious.
IGN hire a better gamer to review games?

I reckon Chuck got this one spot-on in the review. Too many of the cases are solved on what feels like unsatisfactory evidence rather than solid proof. There's also a serious hiccup in the Kew Gardens case, where the accomplice could've been one of two people. The actual miscreant had already been given a cast-iron alibi, which had been accepted by Sherlock Holmes and not referenced in the end sequence at all. And I agree the lack of an overall story arc is a problem in a game that's sold as a single unit and not an episodic release.

On the plus side, the visuals are excellent, the voice acting spot on and some of the cases really do make you feel like Sherlock as you piece together the clues, but overall, I'd make sure you get it from the bargain shelves.

I'd disagree with the reviewer's judgement that the evidence is largely circumstantial and that there are multiple plausible suspects for the crimes. Acquiring every piece of evidence will prove beyond a reasonable doubt who the guilty party is every time, except for maybe 1 case, which I would say the evidence still points to one person
For instance, the one with the sailor's knot, a rope was cut by a tall person, and the victim killed by a very forceful blow. The sailor was the only suspect to fit all those parameters.
There was only 1 case that I got wrong, and that was because I made an assumption, and because the game basically deceived me. (Holmes made an assumption himself that was wrong and influenced my verdict incorrectly, really irked me)
The other criticisms I would agree with. This was a fun detective game that was a little too easy, with no great overarching story.

Had to stop and review this. It's excellent, got it as a free download for Xbox Gold March 2016. I went into it nonchalant because it was free, I had seen a review last year and thought it might be cool but never bought it. 

It's a nontraditional style and at first felt very awkward and unpromising. But by the second case you quickly appreciate the way the gameplay works.

This game is seriously just a big mystery with lots of puzzles. The character doesn't get hurt or have a health meter, and before you solve the case you can peek to see if you want to go back and change anything. It's really a no-lose, win-win situation and you can just have fun solving mysteries.

At first it felt limiting that you couldn't walk around anywhere, it's not a free roam game, you don't even jump anywhere. But as the map begins to expand and you have to go back and forth to places to pick up clues and verify evidence, you are grateful that you can fast travel from anywhere and your world suddenly feels bigger.

It's fun to find clues and see how they fit together, it's a great thinking game. It's worth the price of free all day, and I would have been glad to buy it as well.

NHL 15: In a nutshell

I am a hardcore hockey fan. I absolutely love hockey, but I absolutlely hate this game. I've been playing since Nhl 13 and i've played until my thumb was injured for months. Speaking of injuries, let me start there. I hate the gameplay so much, i'd prefer to simulate my entire Gm Mode if my team didn't have injuries pretty much every other game. Rookie is too easy, Pro is easy enough, so I like All-star, except, when I try to pass the puck, it automatically magnets to the opposition in the middle of the ice, even when I aim (deliberately) down the boards. The "overall/ratings" system is garbage. I'll be coming down the ice full speed and ready to knock someone off thier boots and if i'm playing a better team than mines, my players will just skid right past them, maybe give em a little booty bump on the way, the game litterally forces me to miss the hit even with my best hitters! Collision detection is horrible.Not to mention about half the time I do collide with someone, they have enough time to get back up and grab the puck again or they just take it from me with the same guy i layed the hit on. If you don't have HDMI, the game completely lags and is unbelievably unplayable. The guy who does the player ratings has to absolutely be retarded as most players strengths are not highlighted. Rather, this guy, or guys, are hell bent on who should have a higher overall. It's easily noticable. Matt Read and Couturier are the Flyers best defensive forwards yet their defensive ratings do not stand out (at all) from the rest of the team. Nearly all the starting forwards have minor differences in any of their skills, it's just unbearable to look at! Vinny Lecavlier easily has the hardest slap shot the flyers forward unit but without looking, i bet Giroux was given the hardest slapshot because they wanted to keep his overall around 90. Make sense? So I bet to keep an overall rating high, guys like crosby can hit harder than the guys who gave em his concussions! lol This game disgusts me in so many different ways, like my passes not going to the right players often.... and so much more. Mind you, i can still win games on allstar!!! i've just played it so much, i'm used to all of it's repetivie bullshit tricks and what used to seem like random gameplay to me has turned into redundant, rigged bullshit. If they don't give this game a full makeover next yr, I absolutely will not touch it.
This is what kills me about sports games debuting on next gen consoles from last gen; they leave out a bunch of features and then reintroduce them one or two at a time as new in the next years game.
That's EA for you. They do this all the time.

Thanks for all the comments. I was thinking about getting this game, but I almost only play seasons offline and it seems to be cumbersome to go through the Be A GM mode to do that. I sad that both the FIFA and NHL series seems to be stripped down to force us to play the Ultimate Team modes.

All the haters forget that hockey is played how this game runs. It's fine big deal if you don't have all the game modes they will come in time. Let them fix this and the polished product will be far superior game. Remember almost every" next gen" game has been broken so far.....relax and play some puck boys!

Playing against the computer at the All-Star level is infuriating. The number of times I managed to poke check the offensive player on a 1-on-1 and he still keeps the puck and scores on a F&*&*(&*?ing wrister is out of this world. Not to mention that slow CPU defenders somehow manage to have a burst of speed to thump you into the boards or bodycheck you into outer-space while cutting towards the middle of the ice is somewhat frustrating (i.e. coming down the right wing with Jeff Skinner defended by Tyler Myers. He's about 6 feet away but still, in one skate stroke, he blasts you up in the 30th row of seats). Plus, even though you shoot the puck 20 times in the first period without scoring, the CPU is going to have one rush down the ice and score on their first shot on net. Why? Because your goalie is a paraplegic. Oh and lastly (I'm going to stop after that because there would be a lot more to say), about two times a game, one of my players is going to chase a player a hundred freaking feet away from the puck only to push him and get called for interference. Sadly it's my only option for hockey right now and switching to a lower difficulty is just gonna let me score 8 goals per game.
It's called "scripting" and it's ruined FIFA too. People need to stop buying EA Sports games until they sort this crap out.
So the question is, is the OTP & EASHL modes in past gen version of this game? If so, screw it, I'll buy it for that & wait for hopeful improvements in NHL 16

If you think Minecraft is "a game with nothing in it", then you've either never played it (nor read anything about it, including the review above), or you're just a weird troll. The game has everything in it: a perfect in-game physics system that allows you to build anything and completely terraform a world, monsters to slay, resources and items to collect, optional tasks to complete, dragons to slaughter, 23 different biomes to explore, PvP or cooperative multiplayer, and the like. This "game with nothing in it" has more in it than almost any game I've ever played.
The "game" is for 10 year olds. If you like it that much, you're either 10 or should have it looked at.

Wrong. It's a game for everyone. It's popular from 5-year-old to 65-year-olds. It's the 3rd-best-selling video game of all time. Saying it's only for kids when the majority of people who own it and play it are adults (go watch some Twitch streaming of the game), many of who are incredibly smart computer programmers, is a naïve thing to say.

Im not a kid lol

The game was originally developed by Notch because he wanted to make an isometric 3D building game with RPG elements in the vein of Dwarf Fortress, Dungeon Keeper, and Infiniminer. Explain to me how that indicates to you that it was "specifically developed for children"?
Kids cannot figure out the complex physics system in Minecraft that has led people to make insanely complex automatic farms, traps, and so forth with redstone. Yet, kids can still play the game, eschew those complexities, and completely enjoy it.
The fact that it appeals to everyone from 5-year-old boys, to 13-year-old girls, to their casual game-playing parents, all the way to hardcore gamers and dilettante computer programmers and modders is a testament to how perfect of a game Notch made.
Regardless, say it was developed for children (which it wasn't). So what? So is every Pixar movie yet they're fun for everyone to watch. A great game (or movie or book and so forth) is a great game. Period. Minecraft is a great game.
Then you should get it looked at if you like a game made for kids that much. Do you still play with toys? No? Well, there you go.
ash5454 just got burned! I would love to see what you have to say to all this outstanding evidence! You must be a emo teenager who thinks anything that isn't black or angsty is for kids.

"all this outstanding evidence!"
Evidence of what exactly? That some guy wants to excuse the fact that he plays a child's game by trying to convince others that it's complex?
Next thing you guys will say is that Monopoly isn't made for children because it explores the intricacies of world economics, demand and supply and human greed.
Give me a break, it's a pixeled game with no story or basis where people build things with different colored squares. That some
people build cool things? Sure, there are mods out there that can do incredible things with any game on the market. That the game is complex? BS.
The fact that some adults play with it, does not make it for adults.

i played this game on xbox 360 when it first came out. then i got a PS4 and it looked alot better. the only thing is that i couldnt cross platform transfer my profile so i had to start all over. the game has its up and downs. I grabbed this game when it first came out, played it with a friend until lvl 15 or so, and then put it aside until a few weeks ago. I put it aside mainly because I was really just confused by the game and didn't think the loot system was very good. I also felt that you weren't really rewarded for exploration so it all just felt kinda of schizophrenic to me. 
So, a few months ago I picked it up again as some friends of mine recently bought copies. I really have to say I am having a total blast with it. I really think that the ‘shooting’ aspect of the game is second to none. I am lvl 17 and am now seeing that loot is more interesting. And the world design has really set in too. It really is amazingly detailed. Funny thing is, I have been playing this mostly alone, and it is just as enjoyable.
In conclusion, although I didn’t care much for the game on launch, I do now see that if you dig a little deeper and put some time in, the game becomes much much better. So I do understand some of the hate. In today’s age of instant gratification and reward, if something isn’t enjoyable or rewarding in the first 5 minutes, it ‘sucks’. I so admit I too am like this with games and movies sometimes. So I totally get it.
I imagine when I finish the main campaign, I will buy the Taken King as the reviews for it have been excellent.

Thumbs down. Very disappointing! On a my Windows 8.1 Pro x64 box the game keeps crashing. In July support suggested back leveling nVidia video drivers because they're working on the problem. It's October and the problem still isn't fixed. Tech savvy folks, if you're having a similar issue in win 8.1 x64 check the key value for HKCU\Software\HB Studios Multimedia Ltd.\The Golf Club\Handicapindex_h2158052195 it likely reads (invalid DWORD (32-Bit) value). TGC has more bugs than a baitshop!
This is the best golf simulator out there. The putting SUCKS, I don't care what the developers say. And fix the graphics, they are primitive.

I'll be honest with you, I got The Golf Club on release day, and I am still playing it all of these months later. Sure, it lacks some features in other golf games. But where it shines is that it offers so many free courses to play. The course creator is also cross-platform, so if you design a course on the Xbox One, your friend on the PC or PS4 will still be able to play it. Designing a course is easy, too. Anyone can "design" a generic course . . but by using the simple-to-use tools, you can design an impressive course from scratch. The only real problem with user-created courses is that you're always going to have a really awful course "designed" by some kid with no concept of course design. But there's in-game course ratings and web sites that will point you toward the better courses. (One last thing. The game itself takes up very little space on your hard drive, and the courses are not stored on your hard drive. Loading a course can take a couple of minutes sometimes, but it's a small price to pay for the space you save on your hard drive).

"No progression" is generous for a negative point. How about "pointless?" Maybe "No objectives?" I have never seen such a beautiful game in terms of graphics be such a suck-fest in terms of playability. To say that "golfers" would appreciate it more is nonsense. I play nearly 100 days of golf a year, and this game still sucks. Putting is a pain in the butt, and it feels like a Groundhog Day version of a game . . . just keep doing the same thing over and over and over . . .
Can anyone vouch for the update on 10/20? States that performance is upped 10-20% and a load of features were added: http://thegolfclubgame.com/201...

https://www.facebook.com/pages...

Dear Madden/Xbox One people,
I am a four time cancer survivor who will no doubt be fighting the disease again soon. All I do is play Madden, whether I'm healthy or not. I only use the Tampa Bay Buccaneers when I play. Arguably one of the worst teams on the game. However, on the Xbox 360, I was always ranked in the top 5-10% of the country, even though I only took the Bucs when I would play online.
I dreamt of the day I could play my favorite game on a new Xbox One system, but because I'm always sick, money for extra things was always very slim. On this fourth bout with cancer, my community threw a fundraiser for me. Finally, I had enough money to buy an Xbox One and the Madden game to go with it.
I had played over 500 games online with the 360, check the stats (Gamertag: YoutubeBigSix8). I just KNEW that the graphics, moves, jukes, EVERYTHING were going to be better on the Xbox One. I spent A LOT of money for just this one game, and BOY was I disappointed!
You really took a step back going from the 360 to the One. The movements are just like the old Madden games without the new engine. On the 360, (playing Madden 15) I can work magic with the RB Doug Martin. On the Xbox One, it's like running with an overweight fullback. He has the exact same roster numbers, but the movements are NOTHING similar to the 360 version. It's terrible. I thought maybe I just needed to get used to the new system. I've played over 50 games online with the Xbox One and I am now CONVINCED that the game lost SO much in the system upgrade it's ridiculous.
I find myself preferring to go back to the 360 simply due to the fact that I can move SO much better than on the new Xbox One. I would seriously like my money back because my favorite game is terrible on the new system. Unfortunately, my cancer surviving son has grown fond of his Mortal Kombat game and now the Xbox One has to stay. I really hope that you put just a LITTLE MORE EFFORT into making Madden 16. You had FINALLY got the running right! It was great! Then I get the amazing Xbox One, and it's like you went back in time. Please fix this on Madden 16. The Buccaneers are FINALLY getting a decent QB, and I would really like the mechanics engine to take a step forward versus the SERIOUS step back it took in the system upgrade. I'll end with this: Had I known the game Madden 15 on the Xbox One was going to be this much worse than Madden 15 is on the Xbox 360, I would have NEVER made the serious investment in the Xbox One. Right now, I'm feeling as if I should have purchased a PlayStation.
Hoping for better days,
Ethan Birch
www.six8productions.com
www.youtube.com/bigsix8

The game excellent. The story phenomenal. The game did something that no other game has for me and that is it tugged at me emotionally. Naughty Dog excells at giving games a cinematic feel. And I look forward to that in their future games ..... But ....
This game does not deserve the 10 it was given. While the game is great, it is far from perfect.
Trudging cross country with Joel and Ellie was an experience. We watched the 2 grow from 2 people who just met brought together by a mission to pretty much save humanity. But as the story unfolded, their relationship changed. We experienced their ups and downs on an emotional roller coaster ride, but that roller coaster derailed a few times along the way.
While playing this game, I couldnt help but keep thinking, where are they storing the food for the trip? Better yet, where are they getting the food? And where the hell is Joel and Ellie getting the batteries for their flashlight? Batteries only have a shelf life of a few years, yet there was never a concern about sparing the batteries in the flashlights. Hell, I think I played my whole last playthrough with the damned thing on.
And then there is the issue where you walk into a warehouse with 10 scoundrels looking for you. You are doing your best to sneak by and kill them without making a sound. But while you are sneaking around watching your prey ... Bam, Ellie runs by the guy and pretty much bumps into him and the thug pretends as if he didnt notice the teenaged girl with a gun in her hand run by him. So there were huge issues with AI on both sides.

This has to be one of the most abysmal reviews I have ever read. It completely got almost everything wrong.

As a game, Another World has captivated me since I was a young kid. I can remember playing it at my grandma's house on my SNES back in the day and trying to figure out what to do. Years later, I still play this game from time to time and enjoy making my way through it just as much as I did the first time.

Just because the main character doesn't have the same agility as mario, sonic, or megaman doesn't make it a bad game. Slow and deliberate movement is part of the gameplay.

And something else Colin - the controls respond quite well. Your timing simply sucks.

As another reviewer has said, this game is widely regarded as a milestone in gaming history; its influence can still be felt to this day. The 20th Anniversary edition, while not groundbreaking, only serves to improve upon the game with better visuals and menus; it does not alter the game in a negative way.

As someone who actually knows what they're talking about, take it from me. This game is a solid 9/10 with 1 point being deducted for the fact that the game actually can be quite obtuse and vague in some points, perhaps beyond the point of frustration for some gamers (but personally, I like this).

I am very sorry but I completely disagree with this review. This review does this game a big injustice. 4 out of 10 is a ridiculous score. This game is a regarded as a Magnum Opus and has influenced other game franchises. I am very surprised this game has received such criticism for me personally i would give this game a 9.9 out of 10.
@Retro.Gaming.World  Don't apologize. You are 100% right and this review is 100% wrong. An utter joke.

Another World has long been widely considered a masterpiece for a very good reason: it's fun. The fact that it's also beautiful and cleverly done certainly contributes to the judgement of history, which is, of course, a far greater judge than one Colin Moriarty 25 years after the fact. I don't need to say anymore, except, by way of example why this review is off the mark, Prince of Persia =/= Super Mario Bros. Two vastly different genres. Mr. Moriarty didn't discuss the story and its presentation, which is basically the essence of the experience that makes it a classic. Instead the review repetitiously talks about how difficult the controls were for the reviewer, even going so far as answering its own rhetorical questions in the opposite manner intended by the author, I think:

"I can't deny the feeling of accomplishment I got when I worked my way through a stubborn and annoying part of Another World, which is basically every single part of it."

Yes, that's the point of the game.

That paragraph ends with the following sentence: "Lester walks around like a bag of cement, he shoots his laser gun with no consistency, and he jumps like a 1,000-pound man. Where's the fun in any of that?"

I believe you just answered that question yourself.

7.6 Community? 8.2 IGN? Are you serious? Has everyone gone nuts? I held off as long as I could after hearing so many great raving reviews, just waiting for this price to drop after missing the 10$ window, and now, after cashing in some long-saved trade rewards, I couldn't feel more cheated. Antiquated physics, downright disgusting graphics, incredibly limited "open-endedness" and a sense of motion-to-control that constantly reminds you how stiff and pre-programmed previous gen animations really were compared to current engines; not only does this feel like last gen, it looks like it, plays out like it, and treats you like an idiot for not wanting a last gen game. Were this an early PS3 or 360 title, I would understand and lower my expectations significantly, but this is the same generation that brought us Battlefield 4, Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes, and Wolfenstein: The New Order, and those were just the titles released BEFORE Sniper Elite3, THE SAME YEAR! When Sniper Elite came out on the XBOX and PS2, getting behind the rifle felt nuanced and clever. V2 gave us heightened senses and brought back that feeling of risk with preparation with its PS3 and 360 upgrade. Sniper Elite 3 just feels like a standstill when everybody else is taking leaps. COD2 felt more advanced than this game and would STILL feel more advanced than this game and that's sayin somethin. Now, having said all that about the fundamental mechanics of the game, let's talk about multiplayer. What absolutely ticks me off the most about multiplayer is how so many people praised this game for saying it "made them feel like a sniper", when not a single mode actually effectively utilizes any semblance of caution and marksmanship aside from the same old rinse-repeat run and gun COD formula. If it's the slow gore you want, get back to Max Payne. If it's the sniping and aim assist, ramp up the difficulty on ANY of the umteen cookie-cutter COD's or Battlefields. For anything else, avoid like the plague. This is a stunted experience and to encourage it further would be to perpetuate a poor quality of entertainment. If you absolutely MUST play this, rent it.

I love the sniper elite series. And this game is no exception to that :D
The graphics are great (not the best of it's time, but still really great).
Everything looks beautiful, and also important in my opinion, it looks very natural instead of artificial like GTA V or Dragon age (not that it's a bad game. for those games it works just fine). It really feels like you are out in the canyons or forests. Also the weather is very well made.
Also they improved my favorite thing about the game. The bullet ballistics and the x-ray vision. They look stunning, and are quite realistic. Also they added vehicles into the x-ray vision (much better than in V2) and you can blow them up in quite an awesome way.
The down part however is that it is way too short. Something that really bugged me, cause I could have gone on for many hours it was that awesome. The missions it does have, however, are totally awesome. I was completely stunned by awesomeness in the last mission :P
I really recommend buying this game, though I would say to buy it somewhere on sale, for the game is quite short for it's price even though it is an awesome game.

*edit*

Apparently it is able to get it for about $10 which is a very low price for this still. BUY IT! :D (Be sure to NOT buy this on normal steam pricing for $50. That it is not worth.)

8,5/10 (If it was longer it would have been 10/10)

great game. i finally took the time to play it, having it on my hd for a year now. a lot of heart went into this game and it's got a fantastic score (although not a big number of tracks, most are repeating throughout the game). loved the gameplay and the story. only thing i found a bit weird is the british voice speaking for the individual characters, e.g. when reading/writing a letter. would've been nice if Emile would have been spoken with a French accent. Though this is not a big concern. I absolutely loved the mumbled voices of the characters while playing, that you could yet somehow still understand. 
Lastly it is the only game i ever played that plays during the 1st world war. Being German myself i obviously know a lot about WWII but shockingly little about this war. So i for one appreciated all those historical facts.

The problem with this game is not the historical facts. It's the chase/driving sequences. It's the inconsistent options. It's the hint system (which I did need a few times). While infuriating at times, the chase sequences have user friendly auto saves. The puzzle solving is drilled into your brain one way, but changes halfway through the game to include some things you aren't taught. And the hint system only shows you the pieces, not the solutions (I know that bomb is there, I've been using it for the last 5-10 minutes unsuccessfully). This is why there is an unlimited supply pile of most items needed for progression: trial and error. I also hate the puzzles involving rearranging pipe pieces with levers and wheels. Ugh. Anyways, fun game for the most part. Does a decent job of telling a story. It's still basically a browser based flash game.

Easily one of the best games I have ever played. Art, gameplay, story, music... all excellent. I ran the gamut of emotions- smiling and laughing during the car chases, raging over my poorly timed clicks as the EKGs scrolled by, and then holding back tears as the story reached it's end. It's exactly what a game should be. You cannot be disappointed.

The game started well enough, letting you learn how to control the plane and improving attacks on ground targets. Then as you move up the ranks, you find yourself in missions where you cannot hit mission targets in a fighter, but playing as a bomber is about as exciting as driving a tractor (wait five minutes as you get to target, hit space bar a few times, then wait another 5 minutes for another target, repeat). Then you start to see the problems with game mechanics. 

You drop off throttle because you are flying past the ground targets too fast, but you don't actually lose speed, until you try manouvering then you get a warning saying you are going too slow. 

Even though you aren't manouvering, your sights won't stay still on the target. You can actually shoot  straight at a target with a full magazine and it doesn't take one hit, even though the shots are passing straight through it. 

Worst of all is the lack of scenarios, there only seem to be about 6 on each level, so you end up repeating them time after time. 

Bottom line is it looks good, starts off well, but then you get bored of repeating the same scenarios time after time, then you start seeing the flaws in the gameplay and mechanics, and eventually wish you hadn't bothered. I certainly wouldn't spend money on it 2/5 for the first few days of enjoyment. Put it this way, I had a choice today of playing war thunder or putting my DVDs in alphabetical order - My DVDs won

HORRIBLE LAG! I mean, HORRIBLE! I am hardwired & getting 60 mbps & the game is just frustrating.

When an enemy is near, I go to aim & my crosshair will freeze & then jump, most of the time I get killed before I can aim, because even if I get my crosshair on an enemy, it will jump off of them.
PS4 players ALWAYS spawn later than PC players. Most of the time the PC players are already halfway to the objectives, if not at the objectives. On small maps, sometimes PC players are already on the outskirts of our spawn before I have even spawned making it difficult, if not impossible to even get out of the spawn.
The game is "free to play" & looks great. Just don't spend ANY MONEY on the download content until the, apparently incompetent, developers care enough to fix the lagging servers & the handful of issues that put console players at a disadvantage.
The game favors PC players. Some turn their graphics on low, so they can have superior lines of sight. Some use aimbot hacks (search YouTube gor War Thunder aimbots & you will see videos of people using them). These things coupled with the late spawning put console players at a disadvantage.
Play it for free, just don't give them any money until they fix the issues.

The game has no manual save feature so you lose game progress as a result.  There are plenty of other bugs as well and zero developer support 2 years after release. 5.5 is more than a fair rating for the game. Basically never get this game for the PC unless it is on a massive sale as it was for the Steam Summer Sale.

I remember reading this review back in 2014, and deciding to give the game a pass.  My reasoning was that I had fought Nazis a billion times in my video game career. I did not feel the need to do so again.  In conversations with friends, we discussed how the ww2 thing had been done to death on every form of entertainment; we were getting sick of the fact that they were still making these stories.  It wasn't that we had anything against the second world war, but we wanted artists to explore more original time periods when they created new historical fiction.

Now the year is 2017, and this game cannot download fast enough onto my ps4 hard drive.  There has never been a more appropriate time to shoot at Nazis in a video game!

Having just completed this game, I find it hard to agree with the concluded review found by IGN. It's almost as if reviewers look for more to complain about then to look for things to enjoy. Story-driven games are certainly not as popular as they once were, and the story here is pretty engaging. As a history buff, I've always wondered what would have happened if the Germans had won WWII -where would technology be? What would the world look and feel like? For me, this game -much like the title of this review- answers that question while it tells a story to the player.

I don't think the story was as compelling as the Bioshock series, but it was certainly really badass and creepy. I personally felt the game felt incredible as a first-person shooter. Unlike a lot of games that take out the physical movements of the character as a limitation, this game felt more "real simulation" in that regard. Have a huge gun? Well it would have trouble aiming around a wall or ducking behind cover. Need to move? There was actual acceleration rather than instant fluid movement on a game like Doom.

This game will be played through again for sure, but to rate this game under an 8 by the IGN staff is a shame.
@VisceralShot10 Could not agree with you more!

Actually having to press a button to pick up the items makes it feel very new. Both original Wolfenstein and Doom gave you items automatically by walking over them, and that's what makes The New Order feel weird, especially now in retrospect compared to new Doom which still maintains that old item pickup mechanic.

@Grenadeh I think it makes it more challenging especially on harder difficulties where ammo is so essential. If you do not slow down to pick up the ammo you have just earned, you could make later sections of the game harder for yourselves when you are left with a big mech completely out of shotgun and missile ammo.

Just got the Lunatic Trophy for the base game and now re-playing Whistleblower to 100% the docs/notes and for the insane trophy.  I have to say the one thing that Marty doesn't mention that really brings the DLC down a notch or two is the over-the-top grossness of the DLC bosses, particularly The Groom.  The base game is pretty much a masterwork in how it tells the story, the use of scripted moments, and the supporting score that functions like the best accompanying orchestra to heighten and put a pin on many moments.  Outlast is a gory, over-the-top, gross-out game to begin with... but the base game feels much classier than Whistleblower.  I did enjoy the way the narrative weaves back and forth with the original, but I would have appreciated bosses that were more scary and subtle and less focused on simply increasing shock value.  And as Marty notes, it gets frustratingly repetitive at points where the tight environments means watching dozens of character deaths before you have time to fully explore your surroundings with the bosses on your heels and nowhere to hide from them long enough to buy yourself sufficient exploration room.  Even getting stabbed to death in the testicles eventually gets old after a couple dozen times.
Another thing too is the story is so so so short! 17 missions?? Then after its just repeatable side missions it's awful

A game with great graphics from the Fox Engine with highly good textures in the environment and objects, weather effects, lens flares in lighting, realistic movement in the human interaction, a day-night cycle included in the later game, well done character models in the game, impressive sound effects, enemy AI that can act predictable and unpredictable whenever it wants to for a stealth game, and a smooth frame rate in next gen consoles and PC. Gameplay with well done stealth gameplay just like the previous Metal Gear games with the best control in the a Metal Gear franchise. Well done voice acting and Kiefer Sufferland does solid job as Big Boss but it feels incomplete without David Hayter as the Snake that we know of from the previous games, well written and interesting developed characters with the inclusion of Skull Face with an interesting backstory, and an appropriate soundtrack that fits the tone with the game, and collectables that are worth it to install to the next game to add in more story in it. What falls "short" the keyword is short is that the open world feels small and you can't go anywhere outside of the Black Site in Cuba thanks for invisible walls, a weak story of how Snake lost his arm but with good action scenes, some of the characters aren't that well developed in storytelling, and a short main story mission that lasted two hours and the side ops missions lasted another two hours which is four hours of gameplay with its last year retail price of $39.99 an overpriced demo a kind of dirty business practice that makes Konami look pretty shady and they already are just to cash in on fans of the anticipated Phantom Pain which is already release. If you want to play Ground Zeroes rent it and it's now $20.00 to buy but I would still wait for the price to drop below 20 bucks or even better borrow it from a friend and I got the game for free on Xbox Live for the 360 but since I played it I would get an next gen console or PC to play the game again and add my complete objectives and collectables to the Phantom Pain. Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes gets an 6/10.

I don't understand all the negativity for this game from the unified gaming press. Hitman Absolution was to the Hitman series what Thief is to the Thief series (supposedly) but here is the thing, I hated HA because it was nothing like a HM game but I really like Thief as it is still very much a Thief game. And HA got universal praise for being different by the same gaming sites that hated on Thief for being a little different. OK, I can only compare the reboot to the Thief game that came out on the original Xbox, which I liked at the time for what is was, a medievilesque reskin of Deus Ex. But I am having a blast on Thief. I like the atmosphere and look, I like how Garret feels to control, everything works is it should and it's a fun, romp of a game if you aren't a blatant pc Übermensch fanboy. I think the game is definitely worthy of an 8. I will have to react to one of the older comments here from duncan29, because he says a lot of silly things that simply aren't true.

First, I agree with him somewhat in regards to the story. It kinda feels like even the characters don't give a damn about it. Very early spoiler (like, very first mission/prologue spoiler): Garrett has been apparently unconscious for a year, but he acts like he was out for 2 days. Everybody acts like its perfectly normal for anyone to be in a coma of some sort for a year. No kriff given. Weird.
Second, I also agree with him about the sounds, in a way. It's not "Garrett's superhearing" though, it's just a bugged sound system. Conversation pieces can be stuck on loop forever, sound very loud or very quiet, completely independent from the distance of the speaking person.

With that said:
- Doors are there in every house. Yes, even the City Watch Offices. They are non-interactive though, because those parts of the houses were not modeled/designed by the devs. Or did you really think there are homes that consist of a single bedroom, nothing else? There are doors in every house that can't be opened, but you can very safely assume they lead to other parts of the same building.
- The crowbar isn't in your inventory? You don't say? Have you noticed that the grappling hook (not the arrows) and the blackjack isn't in your inventory either? Or the lockpicks? Hmm, that's possibly because _they aren't consumables_!!! Use your head, please.
- "No skill in pressing E". True. But it's hell of a convenient way to quickly steal everything and open doors and use stuff. Same as in the earlier Thief games. Instead of E, you just used the left and right mouse buttons in those ones. Would that be better? The skill is in completing missions with all the challenges. On Master difficulty. Have fun!

although I agree with 7.5, and most of the critic, I can't possibly believe the author criticized the game as unbalanced. If you kept the same pace everytime, the game would get boring real quick. There are plenty of child games where you can simply mash the attack button to the victory. Theres plenty of health to pick up in the entire game. Heck, there are rooms that will fill your health bar for free everytime you go through it! What else do you want?

Some parts require a lot more than that, and some bosses are going to be difficult. Difficult boss battles is what makes a great game. 

My criticism: no jungle? Felt the game could be longer - beat it in about then hours revisiting every map to collect items. 

Cant recommend it enough. Looking forward to sequels.

There's a bit of exageration on this review when saying this is a very hard game. Seriously, I have a life playing 2d plataformers, and to me, I don't see the insane difficulty they say, maybe in some levels, but there are checkpoints and many lifes, and the secondary characters can help you in all levels with their floating abilities... When you say that this game is very hard, I imagine a person that never played 2d games and have terrible timing problems, because if you have played, you will not have many problems.
People are really so familiarized with easy games that when they take a 2d plataformer that requires a bit more precision and fast thinking, they say the game is insanely hard? It's the kind of game that will be hard as much as you want, because you can just beat the game, or you can find all secrets and beat all levels.
Even if you die in some level, there are checkpoints and you already know what to expect, so you will pass through with a few tries. But the game has a great level design, it's not that hard for players that don't sucks, buy yes, is a challenging game, a good challenging.
As with Mario games, I always try to get the hard levels with stock mario, I want to play this game with "stock" donkey kong, if thats the way to call it. Even if it is harder it will be worth it!

While this is a "mediocre" game entertainment wise. It's mechanics are sound. And it accomplishes what it sets out to do. I think they need to do away with this exact to the point scaling system. Got it for free in February through XBox Live: Games With Gold.  Gotta say, this review is way off.  

First:  It uses the old-school approach of "Try, Die, Repeat" - something many of us grew up with.  I guess the reviewer would rather the game be a no-lose, no-die deal.  Everyone wins and everyone is special.  Right.

Second:  Max is a sequel to a game IGN had actually reviewed called Max & The Magic Marker.  I would expect a reviewer to do their homework.  I suppose that's asking too much.

Third:  I felt the controls were fine.  Sure, it takes a bit to get used to, but it's hardly unwieldy.

Fourth:  No double-jump?  Fall too far and you die?  Heaven forbid!  It's almost like this is a regular kid, rather than a Rayman.  That said, the controls to climb, run, swing, and jump work well.

Fifth:  Yes, it's not very long.  The nice thing is, you can go back to any level to find any secrets or eyes you missed.  That's called replayability.  Too bad you didn't mention that.

Last:  This game was co-developed for the XBox 360, XBox One, and PC.  It looks far better than its charming prequel, but it's not a next-gen game.  Don't expect it to push the envelope of a next-gen system.  It looks good for an XBox 360 game, so it's good enough.
No mention that this is a sequel?  For shame.

My verdict on this game: Absolutely GOD AWEFUL. I'll still play it, as I enjoy the concept, and don't get me wrong; it could've been amazing, but the execution fell flat on it's face!
I don't do competitive or technical terms, so I'll say 3 things about it.
1. You can't lose in the opening. Sure, this might seem like a good idea, make the new players who are bad at the game feel good about themselves! But as soon as they leave that area they're going to dive head first into a group of enemies and die, a lot.
2. The difficulty has no curve. By the time I got to Circe's mission (Giganta), I was dying in two or three hits without any explanation. I had gone back and grinded to 3 level above what most people were and STILL got my ass handed to me within ten seconds.
3. The AI and the Targeting systems... oh boy. Most older games get AI wrong, usually the friendly kind, but DCUO takes it too far. The AI will OCCASIONALLY target non-player allies and attack them. You enter a room full of both enemies and allies and most of the enemies that see you will attack you. The targeting, meanwhile, makes no sense. Press LB or L1 to target? All it does is rotate my camera! And LT/L2 just targets the enemy furthest away!
If you ask me, DCUO should be shut down and given a complete overhaul, because right now (Excuse my next line for its vulgarity) the game is a pile of fucking shit!
3/10 Because I enjoy the concept.

Small addition:
Equipment breaks too easily. I used a staff for 1 quest and it was bought from the Hall of Supervillains Bank. I started using my FISTS mid-fight against Panarchos lo/Io. Unbelievable how much is wrong there.

The game has some very fun elements to it, the one thing that kills me is the community. I play with my daughter, who loves the DC Universe, but her and i feel it next to impossible to accomplish quests because every single individual within a close radius swoops in at every second to steal what we need to move on. Social chat has the charm of a trashy, run down strip club in the ghettos of Tampa, FL. There doesn't seem to be any player interested in immersing themselves in the DC Universe judging by the names and the behaviors seen. That's just my two cents.

Unless you join an online community that shares your interest this is typical behavior from people you meet online. UNFORTUNATELY. I recommend you do some simple searching and it shouldn't be too hard to find one. I recently joined one for the DIVISION and it's pretty significant how much different it is to play with a like-minded group than being at the mercy of random online players. Good luck to you and your daughter.

Finally got around to playing this once it was free and I was floored. This game is amazing. This review calls the story "interesting"; try gripping, thrilling, or terrific. It felt like I was reading a good book or watching a movie whenever the cut scenes happened. The combat is simple, with hidden depths, visceral, and very satisfying. We should be talking about how excited we are the the second or third game in the series, not marveling at how thoroughly every major gaming outlet dropped the ball when it came time to review the first one. After this, I'm not going to bother with reviews anymore. These people CLEARLY don't know what the hell they're talking about.

gave this a go while its free, but this review doesnt hit many of the issues with the game.

firstly, the cutscenes. now i like a good cinematic as much as anyone else to give us some story, but at least give us the option to SKIP the cutscenes. i want to play the game not sit and watch a mini movie every 5mins.

secondly, the on screen prompts. tell us how to do everything at the beginning and then never bother us again. dont interrupt battles midway through just to tell us A means block.

thirdly, the camera needs to be further out or higher up. i dont want to finish off an enemy up close and then not be able to see where i am going before running straight into another group of 3 barbarians.

fourthly, the upgrade system is just too confusing. they either use long winded explanations for simple things like "bonus health/focus capsules (wtf is a capsule or focus)", or they give us no explanation such as the combat or execution upgrades. do i need to trigger the new executions in combat with certain button presses or are they randomly generated? nothing that tells me exactly what i need to know.

As long as you don't have kids and major responsibilities I think it's cool. But overall after your over 30, I think you should be doing other, more constructive things. Like going on vacation. I use to game with my wife, and she got so caught up in it, she became very LAZY, while I worked my butt off. Call me a killjoy, but I just can't get heavily into gaming anymore. Then again I'm almost 40.

Umm, cool? I'm 31, and even though I don't have kids, I have more than enough responsibilities on my plate. I run two small businesses and I recently decided to go back to school full-time to finish my masters degree in computer science, and my wife has a stacked schedule as an administrator at a very busy doctor's office/immediate care, so spending our extremely valuable time and money doing "constructive" things like... going on vacation (lol seriously?)... isn't a very realistic option, at least not on any kind of regular basis.


When I said "countless hours", I meant over the course of two years. We don't have endless time to sit around and play games, but once or twice a week, we like to cut loose and play games together in the evenings when we're done with everything we HAVE to do. It's just a cheap way to have some spontaneous fun that doesn't require driving across town in search of entertainment. Not that any of that is your business, but since you brought it up, there it is. Also, this is a gaming site, not yahoo parenting or something, so talking about the games people play is the entire point. But thanks for passing judgement on me four months after the fact.

This game sucks.

Golf games are about mastering a small skillset that enable you to perform better and better as your gear and skills improve. It's the improvement and bettering your score and performance that is so satisfying.

Powerstar turns this whole process on its head by substituting improved skills with consumable "boosters". I don't know how an entire company managed to develop this to completion without realizing that they were destroying the precision = reward formula that is really at the heart of golf games and golf itself.

It's tantamount to designing a bowling game and making "accuracy" a consumable that you have to purchase separately.

Want to be able to hit 300 yards? Buy a booster! Want a phenomenal spin? Buy a booster! Why you could be the best. All you have to do is buy lots and lots of boosters.

It's an insult to golf games. I really wanted to like it because it was the first "three-click" golf game I've seen on the Xbox. That's its only redeeming quality.

It's now "free" on the One. Which really means you can get a free trial, and buy the rest of the game in separate DLCs, so the full game isn't really "free". It's like what they did with Killer Instinct.

Just downloaded it for my son to play as it was cheap in the store, and he loves it. Yes, its not the most complex of games and it is restrictive in its linear game play,  but the graphics are nice and colourful, its engaging with some solid variation, and some interesting, but simple puzzles - it introduces to a young audiences game mechanics that experienced gamers know well.

It's clearly marketed at younger audiences and it delivers superbly on that front. I suspect the reviewer didn't take this in to consideration well.

Honestly im scratching my head at this review, and a bit confused on what the writer must think a fun game is? I love knack. I just got it and played 3 straight hours last night and there want a dull moment where I wanted to turn it off. Its very engaging and just purely fun. I think the story is great! The graphics are beautiful and the controls are simple as pie. Its a easy game overall but its just FUN. That's something video games are missing these days in large part... Games are generally so detailed, gfx oriented, challenging and complicated that you can't just sit back and feel like you are just having fun. Its like the person who wrote this review was just trying to shit on this great game for some reason? This game sort of reminds me of the fun I had playing games on my nes and snes just from the standpoint that I felt very entertained engaged and joyful while playing knack. I am thrilled a p2 is coming out soon. Its the best game I have played on ps4 so far. Ign should really have ppl who enjoy the genre or type of game they are writing about to do their reviews. I like the camera angles in this game alot and I never felt lost once. With many games made in our time, you may kill a few enemies and since u can walk anywhere u want you may end up 10 miles away from your mission and you end up not advancing the story. You get lost. But in knack the story keeps unfolding rapidly as you play. the developers intended it that way and I am very glad. Its the opposite of disengaging. What was this reviewer thinking? Knack is a awesome game. People should really play this game themselves and come to a conclusion. Im sure most people will enjoy knack. As the majority of comments here reflect.

So I recently played AC3 and Black Flag back to back.
How the majority of the Internet thinks Black Flag is a better game than AC3 is beyond me.


“The size of the world is staggering, and the fact that it's absolutely brimming with fun and rewarding activities made me want to get lost as possible as I traveled from point A to point B.” – Nothing that wasn’t already done in AC3.
Traversal is more glitchy and easily the worst in the series. AC3 controlled almost perfectly, one annoying tree here and there. Dramatically fewer than the annoying trees in AC4.
Too. Damn. Many. Collectibles. The game is a gigantic time sink of nothingness. All Assassin’s Creed can be accused of being time sinks … but at least they were fun. In AC3, it was a pleasure to run and climb on stuff because of the newer animation system. Black Flag though … is on a whole new level. The game has enough systems, but they don’t feel especially pleasant.
“Death animations are relatively short and sweet”. This is a straight lie. Animations last LONGER than in AC3 and combat feels annoying because of this. It doesn’t’ flow as good as AC3. Using 2 swords for combat is simply too much. Connor was much more versatile using a sword and a tomahawk.

@Acryion Oh I can see how the majority of the internet/gaming community could see AC IV Black Flag as being a better, more refined game that BUILT upon what was already done in AC3 - I personally like AC IV's story better, the enviroment (not just what we/you are exploring) but just the tone, setting - everything about ACIII was improved (or worked upon, or tweaked) whatever little cliche term you wanna throw in there.  Basically its subjective its opinion - but I COULD easily see (as most can) how AC IV black flag is a superior title to ACIII - I couldnt wait to be finished with AC3 - but with AC IV I wanted more and it is what it is.  Everything you said could be returned/ and flipped on its head and used to reference AC3 - AC3 if anything did NOT feel important or remotely enjoyable (nor as large) even IF a game is larger and you feel its a time sink then again what large open world game isnt ? AC3 "dabs" at the idea of open world, ACIV accomplishes it, and remember its your opinion personally I dont think a game can have ENOUGH collectibles and ANY game can be considered a time sink - but nothingness ? are we playing the same game cause it was AC3 that I was extremely bored with (from story, to side missions, to the character you played) all extremely forgettable...ACIV on the other hand I can still remember it a year later then again I played AC3 in passing on the X360 and I played ACIV on the PS4 with a new better high end flat panel UHD TV.  That is just graphical though, but for me AC2 and ACIV will always be the best 3 and 1 are too repetitive and the storylines (if ACIV is considered to have a weak main campaign/story) then my lord AC3 has a downright horrendous storyline only thing I can admit about AC3 is its "ambition" but like the movie: Blow w/ Johnny Depp as he states in the end (a perfect quote for this topic) "my ambition far outweighed my talent" you could translate that to a single video game or for that matter Ubisoft Montreal lol...but in the end its all opinion/taste - and to each their own I guess, also I could never personally get into 18 century boston and mr  connor - the american frontier my ass - on the other hand the golden age of piracy and the caribbean was just a pure blast...but as said just above it comes down to taste.

@Acryion And again you must be playing a different version the combat was fine for me (fluid and enjoyable) in ACIV furthermore you claim that the feels annoying...um the PS4 version felt just fine...and the animation times I just dont see that and personally as I said in last post cant.have.enough.collectibles - but again thats personal opinion but my biggest gripe with your comment is "traversal is more glitchy and easily the worse in the series" wow now you MUST be played a different version I had not one glitch, lag, frame rate issue ONE BIT on the PC or the PS4 version infact I would say QUITE the opposite - AC3 = like skyrim in some instances, ACIV - smoother then GTA V in almost every way imaginable thats MY experience, bigger world, smoother context and more fluid (both in and out of combat) more rewards more collectibles (which I see as a plus) and just a better setting/time period.  So in almost everyway I see ACIV as a upgrade from ACIII (and ACII had a better story then both) but I guess the version you played, and your personal taste goes alot into that, cause 99% of the people I've talked to some have only played 2-3 AC titles, some have played nearly every entry in the series but ALL seem to say the same thing that they prefer Syndicate Or ACII or ACIV as there top 3 AC titles (in any specific order)...but to each their own as I've said before everyone is different but alot of what you said I DID NOT experience in my 72 hours of playthrough in ACIV (I played it twice with both a 72 hour playthrough and a slight bit shorter experience on the PC) but it was smooth and enjoyable.

@Acryion And I should note (this post is quite lengthy but I made a post quite along time ago..well a few years back (about 2 years ago) when I made a detailed (and compared to my usual typing where its just one giant run on of a sentence) I made a detailed post back in January 2014 about Assassins Creed III why I thought it was the worse of the entries in the series (it has nothing to do with ACIV as ACIV hadn't even been released yet when I made this original post I had to dig it up on my Gamespot.com account and here is why (in detail) I thought this way.  (the post will be below)

@Acryion (Post Made Originally by my account on Gamespot for the ACIII review in late 2013 10 months after its initial console release) "I just finished this game yesterday and played about 7 hours postgame and im currently at 59% sync which is prob where i will also stop once ive done all naval missions.

Its been 1½ years after i played Revelations, as these games really burn you out after doing one. So i was finally set to play this and have come to the conclusion that so far from AC 1,2,Bro,Rev this is absolutely the worst game in the franchise only toppled by AC1 for me.

This game has returned to things that made the older entries and especially AC 1 a chore and bore to play. 

Some of the main things that ruins this game: 

1. Core Gameplay elements. Theyve really ruined alot of the fluid feel the great entries after AC1 had with this game. Parkour elements dont feel as responsive in the older games again, i felt like i got stuck on way too many things and areas or climbing areas i didnt want to. The city/frontier design seem to play alot into this. Fast traveling gets used alot in this game due to how bad it is to use the horse in especially the frontier area, constantly you will lose the view of the main road or get stuck at rocks and edges with it, often leaving you in horse rides that take 5 seconds or so before you have to jump off and run again. Where is New York in the main story ? Theres like 3-5 missions that takes place there and 2-3 of them are in a prison and the rest is in about 20% of the map section before its over. The most interesting looking and open city in the game is completely absent for exploration due to lack of missions, i never felt like i had to travel through the city to find a new exciting area. Instead the game take place most of the time in Boston or Boreston more like which had like the docks/harbour as the only interesting and distinctive part. The feel in general of discovering in this game is absent due to weather changes which just makes travelling more annoying due to darkness/fog etc. Thrown out the window is also the exotic feel and locations of the 4 prior games where you would see the Colloseum/Bosphorus Area/Hagia Sophia etc. and instead we get to see a bunch of damn trees and post offices/halls *ZzZ*. There was literally no amazing views/areas in this game that made you awe to be inside it or explore, dont get me started on the underground tunnels *ugh*. Mission design is also way to linear and strict, something first introduced in Brotherhood hence why i rate it below AC2 especially. The alternate objectives in this game were also really annoying and felt like they were intentionally designed to be failed so you could replay them, a cheap way kind of from the developer to force in some replay value. I found them rather too time based and frustrating to the point where they took off my attention of focusing on the main objective and suck in the misisons immersion.

I LOVED Asylum. Cannot express that enough. City was quite the letdown. I played through the story whereas in Asylum I did EVERYTHING. And the story in City just wasn't very good.
Origins is the game I was hoping City would be. The graphics are superb when turned up. The combat is a lot of fun and does seem to flow very well. A couple hiccups here and there with the counter button but nothing that truly detracts from it. The voice acting is amazing. I knew Batman was different but he still sounds very close to Conroy most of the time. The Joker though... that dude sounds exactly like Hamill.
The story in this game though is what puts it over the top for me. I've got over 30 hours into the game right now and I'm not quite done (so perhaps it will disappoint in the end), but I am loving this. It's such a wonderful telling of the Batman/Joker beginnings that I can't help but keep playing.
For me, this ranks just under Asylum and well above City. Can't wait for Knight.

This is a game that's annoying as hell, but in the end of the day, because of the inherent qualities of Arkham games, it's not that bad.
First, let me address the IGN review. The grapple and the electric gloves are NOT win buttons.
By the time you acquire the ability to grapple enemies to stone gargoyles, you will be facing 6, 7 enemies in the predator segments. But the grapple has at maximum 3 uses. Plus, it's not that effective, It attract the attention of the enemies.
When you acquire the electric gloves, it's the point when the regular enemies become totally annoying, always with guns and snipers infuriating the player. The gloves take a long road to be charged and discharge very quickly. It gives you more trouble to charge for use than not using it. Plus, even when is charged, it's not that effective, you still needing to take care to counter attack endless waves of enemies, with time patterns that are very annoying to counter attack. The gloves helps nothing, just help with enemies with armor, but those are few. You know what? The batrang move (A+B), that is allowed when you do a 8 hit combo (5 hits with the upgrade), it's much more a "win cheat" than the electrified gloves. Doing an 5 hit combo is very easy and fast to do, you just do your 5 hit combo, with 3 enemies on the floor, press A+B and it's done, 3 enemies defeated instantly.
Another point that this review is wrong. The boss battles are terrible. Or it's too easy (Deathstroke, Shocker) or hard, not because it's well crafted battle, but because the timings to avoid attacks are difficult to understand, which makes the controls feel sluggish (Copperhead, Bane. Bane battle in Asylum it's much superior, flows perfectly, the controls are very responsive). Frequently, death feels cheap, like if the controls are not responding well.
